First, it's important to acknowledge your feelings. As you've shared, you're feeling angry, understandably so. It's okay to feel this way. Reach out to your college counseling resources if you're feeling overwhelmed or just need someone impartial to talk to.

As for your parents, it's a difficult situation to be between blood relations and your core values. It's good to hear that you've spoken to them, as communication is key. However, understanding that changing someone's deep-rooted beliefs can take time.

Regarding your job decision, being a dispatcher for campus police does not necessarily align you with your parents' biases. You can use that position to promote fairness and equality. Make sure to communicate this with your roommate and assure them that your values are not reflected by your parents' attitudes. 

In the end, make sure to prioritize your mental health and well-being. Cutting off ties with toxic family can be painful, but at times, necessary for your growth. Once you are financially independent, such a decision could be easier to make. Meanwhile, surround yourself with positive influences and engage in self-care practices to help you navigate this challenge. 

Remember, you're not alone in this. Reach out and seek support whenever you need it.

post:
I'm so angry, I've known my parents were homophobic and transphobic from a young age. But I was blind to their racism because my father served a mostly African church (we're white). We lived in a mostly black town, and we live in a mostly Latino area now (but our congregation is yt). But now that I am an adult and especially after 2020 my eyes have been completely open to their behavior. Especially my mom, she says hateful and vile things towards people of other races, she said the N WORD! Just tonight she called my young neice who is half mexican only 'half bad". My parents do not understand how they are racist. Even when I blatently call them out   


I warned my roommate of my parents racism already and they made the decision to call the school to see if they can move dorms becuase they may find it necessary. At first I was upset but like an hour later hearing possibly the most racist jokes thus far I agree. I have spoken to them and told them I'm not really going to invite them or even want them to come up to visit at all, and I'm planning to hopefully cut them off. But that all depends especially if I get this job.   


And now I'm questioning if my roommate will be comfortable with ME if I choose to become a dispatcher for our campus police. But I can't cut my parents off if I don't. I need the money which is the only reason I'd do it.   


They have always made everyone around me (including myself) uncomfortable with their various forms of bigotry. I can not allow them to keep doing this.
reply:
Hi there,

Firstly, I'm sending you lots of empathy and strength. It's always hard when beliefs and behaviors of those closest to you conflict so seriously with your own values. It's important to remember that you are not responsible for the views of your parents and I believe you're taking a courageous step by looking to distance yourself from the toxicity. 

One strategy you may find useful is the concept of boundaries. Although it can be difficult, setting clear, firm boundaries about the behavior you will and won't tolerate when your parents are around you or in situations connected with you can be helpful.

Anticipate that boundary-setting will be met with resistance initially, as your parents are likely not used to having their views questioned. However, consistent reinforcement will help - when they cross the line, you could try to calmly state that their comment is unacceptable, and repeat as necessary.

Regarding your financial situation, it's really tough when you face the dichotomy of needing financial support and wanting to distance yourself due to toxicity. Pursuing your job as a campus dispatcher could give you the financial independence you need to establish your boundaries with your parents. 

About your roommate, a good and honest conversation explaining your situation could ease both of your worries. Transparency and communication can build trust in your relationship.

Feel free to reach out to mental health professionals available in the campus, if you think it might help. It's a journey, but remember you're not alone.

post:
A little preface - what the post is about:
I live in a country that is at war.
I can't find a job despite it is required of me.
I found a calling that I love, but parents don't let me do it.
I can't find a girl.
I am overweight.

Firstly, I graduated from the Ukrainian IT University 3 years ago.
In my third year of college, I realized that I didn't want to be a programmer, even though I had excellent grades.
I hate coding. Absolutely everything related to debugging code causes me uncontrollable anger and frustration. I can no longer spend 3 hours looking for a solution to 5 errors in the code that have nothing to do with the logic of the algorithm and are caused only by the specifics of the programming language. Even the thought that I need to learn a programming language makes my hands tremble and makes me irritable.
After graduating from college, I told my mom that I didn't want to be a programmer and I didn't want to go to an IT university. I want to find what I like in life.
The mother replied: ‚ÄúDo you understand what you are going to live on while you are looking for yourself? Without education, you will not be hired anywhere. Finish university, get a job, and then do whatever you want with your life."
In the end, I did. All the time I was studying, I thought that all the roads were open in front of me and I could do anything in life. I thought only lazy people can't find a job. As a student, I could find any part-time job at gas stations, call centers and ‚ÄúMcDonalds‚Äùs. I thought that when I graduated from university, I would take my diploma, go to the lowest paid job as a programmer, after a couple of years I would plow there, and try new things in my free time. That‚Äôs how I thoght until I graduated from university that I realized how wrong I was.
As soon as I graduated from university, all the "doors" of employers for students were closed. No one read my resume on job sites, my phone never rang. Attempts to look for work not in my specialty were also unsuccessful. Only then did I realize that in fact all the doors closed for me at the age of 15, when I first crossed the threshold of my IT college.
The main problem is that IT colleges and IT universities do not teach the necessary knowledge for work. It doesn't bother anyone at all. In Ukrainian colleges, they will forcefully teach a ton of useless subjects in modern meta-coding - from numerical methods to patent law. When I opened the job requirements, I lost heart. I spent 8 years studying to say that I know object oriented programming, I know 1997 database technologies and I can write code in 5 programming languages. But what else do I need:
- Framework #1 - unstudied
- Framework #2 - unstudied
- Framework #3 - unstudied
- Git technology - unlearned
- Modern wrapper for databases NameA - did not sound.
- I have no real experience with real projects from one year.
- I don't have a portfolio of works.
While I was "looking for a job" after a bad experience as a gas station cashier, I tried my hand at editing videos for YouTube. I have never been so inspired by what I do. The progress in motivation compared to what it was with programming was incredible for me. I worked on videos for 12 hours a day. When I started uploading videos, I saw that I get 100-300 views on the first five videos, while other beginner youtubers could not get more than 10.
It is obvious that it is quite difficult to get money from YouTube without monetization and audience‚Äôs support right away.
After the scandal, the mother said that she would help for some time, but if there were no successes, she would stop. When they donated the first five dollars to me, she seemed to be delighted, but completely stopped taking this idea seriously. She seems to deliberately ignore what I do in general, constantly distracting me and giving useless tasks since I have "a lot of free time."
When the war started in Ukraine, the job industry got f~ed. They began to take all the men from work and send them to the front line. The same goes for any men on the street.
25% of the population in Ukraine is unemployed.
Rewinding time forward to today, after 450 days of the war, they parents began to ‚Äúsoftly‚Äù hint to me that it was time to look for a job.
During the war, my mother does not let me go outside even for shopping. That doesn‚Äôt disturb her to propose me work at a constructions.
Since there is a war now, I cannot work in the office or on the street - that is, it is only remote work. Remote work without work experience is either work in a call center, or work as a dispatcher for transportation in America (this is how it works in Ukraine). Accordingly, I have a very small selection of vacancies and a giant wall of ‚ÄúHR-managers‚Äù with gigantic unrealistic requirements.
At the moment I live in a village where there is not much to talk to, so I can‚Äôt even count on meeting girls, I can‚Äôt even find friends.
Even if suddenly a lonely lady was found in my neighboring house, agreeing to spend some time, she would not be very pleased to communicate with me because im overweight (175 cm, 100 kg). I stopped eating sweets and started to lose a decent amount of weight, but it will take a long time anyway. Btw I'm a virgin at 26.
My question is what to do with all this?
Everything is so bad that I can‚Äôt even ask a good question.

P.S.
Today I was contacted by the HR of a travel company and she offered a job as a dispatcher. I have an interview tomorrow. I doubt that I need it. I understand that I sound now like a manchild but hear me out.
At the moment we have enough money to survive. We do not save money, but so far we have everything. When I asked my mother what they were going to spend my money on (I expected that this money would be safely taken from me), she replied ‚Äúthat it will be your money, if you want, spend it on entertainment or shopping or save it for what you need‚Äù.
As a result, I have many questions.
How will I spend money on entertainment if I can be caught and mobilized to the front? What exactly should I buy if I can't go to the store?
I can‚Äôt even rent an apartment for such a salary, that is, it‚Äôs no luck to move out from my parents. From all this I draw one conclusion. They demand a job from me simply because ‚ÄúWell, why do we work and you don‚Äôt?‚Äù Despite the fact that there is no talk of taking money from me for rent or food.
So that's why I think I don't need a job - because for me at the moment the TIME spent on my channel is more important than money. And if I don't have time, I don't need money. But if I don't find a job, they will pester me every day, accusing me of lazyness. Should I accept a job offer?
reply:
Striking a balance between personal passions and pragmatic necessities isn't always easy, but ultimately, it's invaluable. If your parents are insisting on employment for your well-being, you may want to consider taking the dispatcher role. This doesn't mean giving up on your passion; you can still work on your YouTube editing as a side hobby while earning income and showing a sign of proactivity to others. 

The job might also offer unforeseen opportunities or open doors you didn't know existed until you stepped foot through them. Just remember, an occupation doesn't define your entire life or future.

As for your weight, it's excellent that you've decided to take steps toward a healthier lifestyle. While outward appearances might affect initial impressions, always remember that genuine relationship comes from mutual understanding, not merely looks. 

Your situation sounds challenging indeed but hang in there, everyone faces periods of uncertainty. Take each day as it comes, making small steps toward both your immediate and long term goals.

reply:
I am truly sorry to hear that you are experiencing so many challenges at once. The situation you describe is extremely complex and it must be difficult to navigate all of this, especially in a time of war.

Regarding your career, it seems you've identified video editing and creating YouTube content as a source of joy and motivation for you. Despite the resistance from your parents, you are within your right as an adult to follow a career path that brings you happiness. If it's feasible, continue focusing on developing your skills in video editing and work towards monetizing your YouTube channel. This could eventually become your source of income, albeit it might take time.

Regarding the job interview, consider attending it even if you're unsure. You may glean new insights or even stumble upon new opportunities. Jobs can often lead to learning experiences and necessary life skills. Remember, you can always say 'no' to a job offer if it turns out to not be right for you.

Your concern about your weight and lack of romantic relationships is valid and these things can deeply impact our mental health. You've done well to start modifying your diet, which shows you're dedicated to improving your physical health. Consider incorporating even small amounts of exercise into your daily routine - not just for weight loss, but for the mental health benefits exercise brings.

Lastly, you don't need a job simply because your parents ask you to have one, but having one could give you a sense of purpose, focus and potentially open up new opportunities. Whatever you decide to do, remember that your worth isn't measured by your employment status, your weight or whether you've been in a romantic relationship. You are worthy and deserving of happiness and success.

Stay strong. Your situation sounds very difficult, but remember you also possess great resilience and capability to navigate through this. Seeking professional advice might be beneficial in terms of exploring various avenues for your career and personal growth. I wish you all the luck with your decision.

reply:
I'm sorry to hear you're going through such a tough time right now. It sounds like you are dealing with a number of stressors including living in a war-torn environment, unemployment, being overweight and lacking the support and understanding you need from your parents. All of these challenges can certainly take a significant mental and emotional toll. As a clinician, I would recommend trying to tackle these one at a time. 

First of all, regarding career and finding work: It's clear that you have a passion for video editing. Could you perhaps use your IT and coding skills in a way that supports this passion? The creative and tech industries often overlap and your skills could be very valuable. Also, try not to perceive your IT degree as a limitation but rather as a tool that opens up a variety of opportunities. 

With regards to the job offer you received, it might not be what you ideally want to do, but it could help bridge the gap while you seek other opportunities and it would likely provide a sense of purpose and structure. 

Regarding your physical health, you mentioned that you've already started making changes in your diet which is a great step. Perhaps you could also start incorporating some form of physical activity within the limitations of your situation - maybe basic body weight exercises at home.

In terms of your relationship with your parents, it seems that open dialogue might be helpful. Perhaps express to them how you feel about your career aspirations - they might not fully understand your passion for video editing and its potential as a career.

In terms of your mental health, it could be beneficial to seek support from an mental health professional, even if it is remote due to your current circumstances. Remember, it's OK to ask for help and take care of your mental health, just as you would your physical health. 

Finally, remember, it's okay not to have all the answers right now. Take small steps and remember to be kind to yourself during this difficult time.

During the war, my mother does not let me go outside even for shopping. That doesn‚Äôt disturb her to propose me work at a constructions.
Since there is a war now, I cannot work in the office or on the street - that is, it is only remote work. Remote work without work experience is either work in a call center, or work as a dispatcher for transportation in America (this is how it works in Ukraine). Accordingly, I have a very small selection of vacancies and a giant wall of ‚ÄúHR-managers‚Äù with gigantic unrealistic requirements.
At the moment I live in a village where there is not much to talk to, so I can‚Äôt even count on meeting girls, I can‚Äôt even find friends.
Even if suddenly a lonely lady was found in my neighboring house, agreeing to spend some time, she would not be very pleased to communicate with me because im overweight (175 cm, 100 kg). I stopped eating sweets and started to lose a decent amount of weight, but it will take a long time anyway. Btw I'm a virgin at 26.
My question is what to do with all this?
Everything is so bad that I can‚Äôt even ask a good question.

P.S.
Today I was contacted by the HR of a travel company and she offered a job as a dispatcher. I have an interview tomorrow. I doubt that I need it. I understand that I sound now like a manchild but hear me out.
At the moment we have enough money to survive. We do not save money, but so far we have everything. When I asked my mother what they were going to spend my money on (I expected that this money would be safely taken from me), she replied ‚Äúthat it will be your money, if you want, spend it on entertainment or shopping or save it for what you need‚Äù.
As a result, I have many questions.
How will I spend money on entertainment if I can be caught and mobilized to the front? What exactly should I buy if I can't go to the store?
I can‚Äôt even rent an apartment for such a salary, that is, it‚Äôs no luck to move out from my parents. From all this I draw one conclusion. They demand a job from me simply because ‚ÄúWell, why do we work and you don‚Äôt?‚Äù Despite the fact that there is no talk of taking money from me for rent or food.
So that's why I think I don't need a job - because for me at the moment the TIME spent on my channel is more important than money. And if I don't have time, I don't need money. But if I don't find a job, they will pester me every day, accusing me of lazyness. Should I accept a job offer?
reply:
Hi there, 

Your situation sounds really complex and challenging. It seems like you have a passion (YouTube editing) that brings joy and fulfillment, and it may be worth continuing to hone this skill in your spare time for potential career possibilities in the future. 

If the offered job allows for some flexibility in terms of work hours and doesn't affect your physical safety, it might be worth considering. You'd not only satisfy your parent's request, but also generate some income. Having your own money opens up the possibility for greater independence, even if you currently don't have a plan for it. 

To cope with feelings of isolation, you could try to find online communities linked to your interests. Apart from providing socialization, these can provide support, inspiration, or potentially even collaboration opportunities. 

As for your weight, it's commendable that you've made efforts to improve your health and have seen some success. Continue your journey at your own pace, prioritizing health over numbers.

Remember, you're not alone. Reach out to online forums, helplines, and mental health resources that can provide further support. You've shown resilience in tough times, and these unique experiences can cultivate strength for future challenges. You do not have to figure everything out at once, take one step at a time.

post:
A little preface - what the post is about:
I live in a country that is at war.
I can't find a job despite it is required of me.
I found a calling that I love, but parents don't let me do it.
I can't find a girl.
I am overweight.

Firstly, I graduated from the Ukrainian IT University 3 years ago.
In my third year of college, I realized that I didn't want to be a programmer, even though I had excellent grades.
I hate coding. Absolutely everything related to debugging code causes me uncontrollable anger and frustration. I can no longer spend 3 hours looking for a solution to 5 errors in the code that have nothing to do with the logic of the algorithm and are caused only by the specifics of the programming language. Even the thought that I need to learn a programming language makes my hands tremble and makes me irritable.
After graduating from college, I told my mom that I didn't want to be a programmer and I didn't want to go to an IT university. I want to find what I like in life.
The mother replied: ‚ÄúDo you understand what you are going to live on while you are looking for yourself? Without education, you will not be hired anywhere. Finish university, get a job, and then do whatever you want with your life."
In the end, I did. All the time I was studying, I thought that all the roads were open in front of me and I could do anything in life. I thought only lazy people can't find a job. As a student, I could find any part-time job at gas stations, call centers and ‚ÄúMcDonalds‚Äùs. I thought that when I graduated from university, I would take my diploma, go to the lowest paid job as a programmer, after a couple of years I would plow there, and try new things in my free time. That‚Äôs how I thoght until I graduated from university that I realized how wrong I was.
As soon as I graduated from university, all the "doors" of employers for students were closed. No one read my resume on job sites, my phone never rang. Attempts to look for work not in my specialty were also unsuccessful. Only then did I realize that in fact all the doors closed for me at the age of 15, when I first crossed the threshold of my IT college.
The main problem is that IT colleges and IT universities do not teach the necessary knowledge for work. It doesn't bother anyone at all. In Ukrainian colleges, they will forcefully teach a ton of useless subjects in modern meta-coding - from numerical methods to patent law. When I opened the job requirements, I lost heart. I spent 8 years studying to say that I know object oriented programming, I know 1997 database technologies and I can write code in 5 programming languages. But what else do I need:
- Framework #1 - unstudied
- Framework #2 - unstudied
- Framework #3 - unstudied
- Git technology - unlearned
- Modern wrapper for databases NameA - did not sound.
- I have no real experience with real projects from one year.
- I don't have a portfolio of works.
While I was "looking for a job" after a bad experience as a gas station cashier, I tried my hand at editing videos for YouTube. I have never been so inspired by what I do. The progress in motivation compared to what it was with programming was incredible for me. I worked on videos for 12 hours a day. When I started uploading videos, I saw that I get 100-300 views on the first five videos, while other beginner youtubers could not get more than 10.
It is obvious that it is quite difficult to get money from YouTube without monetization and audience‚Äôs support right away.
After the scandal, the mother said that she would help for some time, but if there were no successes, she would stop. When they donated the first five dollars to me, she seemed to be delighted, but completely stopped taking this idea seriously. She seems to deliberately ignore what I do in general, constantly distracting me and giving useless tasks since I have "a lot of free time."
When the war started in Ukraine, the job industry got f~ed. They began to take all the men from work and send them to the front line. The same goes for any men on the street.
25% of the population in Ukraine is unemployed.
Rewinding time forward to today, after 450 days of the war, they parents began to ‚Äúsoftly‚Äù hint to me that it was time to look for a job.
During the war, my mother does not let me go outside even for shopping. That doesn‚Äôt disturb her to propose me work at a constructions.
Since there is a war now, I cannot work in the office or on the street - that is, it is only remote work. Remote work without work experience is either work in a call center, or work as a dispatcher for transportation in America (this is how it works in Ukraine). Accordingly, I have a very small selection of vacancies and a giant wall of ‚ÄúHR-managers‚Äù with gigantic unrealistic requirements.
At the moment I live in a village where there is not much to talk to, so I can‚Äôt even count on meeting girls, I can‚Äôt even find friends.
Even if suddenly a lonely lady was found in my neighboring house, agreeing to spend some time, she would not be very pleased to communicate with me because im overweight (175 cm, 100 kg). I stopped eating sweets and started to lose a decent amount of weight, but it will take a long time anyway. Btw I'm a virgin at 26.
My question is what to do with all this?
Everything is so bad that I can‚Äôt even ask a good question.

P.S.
Today I was contacted by the HR of a travel company and she offered a job as a dispatcher. I have an interview tomorrow. I doubt that I need it. I understand that I sound now like a manchild but hear me out.
At the moment we have enough money to survive. We do not save money, but so far we have everything. When I asked my mother what they were going to spend my money on (I expected that this money would be safely taken from me), she replied ‚Äúthat it will be your money, if you want, spend it on entertainment or shopping or save it for what you need‚Äù.
As a result, I have many questions.
How will I spend money on entertainment if I can be caught and mobilized to the front? What exactly should I buy if I can't go to the store?
I can‚Äôt even rent an apartment for such a salary, that is, it‚Äôs no luck to move out from my parents. From all this I draw one conclusion. They demand a job from me simply because ‚ÄúWell, why do we work and you don‚Äôt?‚Äù Despite the fact that there is no talk of taking money from me for rent or food.
So that's why I think I don't need a job - because for me at the moment the TIME spent on my channel is more important than money. And if I don't have time, I don't need money. But if I don't find a job, they will pester me every day, accusing me of lazyness. Should I accept a job offer?
reply:
Sorry to hear that you're going through this. Your situation sounds very tough, but remember, it‚Äôs okay to carve your own path and not follow the expected norms. Your passion for video editing is a great strength and something you clearly love, so do keep investing in it. Your age isn't a stop sign, there have been many late bloomers in history, so keep pushing forward.

The situation with your parents seems difficult, and while they seem to want the best for you, their approach might not align with what you want for yourself. It might be helpful to have a sincere heart-to-heart with them about your ambitions and feelings. Explain how important video editing is to you and how hard you're willing to work on it.

On the job front, and considering your current circumstances, the dispatcher job could be a good opportunity for now. A steady income can offer a sense of security and may reduce tension with your parents. You could potentially juggle both tasks for a while and see how that goes.

Dealing with weight is not easy, it's a life-long commitment. Slow and consistent changes in diet and exercise will help. Also, remember that physical appearance is not the only defining factor in any relationship. Confidence, personality and shared interests often weight much more. 

Take care of your mental health. It may be beneficial to seek help from a therapist or counselor amid these hard times. You're facing a lot of challenges all at once, and it's OK to reach out for professional help. You're not alone.

post:
I don't want to keep you guys reading for too long so I'll try and quick.

Okay so I am a Romanian citizen that has moved to the uk 5 years ago( i am now almost 18 as I'm writing this)
I was known for always speaking too much, it didn't matter that you were, a girl or a boy, I always had good conversation with everyone, i always made loads of friends, and whenever i saw a girl i liked i could not stop talking to her even in lessons , this was all in my home country, however me and my loving family moved into the uk.
Over the last 4-5 years ive spent in the uk school (year 9-13) I have never made a single friend or had s conversation longer than 10-15 minutes, it got the point where I was hearing everyone calling me the quiet kid and i could not do anything about it,  i would rather be tortured with lava than talk and say something in the classroom unless i was privately speaking with someone. This gets much worse when I am setting next to any girls no matter who she is , i can't even say a damn word, i miss every single party even the last day of school which was a ball/banquet.

Weirdly this is only happening to people my age, i talk alot at work with my colleges who are older.
reply:
Hey there! Sounds like you're grappling with some major changes and they've hit your confidence a bit. Moving to a whole new country is tough, the cultures and languages may be different but remember that deep down, people are all the same. 

It sounds like you're a naturally sociable person, use that strength! Maybe try joining clubs or societies for things you're interested in, this could be an easier environment to make friends as you already have something in common. Consider speaking to a mentor or teacher about your concerns, they might be able to offer advice or pair you up with someone who can help you acclimatise. 

Also remember, it's okay to be the quiet guy sometimes! And as for girls, they can be just as nervous and shy as you. Try starting with small talk, simple questions about their day or interests. Good conversation often starts from there.

Hang in there, bud. Remember every setback is just setting you up for a comeback!

This gets much worse when I am setting next to any girls no matter who she is , i can't even say a damn word, i miss every single party even the last day of school which was a ball/banquet.

Weirdly this is only happening to people my age, i talk alot at work with my colleges who are older.
reply:
Hi there. It sounds like you're having a hard time adjusting after moving to the UK, and that's fairly normal to feel like you're under pressure because of a change in environment and culture. Such transitions can significantly affect our confidence levels and social interactions. I understand your situation can be distressing, so I'd like to offer some suggestions.

First and foremost, remember that it's okay to take time to adjust and find your confidence again. It's great to hear that you're able to talk freely with your older colleagues at work‚Äîit shows that you still possess those social qualities you describe from back in Romania. 

Secondly, you might want to consider seeking professional help to talk things through and get another perspective. Counsellors and therapists specialized in transition are there to help. Also, the school should have support services that you can access. It's not a sign of weakness to seek help when you're struggling.

Next, try to get involved in groups or clubs where you share common interests with others. This can be a launching pad for conversations and for friendships to form. 

Finally, remember to be patient with yourself. Things like this can take time. It‚Äôs about small steps, not big leaps. The person you were in Romania is still there. Take care!

This gets much worse when I am setting next to any girls no matter who she is , i can't even say a damn word, i miss every single party even the last day of school which was a ball/banquet.

Weirdly this is only happening to people my age, i talk alot at work with my colleges who are older.
reply:
It sounds like you're going through a tough time and you're finding it difficult to communicate and connect with your peers in the UK compared to your home country. This kind of adjustment can be challenging, especially at your age when social connections are so important. Perhaps the cultural shift has made you more self-conscious and that could be why you're struggling. 

A lot of people go through periods of being socially anxious, especially when they're in new environments or situations. Speaking to someone about this, like a counselor or a therapist, could provide you with some useful strategies to manage this situation. 

Meanwhile, here are some things you might find helpful. Firstly, you might find it comforting to know that you're not alone. Many people experience social anxiety and it is something that can improve with time and support. Secondly, you might want to practice small interactions with your peers. Start with simply saying hello and gradually build up to more extended interactions. Finally, try not to put too much pressure on yourself. It's okay not to have everything figured out right now, and it's okay not to hit it off with everyone you meet.

As you turn 18, more opportunities for you to meet like-minded individuals outside the school environment will arise. Remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace.

Weirdly this is only happening to people my age, i talk alot at work with my colleges who are older.
reply:
It sounds like you're experiencing quite a bit of social anxiety, especially surrounding your peers at school. It's very common to experience social anxiety in adolescence when we're surrounded by others who are evaluating and judging us. It's understandable because these are formative years for our social identities.

There could be multifaceted reasons for why you feel more comfortable talking to your older colleagues at work. They're from a different social environment, with less pressure and expectation than what's found amongst peers in school. In addition, adults generally carry less judgment and are often more accepting of individual differences. 

Adapting to a new culture is not easy, the norms and language barrier can make it even harder to build relationships. It might be easier to connect with your peers if you share something you‚Äôre passionate about. Join a club or group focused on something you enjoy, there, you'll likely find like-minded individuals. 

You may also want to consider seeking professional help if your anxiety becomes too overwhelming, it's perfectly okay to ask for support. They can help you with coping mechanisms and provide strategies to help you manage these situations. We all need a bit of help sometimes, and there's no shame in asking for it. Remember, you're not alone in this.

Weirdly this is only happening to people my age, i talk alot at work with my colleges who are older.
reply:
Hi there,

Thank you for sharing your story. Adjusting to a new environment can indeed be challenging, regardless of where you're from. It is possible that cultural shock or adjustments may have experienced on moving from Romania to the UK could be affecting your social dynamics. Do not worry, however, the changes that come with such transitions do not have to be permanent.

One initial suggestion I have is that you could try connecting with other Romanian communities in the UK, as they could provide a sense of familiarity which might help you regain your comfort in expressing yourself initially. Gradually, pushing your communication comfort zone could start reaching out to people outside your community too.

The fact that you're more comfortable speaking with people older than you at work might be a helpful thing to explore, it may be that you find interactions with them less intimidating, or they remind you of familiar role models. You could try applying the same approach when communicating with individuals your age, they are still people, just younger, and maybe also trying to navigate their social skills as well.

Mental health is important. If your feelings and these changes start to cause significant distress or hinder your daily functioning, you might want to consult a mental health professional for possible guidance. Therapy and counseling services are a supportive resource in such situations.

With time, patience, and a little effort, it‚Äôs likely that you‚Äôll find your way back to being the social butterfly you are known to be. Just remember, it‚Äôs okay to take small steps and allow yourself to adjust at your own pace. Your experiences and feelings are valid and always remember to be kind to yourself.

All the best.

post:
This turned out to be really long, so thank you for just reading this.

I am not expecting any answers, but I would be happy to hear different opinions.

I am a 31 years old spoilt white male, born to privilege, who is wasting their life.

I feel unhappy with myself, beacuse everything I have ever done was given to me.

​

I have failed two bachelor degrees.

The job I have has been given to me and there is no pressure to do anything meaningful with it, because it is a minute team and it does not force me to engage with people or present any consequences for failure.

I feel no real desire to be good at it.

When that eventually falls through, I have no pressure to get an actual job, because, although I will not live a life of luxury, I will never really have to face any financial hardships (my family owns a bit of property).

​

I feel no reason to seek out connections with people, because I feel it is too much work, without too much reward.

I know, rationally, that the work is worth the reward, because it brings me happiness to connect with people, but not enough to stop myself from actively pushing people away or seeking out connections.

My family is my only real source of meaningful connections with other people, however there are issues there.

My parents are content to never push me to do anything and they let me just exist in the state that I am in.

They do that, because they need me to take care of their emotional needs and serve as an emotional drain for their baggage, while simultaneously refusing to include me in any meaningful conversations which could potentially lead to change.

They also show real support and love, when my problems do not involve them actually changing.

I used to be very close to my sibling, and they show me real support and love, but they have grown distant, since they now have their own family to support and issues to take care of.

Since I have been spoiled from an young age, my safety net is very toxic to me.

​

I have no real desire to improve myself, because I am too scared to change what is essentially a lifestyle that brings no hardships.

More often than not I want to find meaning in life but that requires at least a nominally consistent drive for self-improvement, so that usually fizzles out within days or weeks.

I have been to several therapists, but that ultimately fails, when I just stop engaging, because the desire for change dries up when I fall back to habits that lead to stagnation.

Habits, such as ignoring people, doing nominal self-improvement (i.e. taking the occasional online class or certificate for job-related skills only to do nothing with them and let them expire), consuming media, which makes me feel good about myself, and general laziness.

I have been diagnosed with depression and generalized anxiety disorder, because of my general lack of desire to take basic care of myself, beyond personal hygiene, and actively ignoring the few people from school who still want to be friends.

The only friend I keep in toch with (on and off) tries to make me get off my ass and actually do something, anything, since that is the only way to find something which will make me feel happy and not just content.

​

I often have suicidal ideations, but I know they will not be realized, because that would be an utter waste of all the opportunities that have been given to me as well as any potential I might have.

I also realize the inherent contradiction, between feeling that I have potential worth and feeling bad, because I'm not doing anything about it.

​

I realize that my emotional growth is stunted and I have no real desire to grow, or I would try to do something to change it.

​

All of this makes me a burden to myself, society and family, since I have no desire to give anything of value back, and I do not feel happy with myself, because I want to do something I define as worthwhile.

I have no way of knowing what is worthwhile to me, without trying stuff that I feel might be, but I also have no desire to try things I feel might be.

I do not have any external or much internal pressure to actively change, and it's easy to just ignore myself and by extension people around me.

Ignoring people arond me makes me feel shitty, so I just hate myself more and fall into this spiral of discontent, where I hate myself, but not enough to change.

So I neither hate, nor love myself enough to change.

I just feel I am wasting what was given, which is not enough motivation for me to do anything with my life.

Add to that the fact I should have been going through this when I was 16 (if I'm being generous with myself) and the general understanding that I am wallowing in convenient misery, instead of doing anything about it.

So, being a spoied, whiny, self-hating loser at 31, it's easy for me to distance myself from myself as a way to reconcile with the fact that I don't like myself.

This whole thing also makes me feel very egotistic.

​

The options I see and my questions are:

1. How do I force myself to change, when I don't really want to and have no external pressure to do so?
2. How do I learn to live with myself and not care so much that I have no value to other people?
3. How do I learn to find meaning in what little value I have?

​

Thank you again, for reading this far.
reply:
Hey there! That's a lot of self-awareness and insight for one post. First thing's first, I strongly suggest going back to therapy, whether you feel a desire for change or not. A helpful approach might be trying a different style of therapy or looking at your habits from a different perspective. 

To answer your queries:

1) Change is tough, but sometimes it's not about "forcing" but exploring little steps. Life won't always hand you external pressure - sometimes we've got to be our own catalysts. Choose one small thing that you feel comfortable altering and focus on that. 

2) Value can be subjective. It sounds like you're wrestling a lot with self worth. Remember, everyone has strengths, it‚Äôs just a matter of finding what yours are. 

3) Possibly find a cause that resonates with you - environment, animal welfare, human rights, etc - and volunteer time or contribute in other ways that are feasible to you. It might give you a sense of accomplishment and purpose. 

Try to step outside your comfort zone - that's usually where change really happens! You're stronger than you think mate. You can do this! üí™

I also realize the inherent contradiction, between feeling that I have potential worth and feeling bad, because I'm not doing anything about it.

​

I realize that my emotional growth is stunted and I have no real desire to grow, or I would try to do something to change it.

​

All of this makes me a burden to myself, society and family, since I have no desire to give anything of value back, and I do not feel happy with myself, because I want to do something I define as worthwhile.

I have no way of knowing what is worthwhile to me, without trying stuff that I feel might be, but I also have no desire to try things I feel might be.

I do not have any external or much internal pressure to actively change, and it's easy to just ignore myself and by extension people around me.

Ignoring people arond me makes me feel shitty, so I just hate myself more and fall into this spiral of discontent, where I hate myself, but not enough to change.

So I neither hate, nor love myself enough to change.

I just feel I am wasting what was given, which is not enough motivation for me to do anything with my life.

Add to that the fact I should have been going through this when I was 16 (if I'm being generous with myself) and the general understanding that I am wallowing in convenient misery, instead of doing anything about it.

So, being a spoied, whiny, self-hating loser at 31, it's easy for me to distance myself from myself as a way to reconcile with the fact that I don't like myself.

This whole thing also makes me feel very egotistic.

​

The options I see and my questions are:

1. How do I force myself to change, when I don't really want to and have no external pressure to do so?
2. How do I learn to live with myself and not care so much that I have no value to other people?
3. How do I learn to find meaning in what little value I have?

​

Thank you again, for reading this far.
reply:
First of all, your self-awareness is vital and commendable; it's the first step in both recognizing the problem and taking the necessary steps towards growth. Please remember this is not an immediate process. It's going to take baby steps and that's okay.

Dealing with privileged guilt, depression, and anxiety can be overwhelming. The important thing is to not minimize your feelings just because the source is different from what most people experience. It may be helpful to rethink what privilege means to you‚Äî it doesn't have to mean "don't use it at all". It can mean "use it for good" or "use it to improve on yourself".

The boredom and lack of willpower you describe are classic symptoms of depression, and often, breaking the inertia is the hardest part. You mentioned seeing a therapist and stopping due to stagnation‚Äîthis is a very common occurrence. They say the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results. If past therapy efforts didn't work, it might be useful to try a different approach.

On your question about forcing change: instead of "forcing" yourself to change, maybe focus on building habits, start small. You don‚Äôt need to climb the mountain in a day, just start with one step, no matter how small, and celebrate it.

Second, it's not about not caring so much of having no value, but it might be more helpful to shift the focus from what you perceive as a lack of value to what you can uniquely offer to others. You have your own set of experiences, thoughts, feelings that are entirely unique to you which gives you inherent value.

Lastly, finding meaning isn't a mathematical formula, it isn't a solution you find but a process. The "little value" you mention is highly relative. Instead ask, is there something that sparks even a little joy or curiosity? Remember, it's about the progress, not perfection.

Keep talking, keep reaching out, and keep seeking assistance. Life can and does get better, but sometimes it needs a little nudge to help it along.

This turned out to be really long, so thank you for just reading this.

I am not expecting any answers, but I would be happy to hear different opinions.

I am a 31 years old spoilt white male, born to privilege, who is wasting their life.

I feel unhappy with myself, beacuse everything I have ever done was given to me.

​

I have failed two bachelor degrees.

The job I have has been given to me and there is no pressure to do anything meaningful with it, because it is a minute team and it does not force me to engage with people or present any consequences for failure.

I feel no real desire to be good at it.

When that eventually falls through, I have no pressure to get an actual job, because, although I will not live a life of luxury, I will never really have to face any financial hardships (my family owns a bit of property).

​

I feel no reason to seek out connections with people, because I feel it is too much work, without too much reward.

I know, rationally, that the work is worth the reward, because it brings me happiness to connect with people, but not enough to stop myself from actively pushing people away or seeking out connections.

My family is my only real source of meaningful connections with other people, however there are issues there.

My parents are content to never push me to do anything and they let me just exist in the state that I am in.

They do that, because they need me to take care of their emotional needs and serve as an emotional drain for their baggage, while simultaneously refusing to include me in any meaningful conversations which could potentially lead to change.

They also show real support and love, when my problems do not involve them actually changing.

I used to be very close to my sibling, and they show me real support and love, but they have grown distant, since they now have their own family to support and issues to take care of.

Since I have been spoiled from an young age, my safety net is very toxic to me.

​

I have no real desire to improve myself, because I am too scared to change what is essentially a lifestyle that brings no hardships.

More often than not I want to find meaning in life but that requires at least a nominally consistent drive for self-improvement, so that usually fizzles out within days or weeks.

I have been to several therapists, but that ultimately fails, when I just stop engaging, because the desire for change dries up when I fall back to habits that lead to stagnation.

Habits, such as ignoring people, doing nominal self-improvement (i.e. taking the occasional online class or certificate for job-related skills only to do nothing with them and let them expire), consuming media, which makes me feel good about myself, and general laziness.

I have been diagnosed with depression and generalized anxiety disorder, because of my general lack of desire to take basic care of myself, beyond personal hygiene, and actively ignoring the few people from school who still want to be friends.

The only friend I keep in toch with (on and off) tries to make me get off my ass and actually do something, anything, since that is the only way to find something which will make me feel happy and not just content.

​

I often have suicidal ideations, but I know they will not be realized, because that would be an utter waste of all the opportunities that have been given to me as well as any potential I might have.

I also realize the inherent contradiction, between feeling that I have potential worth and feeling bad, because I'm not doing anything about it.

​

I realize that my emotional growth is stunted and I have no real desire to grow, or I would try to do something to change it.

​

All of this makes me a burden to myself, society and family, since I have no desire to give anything of value back, and I do not feel happy with myself, because I want to do something I define as worthwhile.

I have no way of knowing what is worthwhile to me, without trying stuff that I feel might be, but I also have no desire to try things I feel might be.

I do not have any external or much internal pressure to actively change, and it's easy to just ignore myself and by extension people around me.

Ignoring people arond me makes me feel shitty, so I just hate myself more and fall into this spiral of discontent, where I hate myself, but not enough to change.

So I neither hate, nor love myself enough to change.

I just feel I am wasting what was given, which is not enough motivation for me to do anything with my life.

Add to that the fact I should have been going through this when I was 16 (if I'm being generous with myself) and the general understanding that I am wallowing in convenient misery, instead of doing anything about it.

So, being a spoied, whiny, self-hating loser at 31, it's easy for me to distance myself from myself as a way to reconcile with the fact that I don't like myself.

This whole thing also makes me feel very egotistic.

​

The options I see and my questions are:

1. How do I force myself to change, when I don't really want to and have no external pressure to do so?
2. How do I learn to live with myself and not care so much that I have no value to other people?
3. How do I learn to find meaning in what little value I have?

​

Thank you again, for reading this far.
reply:
Thank you so much for sharing your feelings and thought process so in depth, it certainly makes us appreciate the complexity of the situation you're in. From what you've written, it's pretty clear that you're feeling stuck and confused, but also with a need to change, which is a good starting point!

Acknowledging that you have been privileged due to the circumstances of your birth, and ensuing guilt about the resulting inaction might be very hard to bear. But it can also be used constructively. Every person has a unique journey and yours starts with introspection, which you're already doing. 

First, it's crucial to tackle the issue of your depression and anxiety. Having a mental health condition can cloud our thoughts and make it hard to see past our fears and insecurities. So ensure you are engaging with a healthcare provider to manage and treat these conditions. 

Your feeling of discontent, despite privilege, can definitely be frustrating, but it's vital to remember that mental health and happiness cannot be entirely attributed or attached to external measures of success. 

From what you told us, it appears you're dealing with motivational issues that might be affected by the environment you're in. It could be constructive to explore therapy styles such as motivational interviewing or cognitive behavioural therapy(CBT), as these can lead you to find your intrinsic motivation.

From what you've shared, it sounds like there could be benefits in revisiting your relationships with your family. For some people, a certain level of independence or boundary-setting can be helpful in managing relationships that might feel somewhat burdening or emotionally draining.

Lastly, it might be helpful to start experimenting with new activities, hobbies, or experiences, however small they may be. Growth often sprouts from small seeds. Reflect on your interests and try to explore these interests further.

I hope these suggestions ring true for you. Remember, it's a journey and small steps forward still mean progress. Your emotions are valid and it's perfectly okay to feel this way. Truly wishing the best for you.

reply:
Hello,

First of all, I want to commend you for taking the step to share your feelings--it clearly isn't easy, particularly when it involves such a deep level of self-awareness and introspection. Acknowledging these feelings is a necessary part to finding a more positive way forward.

Without discounting any potential answers you may receive here, consider the possibility of revisiting therapy. Sometimes, it takes a few attempts to find the right therapist or the right kind of therapy that genuinely clicks with you. Cognitive Behavioral therapy, for example could potentially help in recognizing and changing unhelpful thought patterns.

It sounds as though you're stuck in a vicious cycle of self-recrimination and self-isolation. This could be a manifestation of depression, or it could be indicative of deeper unresolved feelings or traumas. If therapy is an option for you, it could be beneficial to explore these areas.

In the meantime, although you have described your lack of motivation to change, it's evident from your questions - you have the desire to grow, to change, and to cultivate meaning in your life. It's small steps. Find one small thing you can do each day that pushes you out of your comfort zone. Also, try to set some achievable goals for yourself that are independent from what others think or how they might perceive you. Your value is not defined by other people.

Consider volunteering as another step forward. This could provide you with a sense of purpose and take the focus off yourself, while making a positive contribution to the world around you. Moreover, it could also help you to form new connections with people.

Remember - it's okay to ask for help, and it's okay to not have all the answers right now. You have started on a path toward change just by acknowledging how you feel. Sometimes, we all need a bit of guidance to navigate through these feelings, and there's absolutely no shame in seeking that out.

Thank you for sharing, and I wish you the best. Keep reaching out, keep talking - you're not alone in this journey.

reply:
I'm really glad you took the time to share all this and it's clear that you're going through a very difficult time. Firstly, you're not alone in these feelings and accepting that there's a struggle is a crucial step towards seeking solutions. 

Regarding your points:

1. The desire to change comes from within and nobody can instigate it but yourself. Set small achievable goals - you don't have to climb the mountain in a day. Even if it‚Äôs just waking up half an hour earlier or reading a book for 30 minutes each day, gradually, you'll gain a sense of accomplishment and momentum for bigger changes.

2. It sounds like your sense of self-worth is tightly knitted with how much value you perceive to be offering others. It's important to remember that your worth isn't defined by productivity or utility alone. Reflect on your qualities that add indirect value. Everyone has a unique contribution to the world, even if it doesn't seem like it right now.

3. Meaning can be derived from the smallest things - it doesn't have to be monumental or life-changing. Start with small things that give you joy or satisfaction. Find the value in everyday tasks and moments.

Given your past experiences with therapy and existing diagnoses, seeking professional help is highly recommended, especially considering your suicidal ideations. ‚ÄòFalling back into old habits‚Äô is part of the journey. Being persistent in therapy is an ongoing process and it‚Äôs okay to slip up sometimes. 

Remember, it is never too late to bring about change. A stagnant life doesn't have to stay that way forever. Start with baby steps and persistence. As clich√© as it may sound, it‚Äôs going to be a journey, not a race. Stay strong and keep reaching out, there are people ready to listen and help.

post:
Hey everyone. I didn't know where to post this, or if I'm asking for advice or venting. That is to say, any kind of response is welcome, both advice and general statements, I don't mind. 

So I'm (M 23) probably the black sheep of the family. Not exactly how you might expect though. I'm in good shape, have a decent job, a house, I recently got married, get along great with my wife(F 21).

I grew up to a family who were and are, extremely poor. Most people don't really believe or fully understand what it means when a person who grew up poor says that. It feels like such an understatement. To be clear, poor as in "I'm shocked CPS didn't take me away" poor, no food sometimes and parents struggling to keep minimum wage jobs or a car poor. Maybe what is commonly called redneck or "white trash". How I am not that way and support my wife at age 23 is a whole other story for a different time. I have a strong mountain man streak still of course ü§†

To make things more complicated I'm a black sheep because I'm probably the only person in the family who is not suffering a severe metal health diagnosis. My brother is schizophrenic, sister and mom severe bi polar, grand parents live in their car due to schizophrenia causing unlivable disillusions. We live in rural Appalachia. More things like drugs and lack of opportunity are at play with them too.

My family rely on me in a way that most people would feel inappropriate, but to me I just can't tell. Maybe the trauma bonding from years of growing up like that, maybe guilt. I give all of them rides to and from their jobs. I know this sound untenable because I don't even live in the same town as them but the guilt of knowing I can, and if I don't they'll have no money and nothing else as a result kills me. This means I wake up early, and go to bed late, I also have to squeeze in 8 hours of work in there too. 

The toilet broke at their house a few months back. I showed them a how-to video and the ordered them the part. I learned that months later it was still broken. I fixed it in 5 minutes after going there. Family holidays happen wherever I live. And I cook them. I recently saw the movie Hillbilly Eligy and cried buckets. I was thinking "man, I lived this, I LIVE this now". My wife had never seen me in such a state, the fact that she didn't see what I saw (how could she of course not her fault) made he feel so alone. It's hard when you can't lean on family for anything, and no one else understands. The pressure of providing for them, and providing for my wife at such a young age is a lot. 

People say "cut them off". Those words hurt me. Most people just can't relate to what it feels like. Imagining holding your mom or dads hand on a cliff side and someone says "let go, it's hurting your arm". It's feels so normal to me in some ways. Maybe you gathered this already but I never had a real childhood. I have been an adult so long as I have had needs you could say. 

Now that I'm married my wife may be the most patient person on this earth. I have no idea how she handles having a husband practically married to his family, she meant my mother the car I got for her to use when hers broke down. This was in the days when I thought my family might be able to get or maintain a car. Eventually it ran out of gas and I went and picked up the gasless car, full of trash and ciggeretes butts from the highway. but I know this is too much for my wife despite her support. She needs space, she needs to see me, she needs a husband. I just don't know how to handle it all.

I'm not the type to really post, it write about my problems. I'm a blue collar man who is used to just swallowing things. Carrying everything as best I can. I find it hard to communicate it to my wife. I can tell she wants me to, but I'm afraid she'll loose confidence in me. 

**td;lr 

My(M 23) family (parents, siblings) rely on me a great deal. They struggle with poverty, drugs and mental health. It puts strain on my relationship with my wife(21 F) of 1 year. Guilt pulls me in every direction trying to navigate this.
reply:
Hi there! The situation you're describing sounds incredibly tough and you clearly care deeply about your family. It does, however, seems like you also acknowledge that the toll it's putting on your own life and your relationship with your wife might not be sustainable. 

Perhaps it would help to seek some advice from social services or a counselor ‚Äî someone who might be better informed about different resources for support in your community. Aid with transportation, food security, mental health services - some of these organizations may be equipped to help so the entire burden isn't on your shoulders. It's ok to seek outside support; having a point of contact who understands the system could lead to more sustainable solutions. They might help you find ways to keep supporting your family, but without sacrificing as much of your own life in the process. 

You‚Äôre doing remarkable work, and it‚Äôs clear that your empathy is a big part of who you are. But it‚Äôs also important to take care of yourself. As they often say in airplanes, you have to put your own oxygen mask on first before assisting others. It's ok to seek help and create boundaries between your life and your family's needs. Take care!

post:
Hey everyone. I didn't know where to post this, or if I'm asking for advice or venting. That is to say, any kind of response is welcome, both advice and general statements, I don't mind. 

So I'm (M 23) probably the black sheep of the family. Not exactly how you might expect though. I'm in good shape, have a decent job, a house, I recently got married, get along great with my wife(F 21).

I grew up to a family who were and are, extremely poor. Most people don't really believe or fully understand what it means when a person who grew up poor says that. It feels like such an understatement. To be clear, poor as in "I'm shocked CPS didn't take me away" poor, no food sometimes and parents struggling to keep minimum wage jobs or a car poor. Maybe what is commonly called redneck or "white trash". How I am not that way and support my wife at age 23 is a whole other story for a different time. I have a strong mountain man streak still of course ü§†

To make things more complicated I'm a black sheep because I'm probably the only person in the family who is not suffering a severe metal health diagnosis. My brother is schizophrenic, sister and mom severe bi polar, grand parents live in their car due to schizophrenia causing unlivable disillusions. We live in rural Appalachia. More things like drugs and lack of opportunity are at play with them too.

My family rely on me in a way that most people would feel inappropriate, but to me I just can't tell. Maybe the trauma bonding from years of growing up like that, maybe guilt. I give all of them rides to and from their jobs. I know this sound untenable because I don't even live in the same town as them but the guilt of knowing I can, and if I don't they'll have no money and nothing else as a result kills me. This means I wake up early, and go to bed late, I also have to squeeze in 8 hours of work in there too. 

The toilet broke at their house a few months back. I showed them a how-to video and the ordered them the part. I learned that months later it was still broken. I fixed it in 5 minutes after going there. Family holidays happen wherever I live. And I cook them. I recently saw the movie Hillbilly Eligy and cried buckets. I was thinking "man, I lived this, I LIVE this now". My wife had never seen me in such a state, the fact that she didn't see what I saw (how could she of course not her fault) made he feel so alone. It's hard when you can't lean on family for anything, and no one else understands. The pressure of providing for them, and providing for my wife at such a young age is a lot. 

People say "cut them off". Those words hurt me. Most people just can't relate to what it feels like. Imagining holding your mom or dads hand on a cliff side and someone says "let go, it's hurting your arm". It's feels so normal to me in some ways. Maybe you gathered this already but I never had a real childhood. I have been an adult so long as I have had needs you could say. 

Now that I'm married my wife may be the most patient person on this earth. I have no idea how she handles having a husband practically married to his family, she meant my mother the car I got for her to use when hers broke down. This was in the days when I thought my family might be able to get or maintain a car. Eventually it ran out of gas and I went and picked up the gasless car, full of trash and ciggeretes butts from the highway. but I know this is too much for my wife despite her support. She needs space, she needs to see me, she needs a husband. I just don't know how to handle it all.

I'm not the type to really post, it write about my problems. I'm a blue collar man who is used to just swallowing things. Carrying everything as best I can. I find it hard to communicate it to my wife. I can tell she wants me to, but I'm afraid she'll loose confidence in me. 

**td;lr 

My(M 23) family (parents, siblings) rely on me a great deal. They struggle with poverty, drugs and mental health. It puts strain on my relationship with my wife(21 F) of 1 year. Guilt pulls me in every direction trying to navigate this.
reply:
Hey there, 

It's clear you're going through a tough time and your struggle is enormous. It sounds like you feel a great deal of responsibility towards your family and it puts tremendous pressure on you. And it's also clear that you value your relationship with your wife and recognize that this family dynamic is taxing on your relationship. 

The communal feeling and compassion you demonstrate towards your family is commendable, but it's also important for you to ensure your own well-being. Setting boundaries isn't about leaving your loved ones in a lurch but about establishing a system that is sustainable for everyone involved. Have you considered involving local support groups, charities, or social services that assist with mental health, transportation, and job support in your area? There may be untapped resources that could help lighten your load while still ensuring that your family gets the assistance they need.

Moreover, it seems like you've had to grow up quickly and take on responsibilities far beyond your age. As a result, it feels like you've had to suppress your emotions. Communication is the key to a healthy relationship, and being vulnerable with your wife isn't a sign of weakness. Expressing your feelings, fears, and hopes might actually lead to deeper intimacy and understanding between you two.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and it's okay to ensure your well-being while caring for others. You have handled so much with strength and grace; don't undermine your achievements.

To take care of others, you need to first take care of yourself.  And sometimes, the best way to help others is to help them help themselves.

**td;dr Reach out to local resources for support, consider setting some boundaries, and open up communication about your struggles with your wife. Your well-being matters just as much as theirs does.

reply:
I appreciate your posting and it‚Äôs clear that you carry a heavy burden, which is taking a toll on you. It's admirable how much you care for your family and your desire to better their situations, but it's also important to remember that you can't pour from an empty cup. Your own health and well-being are important too.

First, I recommend you consider seeking professional help from a caregiver or social worker who can assist in providing resources and managing the mental health conditions of your family. You‚Äôve shown to be very resourceful achieving what you have, use these skills to locate services. This can help lessen your load whilst ensuring your family is taken care of in the proper manner.

Secondly, your concern for your wife is understandable. Have a sit-down discussion with her and openly express your worries and ask for her opinions and solutions. True partnerships are about working together through any circumstance.

Finally, remember to take care of yourself. You‚Äôre doing so much for others, but neglecting your own needs can lead to burnout. Carve out time for self-care, even if it is a few minutes a day ‚Äì it's necessary, not a luxury.

Remember, change takes time and patience. It's a journey, not a race. Every step, however small, is progress. Take the time you need and don't lose hope.

reply:
Hey there, it sounds like you're shouldering an intense amount of responsibility and it's clear you care deeply for your family despite the immense challenges they and you face. First of all, you should be incredibly proud of the effort you've put in to help your family and build a stable life for yourself.

However, it's clear that this situation is putting a lot of strain on your own mental health and personal relationships, which is completely understandable. It can be incredibly draining, both physically and emotionally, to continuously provide for others when you're also needing support and care too. 

Perhaps consider seeking professional guidance in order to navigate this situation. Therapists or counselors can often provide tools and techniques for managing these feelings of guilt and might be able to help you establish some healthier boundaries with your family that also respects your commitment to them.

As for your relationship with your wife, open communication can go a long way. It sounds like she is supportive and understanding, which is a great base to start with. Be honest about what you're feeling and how the situation affects you. Conversations like these aren't signs of weakness and won't cause her to lose confidence in you. Rather, they show strength and maturity in recognizing your own needs and emotions.

Additionally, seeking local resources for your family might ease their dependency on you. This could include vocational rehabilitation centers, food banks, mental health clinics, and better housing opportunities.

Remember the importance of self-care also. You're clearly a giving person, but you also must take care of yourself in order to assist others fully. It's similar to what flight attendants always say during their pre-flight speeches - put on your own oxygen mask before helping others.

It's a tough situation, but please don't forget that it's okay to prioritize your own needs too. You're strong for carrying this burden for so long, but you deserve support as well. Hang in there, and remember there are resources and people out there who are ready and willing to assist.

My(M 23) family (parents, siblings) rely on me a great deal. They struggle with poverty, drugs and mental health. It puts strain on my relationship with my wife(21 F) of 1 year. Guilt pulls me in every direction trying to navigate this.
reply:
Hey there,

First off, you need to give yourself some credit. You've been carrying a weight that few people could bear. You're showing strength and resilience that's admirable. 

However, it's crucial to find a balance between being supportive and leaving some breathing space for yourself. Remember, it's okay to have limits because everyone does. You're not failing anyone by setting boundaries. On the contrary, you're helping your well-being which will let you be a better version of yourself for them.

You've been taking on so much responsibility at such a young age, and it's important to remember that being "the responsible one" doesn't necessarily mean solving everyone's problems. You can help by connecting your family members to resources where they can get help. Non-profits, government agencies, mental health professionals, and even faith communities can offer different forms of support, whether that's in the form of food aid, mental health assistance, job training, you name it. 

Regarding your relationship with your wife, it's important to express yourself clearly. Let her in on your feelings, your struggles. It can strengthen the connection between you two. She loves you, believe in that. There's strength in vulnerability.

It would be highly beneficial for you to find someone to talk to about your feelings, whether it's a counselor, psychologist, or a support group for those in similar situations. You certainly have a lot on your plate, and it would be helpful to speak to someone who's trained to help with these kinds of issues. It may also be beneficial for you to explore self-care strategies, like meditation or exercise. Remember, taking care of yourself isn't being selfish, it's necessary.

You're young and have a lot of life ahead of you. Make sure you're living it for you. It's okay to be there for your family but don't forget to live for yourself, too. You deserve happiness, peace, and fulfillment just like everyone else.

post:
We are together for 2 years and it is a great relationship, we communicate openly about everything, can navigate any fight and I feel overall really good in this relationship. 

I moved to study in his city in Germany (I am from Russia) and we met there. He is finishing medicine degree and wants to find a job in his home city. He has his whole life here, family friends and he does not want to move even to another city in Germany, which I underatand and accept.

I however have lived in 3 countries already and I have a huge curiosity for exploring cultures, languages and just learning about the life abroad. For now I wanna stay in Germany but I do not feel that happy in the city of my boyfriend, it is quite a concervative state, there are not many young people, I feel quite lonely and there is no art scene (I am an illustrator). I am not unhappy here but I wanna try something new. So I want to move to another city in a different state. 

But I know if I move to another city we will break up, we talked about it does not make sense to keep things going if I am not going to settle down in his town. And my concern is, should I really give up my relationship that is very good for something that I am not even sure I will like (living in another city)? 
Maybe I will just never be happy in a place I live long term?

P.s.We also talked about perfect lifestyle that we imagine for us:
His perfect picture is: we will eventually move in together, we will work 9 to 5, spend evenings with friends, sometimes do hikes on the weekend, do holiday couple of times a year, get kids etc
My perfect picture is: we live in a couple of different countries for several years together, explore it, work flexible hours, get a place as a base somewhere, we do campings or travel in a van for some time, even with kids eventually 

And it seemed so drastically different, I dont know if it is just me romanticizing travel, this whole situation makes me feel like I am the weird one who is ready to trade good relationship for novelty and excitement of a new place... 

Tl;dr I want to move around and my boyfriend wants to stay in his hometown forever, should I stay with him in his hometown?
reply: Hey there! Both your dreams about the future are equally valid and you're not weird for wanting to pursue your passion for exploring. Remember, it's essential to find a balance in any relationship. Failure in finding the same may indeed lead to dissatisfaction down the line. And since you're unsure about giving up your relationship for a potential new city, maybe try traveling for a bit to the city of your choice while still maintaining your relationship? This might help you make a better decision without losing your relationship abruptly. Communication and compromise are the keys! Don't rush, take your time to figure things out! üíïüåçüóùÔ∏è
