Tl;dr I want to move around and my boyfriend wants to stay in his hometown forever, should I stay with him in his hometown?
reply:
It sounds like you're having a really tough time with this decision, and it's completely understandable. It's never easy when reconciling our desire for adventure with maintaining the stability of a cherished relationship.

It's really crucial to remember that both of your desires are valid. Neither of you is inherently "right" or "wrong" in what they want from life, and it's important not to devalue your own desire to see the world out of guilt or a perception that it's somehow less worthy. Nobody's desires in life should be viewed through a lens of being weird; we're all wired differently.

One potential route to take here might be to try a temporary long-distance arrangement. Would your boyfriend be open to this? A few months apart might give you an idea as to whether you truly miss each other and can't live without each other, or whether maybe, a more independent lifestyle would suit each of you better. 

The most crucial thing is open and honest communication. Make sure he fully understands your desires and concerns, and listen to his as well.  
Remember, it's your life as well, and it's important that you're able to pursue your interests and desires without feeling guilt. Balancing relationship considerations with personal dreams can be tough, but navigating these difficult conversations now can prevent a lot of potential heartache in the future. 

Keep exploring this and really take time to understand what you want from life. It's okay to prioritize yourself sometimes, and remember, your happiness matters.

reply:
It sounds like you're in quite a challenging situation and it's understandable that you feel conflicted about this, as both your relationship and your desire to experience new places and cultures are important to you. 

It seems key to your dilemma is balancing personal fulfillment and happiness with the potential loss of a meaningful relationship. It's a tough spot to be in and there's no right or wrong answer, as it greatly depends on your individual values and priorities.

Relationships often require compromise, but it‚Äôs also essential not to suppress key aspects of your own identity or sacrifice your happiness for the sake of a relationship. From what you've described, it appears living in a vibrant city and having the freedom to explore new cultures holds significant value for you, perhaps even contributing to your happiness and mental well-being. 

However, the final decision hinges on your evaluation of the relationship and whether it fulfills you enough to compromise on your desired lifestyle or if your yearning to explore different cities and cultures is too strong. 

You might also consider exploring long-distance if you both are open to it. It could be a temporary measure while you both figure out where your hearts truly lie. Remember, it's okay to prioritize yourself and your well-being.

Lastly, seeking professional help from a counselor or a psychologist might help you navigate this difficult decision-making process with additional insight. They can provide you with a safe space to express your feelings, explore your priorities, and develop strategies to communicate your needs to your partner.

post:
We are together for 2 years and it is a great relationship, we communicate openly about everything, can navigate any fight and I feel overall really good in this relationship. 

I moved to study in his city in Germany (I am from Russia) and we met there. He is finishing medicine degree and wants to find a job in his home city. He has his whole life here, family friends and he does not want to move even to another city in Germany, which I underatand and accept.

I however have lived in 3 countries already and I have a huge curiosity for exploring cultures, languages and just learning about the life abroad. For now I wanna stay in Germany but I do not feel that happy in the city of my boyfriend, it is quite a concervative state, there are not many young people, I feel quite lonely and there is no art scene (I am an illustrator). I am not unhappy here but I wanna try something new. So I want to move to another city in a different state. 

But I know if I move to another city we will break up, we talked about it does not make sense to keep things going if I am not going to settle down in his town. And my concern is, should I really give up my relationship that is very good for something that I am not even sure I will like (living in another city)? 
Maybe I will just never be happy in a place I live long term?

P.s.We also talked about perfect lifestyle that we imagine for us:
His perfect picture is: we will eventually move in together, we will work 9 to 5, spend evenings with friends, sometimes do hikes on the weekend, do holiday couple of times a year, get kids etc
My perfect picture is: we live in a couple of different countries for several years together, explore it, work flexible hours, get a place as a base somewhere, we do campings or travel in a van for some time, even with kids eventually 

And it seemed so drastically different, I dont know if it is just me romanticizing travel, this whole situation makes me feel like I am the weird one who is ready to trade good relationship for novelty and excitement of a new place... 

Tl;dr I want to move around and my boyfriend wants to stay in his hometown forever, should I stay with him in his hometown?
reply:
Hello,

This sounds like a complex situation that's causing you a fair amount of stress. Firstly, remember there's no 'right' or 'wrong' decision here, only what feels right for you.

A key component of any relationship is compromise. Both of your future visions are valid, but they do differ significantly. It might help to have an open and honest talk about this dilemma, discussing each other's desires and compromises that could meet half-way. For example, could there be prospects of shorter trips for you to explore, and for longer stays in the hometown for him? 

You mentioned that you're unsure whether you'll enjoy living in a different city. It's often difficult to gauge how much we'll like something until we try it. Perhaps you could take a short trip to the city you're interested in or maybe even spend a few weeks there to see how it feels. 

It's also important to remember that one person might not fulfill our every need and want, and that‚Äôs okay. For the wanting of exploration and novelty, you might find fulfilling these needs through friends, family or solo journeys can also be rewarding. 

Lastly, it's crucial to remember that it's completely okay to prioritize your happiness and interests. Every individual has different aspirations and you are not "weird" for seeking novelty and excitement. It's merely a characteristic of you and may ultimately contribute to your well-being. 

I hope this is helpful. Whatever decision you make, ensure it's one that makes you happy and that you're comfortable with. The key is to choose what aligns with your values and desires in life. You've got this.

Tl;dr I want to move around and my boyfriend wants to stay in his hometown forever, should I stay with him in his hometown?
reply:
Hello, 

Your situation is indeed a challenging one, but remember - it's all part of growing and learning. You're in your 20s, and it's completely normal at this stage in life to be unsure, and even feel a little overwhelmed, about what future holds. You're also a woman of a different cultural and racial background (Russian) in a foreign country (Germany), which may add an extra layer of complexities to your experiences.

From what you've shared, it seems like you genuinely love your boyfriend, enjoy a good relationship with him, and yet, you feel a powerful longing for exploration and cultural immersion that he doesn't share. It's important to remember that this doesn't make either of you wrong, each person has their own path to follow, and what might bring happiness and satisfaction to one person may not necessarily provide the same for another. 

Perhaps, you could consider having an open and honest conversation with your boyfriend about how you feel. Frame it not as a demand or ultimatum, but as a personal need you're trying to address. Make sure to emphasize that your desire for exploration isn't a reflection on your relationship with him, but more about your own personal journey and growth. It's also important to consider his feelings and thoughts on the matter.

For your personal concerns, maybe seek advice from a mentor, advisor, or a professional in your field. They can provide you with a different perspective, and a clearer view of long-term implications regarding your career and personal development.

Always remember that it's okay to prioritize your needs, mental health and overall well-being first. There's no perfect solution to your situation, but by taking these steps, hopefully you'll be able to find the balance and happiness you're seeking. It's your journey and you must do what feels right for you.
  
Stay Strong! You got this! ü§ó

post:
I (23f) think I'm going to finally break up with my bf (32m). We live together. I also  have terrible rsd so this is going to be extremely painful, and my first ever break up where I'm consciously not going to jump straight into another relationship afterwards in order to stop myself from feeling heartbroken. I'm trying to be a better person...

Anyways, I live with him in Scotland, but my whole family and support system is in Ireland. I moved out of Ireland because I could never really see myself living here permanently, but I do of course miss my family and friends. I went to uni in Scotland and just ended up staying afterwards. My dilemma is whether to stay in Scotland after the break up or go back to Ireland.

 I recently got a nice job offer in Scotland, starting next month, for at least 3 years. I still don't know what I want to do on my life, and this job seemed like a good starting block to figuring it out. So if we break up, do I stay there, find a room to rent for a good bit of money (yay Edinburgh) and start my new job in September?

On the other hand, I could move back in with my parents in Ireland. I could get a job in a pharma company here without an issue, as it's a huge sector here and I have a relevant course completed. By moving back, I could save a good amount of money but I will also feel like I took a step back in my life, instead of forward, if that makes sense? My parents have no problem with me moving back here - in fact, they always wanted me to come back to Ireland after uni. 

If anyone has any great words of wisdom, I would be forever grateful.

TL;DR Gonna break up with my bf, not sure whether I should stay in Scotland or move back to Ireland where my family is.
reply:
Hey, tough decisions ahead but remember this is your journey. Each path has its own merits. On one hand, taking the job in Scotland is a new experience that comes with independence and growth opportunities. You'd face new challenges and experiences which might be good for personal growth.

On the other hand, going back to Ireland gives you stability and a strong support system during this potentially heartbreaking time. It's okay to rely on your support system when you need it, and it doesn't mean you're going backwards, just taking a different path.

Might help to envision how you see your life panning out in each scenario. Listen to your gut feeling as well. No path is inherently better than the other, it's all about what you value at this point in your life. Sending you good vibes! üåªüí´

I also  have terrible rsd so this is going to be extremely painful, and my first ever break up where I'm consciously not going to jump straight into another relationship afterwards in order to stop myself from feeling heartbroken. I'm trying to be a better person...

Anyways, I live with him in Scotland, but my whole family and support system is in Ireland. I moved out of Ireland because I could never really see myself living here permanently, but I do of course miss my family and friends. I went to uni in Scotland and just ended up staying afterwards. My dilemma is whether to stay in Scotland after the break up or go back to Ireland.

 I recently got a nice job offer in Scotland, starting next month, for at least 3 years. I still don't know what I want to do on my life, and this job seemed like a good starting block to figuring it out. So if we break up, do I stay there, find a room to rent for a good bit of money (yay Edinburgh) and start my new job in September?

On the other hand, I could move back in with my parents in Ireland. I could get a job in a pharma company here without an issue, as it's a huge sector here and I have a relevant course completed. By moving back, I could save a good amount of money but I will also feel like I took a step back in my life, instead of forward, if that makes sense? My parents have no problem with me moving back here - in fact, they always wanted me to come back to Ireland after uni. 

If anyone has any great words of wisdom, I would be forever grateful.

TL;DR Gonna break up with my bf, not sure whether I should stay in Scotland or move back to Ireland where my family is.
reply:
It sounds like you're facing a major crossroads decision, and it's completely understandable that you feel a bit lost. It's great that you have opportunities in both places, and both come with their own unique pros and cons.

Postponing your decision might seem appealing, but it could also prolong your stress. So it's better to think through your options and make a clear-headed choice. Breakups can be incredibly tough, especially when RSD is a factor. Remember to prioritize your mental health during this time and work to surround yourself with support, whether it's friends, family, or a therapist. 

Staying in Scotland means establishing independence and launching your career at your new job. It might be harder initially, especially if you're feeling lonely or heartbroken. Renting a room and navigating a new professional environment are big challenges but ones you may feel ready to take on.

Moving back to Ireland, on the other hand, provides you the comfort of family and friends along with quick job stability. But you'll also have to contend with feeling like you're stepping backward. If you opt for this, it could be a short-term choice, a time to heal and rebuild until you're ready to move forward again.

Perhaps you could try listing out the pros and cons of each option, or speaking with someone who you trust and who knows you well. Regardless, it's important to keep in mind that the decisions we make are not always permanent. If you try one path and it doesn't seem right, you always have the power to reassess and change direction.

Above all, remember change is bending, not breaking. It can be a new opportunity and not a setback. All the best.

reply:
Your situation sounds complex and emotionally challenging, but it's clear that you're reaching out and taking steps to look after your wellbeing, which illustrates great strength.

You've noted that you struggle with Rejection Sensitive Dysphoria (RSD), which can indeed make break-ups emotionally more intense, and it's important that you get the support you need during this time. It can be helpful to work with a healthcare provider or mental health professional who understands your condition and can provide appropriate coping strategies.

In terms of your decision, it's crucial to weigh both your emotional needs and your professional aspirations. On one hand, having a support system in Ireland during this challenging time could help with your mental health, but on the other hand, there‚Äôs this new opportunity in Scotland that you‚Äôre excited about. 

This decision comes down to what you believe would help you heal and grow best at this time - pursuing a promising job opportunity or being closer to a familiar and supportive network. Both are valid choices, and only you can make that call. However, remember that choosing one option does not close off the other entirely. 

You might also consider consulting with a professional career coach or a personal therapist to help you work through these challenging decisions. Regardless, remember, it's okay to take time to heal and discover what truly serves your life path best. Make sure to prioritize your mental health and self-care during this challenging moment. Good luck with your choices.

reply:
Firstly, kudos to you for choosing your own well-being over the comforts of reliability. Breakups can be intense, especially when you're cohabitating, so it's important to remember to practice self-care during this period of change.

You're faced with two options, both of which have their own set of benefits and drawbacks. The decision belongs to you, and both have potential to contribute positively to your life journey. It comes down to what you prioritize more at this stage in your life and what you think would be more beneficial for your emotional and mental well-being.

Staying in Scotland would allow you to explore a new job opportunity, potentially propelling your career forward. It will also give you the chance to establish an independent life. However, be mindful of the fact that you may feel more alone without your family and support system around.

Moving back to Ireland provides the comfort of being close to those who care about you, helping you through this break up. It's good for your mental health to have people close who can help you process your feelings, and remember, taking a step back can often prepare us for a bigger leap forward.

A compromise could be to take up the job offer in Scotland and try it out. If it doesn't work for you, you always have the option to go back to Ireland knowing you made an attempt to move forward.

Remember, there are no wrong decisions here. It's about making the choice that is right for you from where you stand now. Good luck with whatever you choose!

Firstly, I acknowledge your courage for deciding to end a relationship that is not serving you and wanting to focus on your wellbeing. Remember, it's normal to feel a gamut of emotions during this challenging time, especially given your RSD. But ultimately, you have to prioritize your mental health and happiness. 

When it comes to your question, it seems like you've taken a balanced approach in weighing up your options. Both paths have their merits. Staying in Scotland could be advantageous for your career and would help you establish further independence. However, returning to Ireland would mean an established support network in the form of your family and a job opportunity too. 

There's no right or wrong answer, just what feels right for you. You might consider speaking directly to your loved ones, as they know you better than anyone and can provide personalised advice. Remember that moving back to Ireland shouldn‚Äôt be seen as a step back. Sometimes, taking a proverbial step back gives us the room we need to take two steps forward. Look at it as an opportunity to reset and reprioritize and not as a defeat.

Whatever decision you make, seeing a professional mental health counsellor can help you navigate through this stressful period. It can also be beneficial to join a local support group, finding people who are dealing with similar issues can offer another level of understanding.

Lastly, congratulations on the job offer, and I wish you all the best during this challenging time. I'm confident that you'll make the right decision for yourself.

post:
What do I do?

apologies bit of a long one, finally telling my story, I will do a tldr at end :)

Male 22 Irish, 68kg , 5' 8

I had a good upbringing, always got treated well by parents except the odd disciplinary issues whenever I acted out, no trauma etc. I work out regularly, I am on decent shape, I would get attention from girls, I would always be in the top achievers in school (went to a grammar school, not sure what US equivalent is) good social life etc (no external stressors) so I am unsure why I am still so unhappy. My main problem is either depression or depersonalisation . First dealt with depersonalization although I didn't know what it was at the time at around the 14, happened on a handful occassions, most notably after physical exertion (dpdr then became chronic at 16) Had my first dealing with a deep depression around 15 years old due to a bad breakup with a girl I felt I loved at the time. I started dabbling with weed and mdma to help numb the pain, I smoked weed for around a year and took mdma for about 3 months and then after one random night I took a hit of a joint I got sent into full fledged dpdr, this has led me to be depressed (cause or symptom of dpdr im not sure in my case). The first few months of this was horrible, I was forced to go to school and I felt like I was going to faint every 5 minutes due to the overwhelming dissociation. In hindsight looking back I am glad I forced myself to continue on with life, the dpdr eventually , well I wouldn't say gotten better, but it faded enough into the background where it wasn't the only thing I had my attention on, atleast after the first 6 months anyway, I had a general feeling of low mood from then on but continued to carry on with life. Was referred to Mental health team and got counselling  (cbt). Tried to teaching me grounding tips for panic attaics when dpdr came on even when I kept reiterating that it was a constant state, not a transient one. Then came 18 where I had hit another low with dpdr, this made me housebound and extremely suicidal. I was prescribed citalopram / celexa and at the time I didn't feel like it workd but looking back it brought me back out of the house within a certain distance ( the dpdr / anxiety made me never leave the house), say maybe 10 mile from my house, a huge improvement on not being able to move 10 metres from my house. At this age I have left school, but the citalopram managed to give me enough courage to start a full time job in which I held for 6 months, at this period, life has become normal. I am working, I am socialising, I am drinking at the weekends (typical "fitting in" 18 year old starter pack). I'm still suffering from dpdr at this rate btw. 6 months into the job I have another breakdown. Looking back they feel like burnouts where I just couldn't cope anymore with trying to be normal when inside I felt horrible all the time. I went back to the doctor and he suggested that maybe the citalopram has pooped out and we should start a new SSRI in the form of Fluoxteine, much the same story of citalopram with much more weight gain, was able to go back to education and finish off a college diploma at 19-21 years old, again, still very much in dpdr, depression stilll there but not suicidal per se. At 21 I had enough of the weight gain and decided to come off anti depressants and raw dog the pain, I was feeling shit anyway on them and severely overweight ( went from 11 to 15 stone) , might aswell feel shit and look good atleast lol. Managed to lose 5 stone but still again depressed, anxious and still in dpdr. Fast forward to 22, this is where things took a new hell, I tried to sertraline, worst decision of my life. I sent me to a level of dpdr I have never been before, so deep that I thought I was dead and a literal ghost. I had to stop sertraline as any longer on it I think I genuinely would have ended it all. Anyway 7 months on, still depressed lol. Not sure what to do

Things I've discovered recently that could contribute ; 

‚Ä¢ B12 and Folate defeciency, my b12 levels were horrible and folate was even worse, been put on folic acid and b12 injections and cofactors, 2 weeks in no improvement thus far
 ‚Ä¢ VitD defeciency, taking 5000iu vit d3 with 100mcg k2, just started yesterday so no input on that

Things I have tried;

‚Ä¢Exercise , distracts me for a bit but not a cure
‚Ä¢CBT, meh
‚Ä¢Socialising, similar to exercise
‚Ä¢SSRi's , unhappy and fat lol




tldr no trauma, ocassional teenage drug use, chronic dpdr, depressed for no reason
reply:
Hey there! I'm really sorry to hear you're struggling. It's great that you're reaching out and trying to analyze potential causes, though. The deficiencies you've mentioned might indeed contribute to your feelings, so continue with the supplements but keep in mind it can take time to feel any difference. It's also worth raising this with your doctor again to see if anything else needs adjusting. 

Have you considered mindfulness, meditation, or yoga along with your other exercises? They could help with grounding and managing DPDR. 

Engaging in hobbies or activities you've enjoyed in the past can also sometimes help _ a bit like the 'fake it till you make it' mentality; you might find joy seeping back in over time. 

It's important to remember that it's okay to not be okay all the time. You're doing your best and that's all anyone can ask for. Stay strong, ask for help when you need it, and continue to reach out. And if you ever feel suicidal, please seek immediate professional help. Wishing you all the best, mate!

 ‚Ä¢ VitD defeciency, taking 5000iu vit d3 with 100mcg k2, just started yesterday so no input on that

reply:
It really sounds like you've been dealing with a lot, and it's incredibly brave of you to share all of this. While I'm not a medical professional, I can share some suggestions that might help.

Firstly, it might help to continue to explore potential physical causes, like the vitamin deficiencies you mentioned. Sometimes, it can take more than a few weeks to really see changes in mood from this type of treatment. Keep in contact with your doctor about this and continue to discuss any other possibilities.

A surprising amount of research suggests gut-health plays a huge part in psychological wellbeing. A diet rich in gut-friendly foods (i.e. fermented foods, whole grains, lean proteins etc.) might assist in improving your mood. It's worth a try.

Psychiatry has come a long way. Perhaps you could look into psychological therapies beyond SSRIs. Ketamine infusions, transcranial magnetic stimulation, or ECT may provide relief where other treatments have failed. Conduct a thorough consultation with a mental health professional about these.

Additionally, consider approaches like mindfulness or meditation if you haven't yet. There's a lot of research suggesting these can help manage a variety of symptoms, including those of dpdr. 

And remember, it's totally okay to reach out to a professional when your mood is low - you don't need a "good reason" to feel the way you do. Please remember to take care of your physical health as well. Regular sleep, a healthy diet, and appropriate physical activity can directly impact your mood and help tackle your symptoms. And remember - it's okay to seek help.

post:
What do I do?

apologies bit of a long one, finally telling my story, I will do a tldr at end :)

Male 22 Irish, 68kg , 5' 8

I had a good upbringing, always got treated well by parents except the odd disciplinary issues whenever I acted out, no trauma etc. I work out regularly, I am on decent shape, I would get attention from girls, I would always be in the top achievers in school (went to a grammar school, not sure what US equivalent is) good social life etc (no external stressors) so I am unsure why I am still so unhappy. My main problem is either depression or depersonalisation . First dealt with depersonalization although I didn't know what it was at the time at around the 14, happened on a handful occassions, most notably after physical exertion (dpdr then became chronic at 16) Had my first dealing with a deep depression around 15 years old due to a bad breakup with a girl I felt I loved at the time. I started dabbling with weed and mdma to help numb the pain, I smoked weed for around a year and took mdma for about 3 months and then after one random night I took a hit of a joint I got sent into full fledged dpdr, this has led me to be depressed (cause or symptom of dpdr im not sure in my case). The first few months of this was horrible, I was forced to go to school and I felt like I was going to faint every 5 minutes due to the overwhelming dissociation. In hindsight looking back I am glad I forced myself to continue on with life, the dpdr eventually , well I wouldn't say gotten better, but it faded enough into the background where it wasn't the only thing I had my attention on, atleast after the first 6 months anyway, I had a general feeling of low mood from then on but continued to carry on with life. Was referred to Mental health team and got counselling  (cbt). Tried to teaching me grounding tips for panic attaics when dpdr came on even when I kept reiterating that it was a constant state, not a transient one. Then came 18 where I had hit another low with dpdr, this made me housebound and extremely suicidal. I was prescribed citalopram / celexa and at the time I didn't feel like it workd but looking back it brought me back out of the house within a certain distance ( the dpdr / anxiety made me never leave the house), say maybe 10 mile from my house, a huge improvement on not being able to move 10 metres from my house. At this age I have left school, but the citalopram managed to give me enough courage to start a full time job in which I held for 6 months, at this period, life has become normal. I am working, I am socialising, I am drinking at the weekends (typical "fitting in" 18 year old starter pack). I'm still suffering from dpdr at this rate btw. 6 months into the job I have another breakdown. Looking back they feel like burnouts where I just couldn't cope anymore with trying to be normal when inside I felt horrible all the time. I went back to the doctor and he suggested that maybe the citalopram has pooped out and we should start a new SSRI in the form of Fluoxteine, much the same story of citalopram with much more weight gain, was able to go back to education and finish off a college diploma at 19-21 years old, again, still very much in dpdr, depression stilll there but not suicidal per se. At 21 I had enough of the weight gain and decided to come off anti depressants and raw dog the pain, I was feeling shit anyway on them and severely overweight ( went from 11 to 15 stone) , might aswell feel shit and look good atleast lol. Managed to lose 5 stone but still again depressed, anxious and still in dpdr. Fast forward to 22, this is where things took a new hell, I tried to sertraline, worst decision of my life. I sent me to a level of dpdr I have never been before, so deep that I thought I was dead and a literal ghost. I had to stop sertraline as any longer on it I think I genuinely would have ended it all. Anyway 7 months on, still depressed lol. Not sure what to do

Things I've discovered recently that could contribute ; 

‚Ä¢ B12 and Folate defeciency, my b12 levels were horrible and folate was even worse, been put on folic acid and b12 injections and cofactors, 2 weeks in no improvement thus far
 ‚Ä¢ VitD defeciency, taking 5000iu vit d3 with 100mcg k2, just started yesterday so no input on that

Things I have tried;

‚Ä¢Exercise , distracts me for a bit but not a cure
‚Ä¢CBT, meh
‚Ä¢Socialising, similar to exercise
‚Ä¢SSRi's , unhappy and fat lol




tldr no trauma, ocassional teenage drug use, chronic dpdr, depressed for no reason
reply:
It seems like you've been through an incredible journey and have shown great self-awareness throughout. Dealing with depression, depersonalization, and anxiety for that long and in such a variety is very challenging. I applaud your efforts to seek help and try various strategies such as medication, therapy, and lifestyle changes. Despite the ups and downs, you've persisted in seeking a way forward. 

Everybody's experience and response to mental health struggles are unique, so it may take a while to find what works best for you. I would suggest looking into different kinds of therapy, such as dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) or acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT), as they have different focuses and methods than CBT.

Have you ever looked into mindfulness exercises? They can be a helpful tool in managing your feelings of depersonalization. For depression, it is often encouraged to engage in activities that previously brought you happiness even if they no longer do, known as behavioral activation.

Regarding your diet, you're on the right track in addressing deficiencies, though it may take more time and consistent use before a noticeable effect. Continuing to exercise and maintaining a healthy diet can be beneficial both physically and mentally, though I understand these are not magic solutions. 

Lastly, remember it can be very beneficial to have a strong support network, whether it's friends, family, or online communities like this. You don't have to go through this alone. 

Please note these suggestions are not a substitute for professional advice but are recommendations you could consider discussing with your healthcare provider. Always prioritize care from a professional mental health clinician.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about the tough time you've been going through. It's brave of you to share about your experiences here so openly.

The feelings you've expressed are quite common in individuals experiencing persistent Depersonalization-Derealization Disorder (DPDR) and depression. You're not alone, and it's really important that you continue to reach out and express these feelings to others.

Firstly, I hope you're able to get professional guidance managing your B12, Folate, and VitD deficiencies. This could potentially be influencing your mental state, so it's worth keeping up with the treatment.

Moving on, I'd suggest revisiting the basis of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). It's not an instant fix and takes time, so don't discount it if you didn't see immediate improvements. The aim of CBT is to help you understand your thoughts and behaviors, and ultimately develop coping mechanisms to deal with experiences like DPDR and depression.

Exercise and socializing may not feel like they're curing the issue, but they can really help with managing depressive symptoms. It's about the long-term benefits - both physically and psychologically. Keep up with these, they're beneficial even if they don't seem so in the immediate moment.

Lastly, when it comes to anti-depressants, it's crucial to consult with a healthcare professional. Everyone responds to medication differently, you've to work with your doctor to find the right medication and dosage for you.

Always remember reaching out for help is the greatest step you could ever make. Don't give up. You're stronger than you realize.

First off, I want to acknowledge how difficult it must have been for you to write this out and to commend your bravery for sharing your story. The feeling of disconnection and anxiety can be overwhelming at times, and it's understandably affecting your overall mood and wellness.

Depersonalisation and depression seem to be very present for you, so my primary recommendation would be continued professional help. If your current mental health team isn't providing the support you need, consider seeking out a psychiatrist or therapist specialized in depersonalisation and depression. They are more likely to have experience with your specific issues and can provide better guidance and treatment options. 

Regarding your medication, it's not unusual for certain treatments to become less effective over time, or for new medications to magnify symptoms. Always consult with your providing physician about these shortcomings and potential alternatives. 

Despite the mixed feelings towards SSRIs, one thing that seems to have worked for you is maintaining a routine and getting out of the house. You experienced a marked improvement in mood and overall quality of life when you were working and staying active. This is a very common and important aspect of managing mental health issues.

You're on the right track with exercise, vitamin supplements, and maintaining your social life, but remember, these aren't cures but tools to help manage symptoms. They're most effective when used in conjunction with professional mental health treatment.

In closing, do know that progress may not always be linear, but every step you take on your journey to better mental wellness is important. It's okay to feel down sometimes, even unsure about what's next, because it's part of the process. Don't rush, take it day by day, and always give yourself credit for your strengths and accomplishments.

post: Hi all, asking for advice. I live in south side Chicago, which means we have an alley system and an alley porch system unknown to folks who aren‚Äôt Chicago. About a month ago, some new folks moved into a unit next to my condo. Our alley noise now, basically, is the man (I assume gender) is constantly abusive at vocal registers to the lady (I assume gender). When they most recently started up, I went on my porch to vape to try to disrupt it, if they saw me, which they did. "The white boy is seeing you," she said. Went quiet quick. I‚Äôm an anti-racist no-cops person, and don‚Äôt need advice from people who ask me to call cops, which I won‚Äôt. What‚Äôs a good way to get info for help to someone in this situation?
reply: Hey! Fellow Chicagoan here. Your situation sounds really tough. You mentioned that you don't want to call the police, which is a decision I respect. Maybe, you could discreetly slide a note under their door with numbers for local resources like domestic abuse hotlines, women's shelters, and counseling services. The important thing is that the lady knows that there are safe places out there where she can seek help. These organizations are equipped to deal with this more than an individual, no matter how well-meaning they are. Remember to take care of yourself in the process too. This must be stressful.

reply:
Hey there, it's definitely a tough spot you are in, wanting to help but not overstepping. It's admirable that you want to do something.

Instead of intervening directly between the individuals which might escalate things, you could try a subtler approach. Leave some literature or resources about abuse at their doorstep when you know they are not around. Try to not make it appear targeted so as to not incite anger from the perpetrator. You could potentially leave flyers for an area women's shelter or hotline for abuse victims in every porch in the alley, making it seem more like general distribution and less like someone's trying to interfere or point figures. This may provide the woman with information she can use to seek help on her own terms. 

Additionally, you can also reach out anonymously to local social services or organizations that support domestic abuse victims and provide them with your concerns and observations. They may have other recommendations or strategies that can be employed to ensure the safety of the individuals involved.

Remember, while you are doing your part to help, it's also important to prioritize your own safety in the process. From one Chicagoan to another, be careful out there.

reply:
Hello! It's difficult to be in a position where you are witnessing potential harm and feeling powerless about what steps to take. One approach could be to have a conversation with your neighbors, if you feel safe doing so. Make the interaction casual, simply introduce yourself and open a line of communication. 

You could also look for local community resources focused on domestic abuse or violence, and find a way to subtly share that information with them. Sometimes, dropping off a brochure or flyer with a non-threatening excuse such as 'I'm dropping these off for everyone in the building' might be useful.

Talking to your building's manager or HOA might also be a discreet way to bring some attention to the situation. However, it's crucial that you take precautions to ensure the safety and privacy of the individual who may possibly be in a difficult situation. Meanwhile, continue to maintain a supportive presence as often as you can safely do so. The National Domestic Violence Hotline is also a great resource and can offer advice tailored to your individual situation, they can be reached at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233).

Consider leaving a note for the lady in a spot she'll regularly check, like her front door or mailbox. post:
A week ago Sunday my husband smashed a glass plate and flying  glass hit our son who recently turned 8. DH was having a meltdown because I wanted to visit my cousin who was visiting from Florida a second time in a ten day period, during a 4 day weekend (that was the theme, at least, it's hard to know what actually set him off this time or any other).   The tantrum began when I slept in and within earshot of my son who told me he was "sorry I got yelled at" when things calmed down and I got food made. I knew it wasn't over and 30m later (ik cuz I was recording) he continued it in front of the kid, liberally calling him a retard and me the n and k word (we are white of non Jewish descent, but anyone who opposes him is a kword). After breaking the plate he proceeded to chase me around the house hitting me in the arms, breast, and face while I tried to find a broom (..and not fall, he tried twice). That was it, for me, hed been hitting me since 2019, verbally abusing us both for years, and slapped the kid in late April this year (first time he'd hit the kid). I was done, finally told my family the whole story of the past years and got an emergency protective order and then a 2 week temp order 2 days later. I have the right to stay in the house but I'm at my mom's for safety. 
My son has basically been acting like we're on vacation, he knows his dad's is at his grandpa's house but nothing about how long that will be, and he didn't even ask it like "where's dad" but more like "Is he at our house". He's said he likes being here, he says he wants to stay longer, my mom and aunts are slowly trying to teach him that no one is going to lose their shit at him if he spills something or throws up in the car. Kid hasn't mentioned his father or the abuse directly, other than to tell cps his dad yells at him alot. When I asked cps they unhelpfully said I could either "ease him into it or rip the band-aid off" and I don't know what to do. I intend to get a 2 year no contact order when the temp one expires, I intend to get full custody with supervised visitation and knowing his dad it's not impossible he'll never see him again. What should I tell the kid? He seems pretty accepting and happy go lucky in general and idk what to do.
reply: I'm really sorry to hear about what you're going through. It's okay to keep your son in the loop but it should be done in a tactful and sensitive manner. You know your child's perception and understanding level best, hence you're the best person to decide how much to tell and when. A simple "Dad has to stay elsewhere for now because he was not treating us nicely, and it's important to treat everyone with respect and kindness" might work as a start. I'd also recommend consulting a professional therapist to guide you through this complicated process, someone well-versed in cases of domestic or verbal abuse and that specialises in children mental health, because they can advise you on how to help your son process this. Take care of yourself, nobody deserves to go through any kind of abuse, and remember, you‚Äôre doing an incredible job by seeking a safe and secure environment for yourself and your son.

What should I tell the kid? He seems pretty accepting and happy go lucky in general and idk what to do.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about what you've been going through. It takes a lot of courage to take the step that you have and now it's about helping your son navigate through all of this change. Children often internalize things differently than adults and finding a delicate way to communicate what's going on will be necessary.

Firstly, it's vital to reassure him that he didn't do anything wrong and that this is about his father's behavior, not anything to do with him. It might be helpful to consult with a child psychologist or counselor who can give you expert advice on how to handle this difficult conversation.

Next, remember to only share information he can understand and process according to his age and maturity level. Instead of telling him everything at once, releasing information bit by bit would be less overwhelming for him.

Be truthful, but choose your words with care, comfort him and be there for him to answer his questions, even the most difficult ones. Perhaps something along the lines of "Dad has some issues which he needs to sort out, and because of this, he can't live with us right now. We're staying here where it's safe, and we can be relaxed and happy. You've done nothing wrong, Dad is the one who needs to work things out."

Lastly, seek professional psychological support for both of you.  It can be difficult to navigate the emotional impacts of escaping an abusive situation. A therapist or counselor can provide professional advice and help with the process of healing.

Please remember that this is directional advice and it's helpful to seek professional assistance when dealing with this. Remember, you're not alone, reach out and seek support from local domestic violence programs or services in your community.

post:
A week ago Sunday my husband smashed a glass plate and flying  glass hit our son who recently turned 8. DH was having a meltdown because I wanted to visit my cousin who was visiting from Florida a second time in a ten day period, during a 4 day weekend (that was the theme, at least, it's hard to know what actually set him off this time or any other).   The tantrum began when I slept in and within earshot of my son who told me he was "sorry I got yelled at" when things calmed down and I got food made. I knew it wasn't over and 30m later (ik cuz I was recording) he continued it in front of the kid, liberally calling him a retard and me the n and k word (we are white of non Jewish descent, but anyone who opposes him is a kword). After breaking the plate he proceeded to chase me around the house hitting me in the arms, breast, and face while I tried to find a broom (..and not fall, he tried twice). That was it, for me, hed been hitting me since 2019, verbally abusing us both for years, and slapped the kid in late April this year (first time he'd hit the kid). I was done, finally told my family the whole story of the past years and got an emergency protective order and then a 2 week temp order 2 days later. I have the right to stay in the house but I'm at my mom's for safety. 
My son has basically been acting like we're on vacation, he knows his dad's is at his grandpa's house but nothing about how long that will be, and he didn't even ask it like "where's dad" but more like "Is he at our house". He's said he likes being here, he says he wants to stay longer, my mom and aunts are slowly trying to teach him that no one is going to lose their shit at him if he spills something or throws up in the car. Kid hasn't mentioned his father or the abuse directly, other than to tell cps his dad yells at him alot. When I asked cps they unhelpfully said I could either "ease him into it or rip the band-aid off" and I don't know what to do. I intend to get a 2 year no contact order when the temp one expires, I intend to get full custody with supervised visitation and knowing his dad it's not impossible he'll never see him again. What should I tell the kid? He seems pretty accepting and happy go lucky in general and idk what to do.
reply:
I'm truly sorry to hear about the distressing situation you and your son are going through. It‚Äôs commendable that you've taken steps to ensure both your safety and have reached out for help. The question about how to talk to your child about domestic violence is a delicate one. Every child reacts in different ways, but it could be helpful to use age-appropriate language to explain the situation, making sure to emphasize that what is happening is not his fault and that he is safe now. 

Books, stories or toys can also be a helpful tool to better articulate the situation. Remember, it's okay not to have all the answers immediately. If he asks something you're unsure about, you can say you will find out and tell him later.

You should consider professional therapy, especially for your son, who might benefit from counseling to express his feelings in a safe environment. The therapist can guide him to develop coping mechanisms and address any emotional trauma effectively. Experts are trained to handle such situations sensitively and can provide valuable support to you both.

If possible, consider joining a local support group for victims of domestic violence. Being in the company of people who have endured similar experiences can provide comfort and useful advice.

These steps are just guides, the most important aspect here is to ensure both your son and yourself feel safe and secure. Don't hesitate to reach out to professionals or authorities if you are ever feeling threatened. You've shown great strength and courage already, remember to care for yourself as well while on this journey.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about the situation you and your son are in. It's incredibly brave and strong of you to take such steps to protect yourself and your child. 

As for how to communicate with your son, it's a delicate process. You should tell him the truth about the situation in a child-friendly way. Reassure him that this decision is to keep everyone safe and happy. Remember to focus on his dad's behaviors as inappropriate and not vilify his dad as a person - after all, he is his father. Try to explain that sometimes, adults make mistakes and don't know how to handle their feelings, and it's not the child's fault.

Encourage your son to express his feelings and let him know his feelings are valid, it's okay to miss his father, it's also okay to feel angry or upset about what's happened. If the matter becomes too overwhelming, don't hesitate to seek a child counselor or a therapist, they are trained to handle such delicate issues. 

Finally, make sure you take care of your emotional well-being too because your child needs you to be strong. Reach out to professionals if needed. Remember, you are not alone in this. You are doing what is best for you and your son, and I applaud you for that. Take care.

I intend to get a 2 year no contact order when the temp one expires, I intend to get full custody with supervised visitation and knowing his dad it's not impossible he'll never see him again. What should I tell the kid? He seems pretty accepting and happy go lucky in general and idk what to do.
reply:
I'm really sorry you're going through this, but I applaud your courage to stand up for yourself and your son. It's crucial to tackle such a sensitive subject with your child delicately and honestly, because honesty, even when difficult, can foster trust between you in the long-run. 

You've mentioned your son has been relatively accepting and seemingly unperturbed, which is good. This could be due to his young age and not fully comprehending the complexity of the situation. Yet, it's crucial not to underestimate the extent of his understanding or comprehension of the abuse. Keeping open channels of communication is highly important and it's great that he feels comfortable expressing that he likes being at your mum's, as it shows he feels safe and secure.

While I understand that 'ripping the band-aid off' may seem harsh, a softer, gentler touch might be needed. You might want to consider explaining that his father is having to take time apart to work on some personal issues, emphasizing that it's not his fault and reassure him that you'll always be there for him. Gradually, you can introduce more details as he grows older and has a greater capacity to understand.

By all means, reach out to a counselor or professional who specializes in trauma and family issues. They can guide you on how to navigate this conversation in age-appropriate, gentle yet honest ways. Remember, it's your strength and love that will help your son through this difficult time. You're already showing him by example that he should never tolerate abusive behavior. 

Please stay strong and care for your well-being too; care for the caregiver is often overlooked but very important in these situations. Keep seeking support from the wonderful network of people you have mentioned. Your son and you are not alone in this and there's a brighter future waiting for you.

Another matter, my parents kinda hate me right now (or at least don't really care about me) and I also do I hate myself too (not absolute hate, rather disliking) and I feel mentally trapped right now. Never got the motivation to do stuff and my plans with the uni are off now since I couldn't find any place because I didn't have a guarantor which almost always gets asked for in germany.  
All this kinda made me feel empty and meaningless.

Try to find love and acceptance within yourself, which is a journey in itself, but definitely worth it. Regarding uni, it may seem bleak right now, but there's always other ways to reach your goals. You might try looking for scholarships, grants, or part-time jobs. Lastly, it's completely normal to feel empty sometimes, but you are not alone and there are resources online and offline to help you navigate this. Check out https://www.hotline-erste-hilfe.de/ (a german mental health hotline) to talk about your feelings. You matter. üíô

Regarding your relationship with your parents and your self-esteem, please remember, emotions are often temporary and don't always reflect the entire reality. post:
It's not even their fault either. I finished my gymnasium degree just a few months ago, which is very bad, but finally at 26 I am done. The reason being was that I was struggling a lot with school as a kid, and then I isolated myself for a few years as I was older. The last 2-3 years I have been working so hard to finally complete my gymnasium degree. There were so many days where I just wanted to die, mainly because of how my entire life had turned out. 

Through all the hardships I managed to do it nontheless. It's just gymnasium, so nothing special at all in Sweden. Everyone has done it. I am now preparing for university next year, with the goal of studying computer science. 

Since coming out of isolation for all those years and talking to people again, has been very difficult. I feel like I am at a point where I would borderline feel infantilized talking to an 18 year old, being a 26 year old guy. There are so many life experiences which I lack, that everyone else my age and younger has.

I am constantly on edge when talking to people, because I am so afraid that they will bring up questions about my past that I would never be able to answer because of how ashamed I am over it. 

I feel like crying when I am talking to people and they speak about all their experiences, countries they visited, love, so on and so forth. I have missed out on all of this and I can not convince myself that I deserve any of it, because I don't have anything to offer as a person. 

My main motivation that I used to get through gymnasium was that once I am done, then I will no longer be ashamed. With gymnasium being the bare minimum, it should put me on an equal playing field with everyone else, so that I wont stand out too much. After finally finishing gymnasium I was crying tears of joy. Then those tears turned to sadness because I realized that it wasn't enough and until I am done with my university degree, that I shouldn't try to make friends or maybe even more.

I truly hate the way my life has turned out. I am trying to do the best out of this terrible situation. I will never be able to catch up on all of life experiences which I missed out on. It almost feels like people my age and sometimes even younger, feel way older when I talk to them, because of how pretty much sheltered I was for a large part of my adulthood.
reply:
Firstly, congrats on completing your gymnasium degree! That's a huge accomplishment, especially considering the personal struggles you have overcome. No life journey is ever linear, and everyone progresses at their own pace - there's no set timeline on when to hit milestones. So, you're not "behind" or less worthy.

Meet people with the focus on the present and future, not the past. If you're uncomfortable about discussing your past, redirect the conversation towards current interests or future goals. Most people find that more interesting anyway!

Remember, you do have something to offer - your unique perspective born out of your experiences. You are enough just the way you are. You don't need the approval of others to validate your worth. You've shown resilience, determination and introspection - these are qualities that many respect.

Also, it's never too late to gain experiences or make friends. Start small - local clubs, meetups, conferences relating to your uni course might be a good start. Surround yourself with people who support and uplift you.

Lastly, it's okay to seek professional help if your negative feelings persist. Mental well-being is paramount. Remember it's okay to ask for help. Stay strong, take care, and good luck with your future in computer science! Your journey is just beginning. üí™‚ú®üöÄ

reply:
Hi there,

Firstly, I want to acknowledge that it took a lot of bravery from you to share your feelings. It's clear that you're dealing with a lot of overwhelming emotions and negative self-perceptions. I'd like to tell you that it's never too late to embark on new experiences, and that everyone has their own pace and rhythm in life - yours is just as valid as anyone else's.

Perhaps you're putting too much pressure on being like everyone else or achieving milestones that society sets. It's important to remember that everyone has their own scenario. Some people may have plenty of life experiences at an early age, while others might just be starting to explore the world in their 30s. There's no right or wrong way to live life, and there's no single definition for a perfect life. What's important is that you're happy and contented with your life path.

Regarding your fear of sharing your past or feeling ashamed of it, remember that those experiences have shaped you into the person you've become today. It's alright to feel vulnerable and it's okay to share your feelings with others if you feel comfortable. It might help you feel less alone and find people who can understand your situation.

Lastly, it's advisable to reach out to a mental health professional who specializes in older adults and late-life changes. They can provide you with a secure environment to share your feelings in depth and provide additional coping strategies. If you feel up to it, consider joining a support group where you can hear from others who are going through similar situations. Sometimes, just knowing that you're not alone can make a significant difference. 

Remember, the path of life isn't always straight and smooth, but taking one step at a time, we can overcome the obstacles, no matter how formidable they may seem. Take care!

reply:
First off, congratulations on completing your gymnasium degree--that's a big accomplishment worth celebrating! It's important to remember that everyone has a different path in life and comparing your own journey to others rarely provides a fair or accurate perspective. Regardless of the timeline, you've made progress and you are striving for a brighter future, which is admirable.

Isolation can certainly make it difficult to feel connected to others, particularly if it feels like they've had many life experiences you haven't. But remember, we all have unique experiences and stories. It's not a contest. Your story is yours alone and it also makes you who you are today, and that is special.

You are soon to start university which can offer new opportunities to meet people. Instead of focusing on your perceived lack in life experiences, how about leveraging what you've got? You have an interest in computer science and that's a wonderful place to start. There are many clubs, societies, or events around technology at universities where you can meet people with similar interests. 

Another important point is to work through the shame and embarrassment you feel. You've described some tough circumstances and have understandably struggled, but that doesn't make you less deserving of happiness, connection, or love. The past cannot be changed, but the future can be shaped. Try not to let your past dictate your future. Self-forgiveness and embracing self-compassion are steps towards your well-being.

Consider seeking mental health support. Therapists/counselors/psychologists are trained to help people navigate through feelings of shame and inadequacy. They can also help you cultivate better social skills and provide strategies for building self-esteem. 

Lastly, remember, it's never too late to start living the life you want. Every step forward, no matter how small, is progress. It sounds like you've made a lot of progress in the last few years and that's something to be proud of. Some days will undoubtedly be harder than others, but never forget how far you've come.

post:
It's not even their fault either. I finished my gymnasium degree just a few months ago, which is very bad, but finally at 26 I am done. The reason being was that I was struggling a lot with school as a kid, and then I isolated myself for a few years as I was older. The last 2-3 years I have been working so hard to finally complete my gymnasium degree. There were so many days where I just wanted to die, mainly because of how my entire life had turned out. 

Through all the hardships I managed to do it nontheless. It's just gymnasium, so nothing special at all in Sweden. Everyone has done it. I am now preparing for university next year, with the goal of studying computer science. 

Since coming out of isolation for all those years and talking to people again, has been very difficult. I feel like I am at a point where I would borderline feel infantilized talking to an 18 year old, being a 26 year old guy. There are so many life experiences which I lack, that everyone else my age and younger has.

I am constantly on edge when talking to people, because I am so afraid that they will bring up questions about my past that I would never be able to answer because of how ashamed I am over it. 

I feel like crying when I am talking to people and they speak about all their experiences, countries they visited, love, so on and so forth. I have missed out on all of this and I can not convince myself that I deserve any of it, because I don't have anything to offer as a person. 

My main motivation that I used to get through gymnasium was that once I am done, then I will no longer be ashamed. With gymnasium being the bare minimum, it should put me on an equal playing field with everyone else, so that I wont stand out too much. After finally finishing gymnasium I was crying tears of joy. Then those tears turned to sadness because I realized that it wasn't enough and until I am done with my university degree, that I shouldn't try to make friends or maybe even more.

I truly hate the way my life has turned out. I am trying to do the best out of this terrible situation. I will never be able to catch up on all of life experiences which I missed out on. It almost feels like people my age and sometimes even younger, feel way older when I talk to them, because of how pretty much sheltered I was for a large part of my adulthood.
reply:
Firstly, I'd like to congratulate you on completing your gymnasium degree, especially through such trying times. Completing an academic milestone, regardless of how 'normal' it may seem to your peers, is a big achievement in your personal journey. With regards to your worries of feeling infantilised or lacking life experience, I‚Äôd like to remind you that everyone has a different life journey. There's no "right" amount of experiences you should have had by any certain age. The beauty of human life is in its diversity.

Remember, growth isn't linear or confined to a timeline. It's great that you are working hard and have the end goal of finishing university, but be sure that you aren't restricting yourself from finding joy and building relationships in the present. Suppressing social interactions may only magnify feelings of inadequacy and isolation, which seem to be affecting you significantly.

Remember, your past doesn't define you, it molds you. It's perfectly fine to feel embarrassed, but don't let that shame prevent you from embracing your present and future. When discussing your past, you have the choice of how much to share. You might find it surprising that a lot of people would not judge you, but rather appreciate your resilience and strength.

As a fellow Swede, I would strongly advise seeking professional mental health services. We're lucky to have accessible mental health resources in our country, which can benefit individuals like yourself who are suffering in silence. Seeing a therapist or counselor could potentially be very beneficial in managing these difficult feelings and experiences, and they could potentially guide you towards finding more effective coping mechanisms.

post:
Hi guys, 
I Just feel that I need to tell someone about my doubts. Basically, I am 20, full time employeed in a quite high-earning job (especially considering my age), studying part-time petroleum engineering at the top ranked STEM university in my country, I work out every second day, I keep my diet clean, I never do drugs/smoking/alcohol, I'm 6,6 feet tall and I think that I'm quite mature for my age. The problem is, that I basically don't have "Access" to girls my age. At my job I work only with men, and I study also with only men (let's be honest, petroleum engineering isn't so popular amongst women). I've tried tinder, organised group trips to the mountains, science clubs at my university, even approaching women directly at festivals. None of these methods worked. I've never been in a relationship before, and until I was 19 years old (when I finally went to see a doc and got meds) I struggeled with extreme OCD and social anxiety, so I didn't made any female-friends in the secondary school or earlier in my education (I lived in Norway before secondary school, where, originating from Poland, I got bullied for my ethnicity, and it didn't help me making friends, especially considering my struggle with OCD and social anxiety back them). That's basically it, I try to not think too much about it and rather focus on self-development, however back in my head there is allways this crippling fear that I've missed my shot, and that it is too late for me to ever find a partner that would be attractive and compatible to me. I can especially feel it, when I see couples walking down the streets, or riding in a car together. It's an extremely awful feeling, that stays with me, althought I try to mute it by focusing on my career and gym. However this feeling never quite goes totally away. So, what should I try to do? How should I accept my past? 
Thank you for reading my story guys, I Just really needed to share it with someone.
reply: Hey there! Kudos to you for sharing your situation and feelings honestly. First of all, you're only 20, it's not 'too late' for you to find a partner. Love finds us in unexpected ways and times. Your focus on self-improvement is wonderful! Continue working on yourself and things will fall into place. Remember, it's important to have some social interaction too. How about joining social clubs or volunteer work? To cope with your past, consider therapy or counseling; it can offer comfort, tools, and strategies. Everything takes its own sweet time. Until then, continue the work you're doing on yourself and be open to new experiences. Hang in there! üòäüëç

How should I accept my past?

reply:
Hey there, 

Firstly, thank you for sharing your story here; it takes courage to open up about such personal struggles. One key aspect I hope you realize is that there isn't any universal timeline for finding a partner, we all walk on different paths and experience growth or milestones at our own pace. Your fears and worries are understandable, but they are not reflective of an ultimate truth - you haven't missed any 'shot.' 

Moreover, given your struggles with OCD and social anxiety in the past, it's an achievement that you have managed to accomplish so much academically and professionally. Don't overlook these achievements.

As for meeting compatible partners, it might benefit you to expand your social circle beyond your work and studies, exploring other interests or activities that could introduce you to more diverse groups. Engaging in social activities‚Äîwhether that's recreational sports, volunteering, book clubs, etc‚Äîwhere there is a shared interest go a long way in fostering meaningful connections, and often the most rewarding relationships stem from such connections. 

Accepting your past means recognizing that your experiences have shaped you but do not define you. Therapy can be very helpful, and there are often services specifically for social anxiety. If you're not already engaged in therapy, it might be something for you to consider.

Lastly, don't ignore that "awful feeling", instead use it as motivation to take action towards your desired outcome. Keep reminding yourself that every person's journey is different, and it's alright that you're on a different timeline from others. Reflect on your progress and keep growing at your own pace.

Remember, help is available and you're not alone in this.

reply:
Hi there,

I'm sorry to hear about the struggles you're experiencing with loneliness and worry about your future romantic connections. They're completely valid, and speaking up about them is an important first step. It's evident that you're putting a lot of effort into improving yourself personally, academically and professionally, and those are all amazing achievements you should be proud of.

It's important to remember that everyone's timeline for relationships is different, and it's never too late to build this aspect of your life. You have made significant progress in dealing with your OCD and social anxiety, and that sets the stage for improvement in other areas as well. 

It's good that you have made attempts to meet new people through different channels, it's all part of the journey. Sometimes the quest for companionship can be quite daunting and it might seem easier to just focus on other areas of your life like work or fitness. While it's important to prioritize these areas, don't let that discourage you from seeking connections with others.

Seeking professional guidance about these feelings you're struggling with could be really helpful. A mental health clinician could assist you in understanding and managing these feelings related to your past bullying experience, your initial battles with OCD/social anxiety and your ongoing loneliness.

Let's remember that your value as a person isn't determined by whether or not you're in a romantic relationship. You're a smart, successful, and dedicated person, and those qualities will shine through to the people you meet. Keep focusing on improving yourself, but also allow yourself the opportunity to connect with others and be open to new experiences.

Take care!

I want to reassure you that despite how you're feeling, you have not missed your shot. Your fear and anxiety about this can feel incredibly consuming but it's just that, fear, not a prophecy.

You're a young man, with education, a great job, self-care habits, and many years ahead of you. It's important to understand that everyone goes through life at their own pace, especially when it comes to relationships. It's not a contest or a timeline you must strictly follow. You mentioned struggling with extreme OCD and social anxiety which you've sought help for - kudos to you for seeking out that support. 

Building connections can be a bit more difficult due to your past experiences, and current male-dominated work and education environment. post: Hello, I am an Italian boy. Since I was little, I have experienced one problem after another. As a child I was often in the hospital because I couldn't balance, I would fall, and I was always bumping around. Once I even hit my head against a chimney, fortunately turned off. Besides that, when I was 3 years old my parents separated. I remember little of my life before that, I only have a vague memory of my father yelling at me and another of the whole family sitting together at the table. My two older brothers grew up in a happy family, and I constantly had to choose between being with my mother or my father. Then at school I was always excluded, always the one in the corner by myself, the last one, ostracized. And it's still like that. I'm tired of it all. I'm tired of making fake smiles at home. I'm tired of making fake smiles school and everywhere. The only friend I had hasn't spoken to me in a few years, I'm completely alone. And sad.
reply: Hey there, first off I want to say, you're incredibly strong for opening up about your experiences. I'm here to read between your words and my heart aches for what you've been through. Life can be rough sometimes and it seems like you've been dealt a tough hand. My advice is to express your feelings honestly, whenever and wherever you can. It's okay to feel sad, your emotions are perfectly valid. Perhaps reach out to someone at school or look for online communities with people who may be experiencing similar struggles. Remember, even when you feel alone, there are people who would be ready to listen; all you have to do is reach out. Also, consider professional help if you can, a psychologist or a counselor. They are trained to help in situations like this. And always remember, no storm lasts forever. You are strong, you are capable and you are worthy. Don't give up!

post:
alt account for this one, im 15M and i have black curly/wavy hair, i love having a small curly fringe sit on my forehead. its been getting kind of long and me and my dad and my mom were out, and we went to a turkish barber, (i went to him last time and it was decent) i told him to do it exactly like last time but a bit *LONGER*. Now it looks like i have a big lump of shit on my head, i told him to keep it curly, he brought it all back. There is nothing i can do now since i can only just wait. 

im not exaggerating when i say i have to mentally prepare myself to look in the mirror, ive had a breakdown 3 times already (im not that sensible, its the first time i cried in months)
and i got this yesterday, saturday and i have a match on monday, and im going out with my girlfriend on tuesday. she says it looks good
from snaps, but im afraid shes going to change her mind when she sees it in real life.

to give you an idea of how lobotomised this haircut is: imagine a facebook post of a pakistani kid, on his first day of school, with his uniform on, a forced smile and a forced haircut. I cant stand my face in the reflection of my phone. 
it completely killed my self confidence, im feeling suicidal, depressed and cant be bothered to do anything. and its going to stay like this for another month, even when it marinates its going to look terrible. 

thank you for reading
reply:
Hey there, first off, I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life. 

Regarding your hair, remember this is temporary. Hair grows back, and in a few weeks, you'll probably be able to style it in a way that you're more comfortable with. In the meantime, try experimenting with different hair products or styles, maybe something like wearing a hat or bandana could help you feel more confident? 

Remember, you're more than just your hair. Try not to let a bad haircut ruin your day or your game! Your friends and girlfriend like you for who you are, not just how your hair looks. Stay strong, buddy! ~Checkout r/fierceflow or r/malehairadvice for more hair care tips.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear how much this is affecting you. You're going through a tough time, but it's important to remember that your feelings are valid and you're not alone. Haircuts sometimes don't turn out the way we expect them to and it can be really upsetting, but try to keep in mind that hair does grow back, and there may be ways to temporarily style it or product to use that can make you feel more comfortable in your own skin.

Now, it seems like this is about more than just an unsatisfactory haircut, it sounds like you're struggling with some serious feelings of depression and even suicidal thoughts. It's incredibly brave of you to share your feelings like this, but I strongly suggest you reach out to a mental health professional, counselor, or a trusted adult in your life who can provide you with the support you need. 

You could also look for online resources that are targeted at people your age who are dealing with similar feelings. There are places where you can talk to people who have been where you are and who can offer assistance. You should never hesitate to call the suicide hotline for help as well, they are there for a reason, they are well-trained, and they are ready to help.

Remember, your prowess at a match or your worth in a relationship shouldn't depend on the style of your hair. It‚Äôs about the person you are and your character. You are bigger than a haircut! Don't let it dim your shine. You've got this!
