post:
When the year started my young brother of the age of 8 at the time got diagnosed with some sort of cell dysfunction and he spent around 3 months in and out of the hospital.Considering that we are on a pretty underdeveloped country in EU then the doctor didn't know what to do.We had thought of a plan to go to Turkey to get him well some sort of cute but then he fell into a coma.After around 2 weeks in the coma he passed away.
The two things I regret the most are about how I treated him his whole life and that I didn't visit him nearly enough while he was going on and of the hospital.
reply: I'm so sorry for your loss. Please understand, it's normal to feel guilt and regret when we lose someone we love, but it's important to remember to not blame yourself. A counselor or grief support group may provide the help you need to process these feelings. Talking about it with supportive people can also be beneficial. Remember, it's never too late to honor your brother's memory, perhaps by doing something meaningful in his name. Take care. üíîüôèüèª

post:
When the year started my young brother of the age of 8 at the time got diagnosed with some sort of cell dysfunction and he spent around 3 months in and out of the hospital.Considering that we are on a pretty underdeveloped country in EU then the doctor didn't know what to do.We had thought of a plan to go to Turkey to get him well some sort of cute but then he fell into a coma.After around 2 weeks in the coma he passed away.
The two things I regret the most are about how I treated him his whole life and that I didn't visit him nearly enough while he was going on and of the hospital.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It's clear that you care deeply about your brother and his passing has caused significant anguish for you. It's completely natural to experience feelings of guilt and regret following such a loss, and it's important to remember that the 'what ifs' and 'if onlys' are a normal part of the grieving process. 

Don't blame yourself for how you treated him. Remember that no one is perfect. We all say and do things that we wish we could take back. As for visiting him, remember that illness and hospitalization can be difficult and disruptive for families, especially when they're in environments with limited resources.

I'd strongly recommend seeking out grief counselling if it's available to you in your country. Speak with healthcare providers or local community/religious leaders about resources for grief counselling or support groups. If that's not possible, there are a number of online communities for grief support that can provide a safe, supportive space to share your thoughts and experiences. 

Lastly, it can be really beneficial to remember and celebrate the life your brother lived rather than focusing on the way he died. Write about your memories of him, draw pictures, make a photo album or collage, or find some other kind of creative outlet that can help you to express what you're feeling. 

Please remember, you're not alone in this. Taking steps to heal after a loss can be a lengthy process, but it's very possible. Allow yourself the time to grieve and feel whatever you need to feel.

Please try to remind yourself that you did the best you could given the circumstances you were in, and it's clear that you care deeply about your brother. Consider reaching out to a local grief support group or counselor who can provide you with more personal guidance during this difficult time. You might also find some solace in journaling your thoughts and feelings. Most importantly, please remember that you're not alone, and it's okay to lean on others for help. Your feelings are valid.

The two things I regret the most are about how I treated him his whole life and that I didn't visit him nearly enough while he was going on and of the hospital.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about your loss and the pain you're experiencing right now. Losing someone you love is never easy, especially under such difficult circumstances. Grief, coupled with regret and guilt, can feel incredibly heavy. 

First and foremost, it's really important to understand that your feelings of regret are a natural part of the grieving process. We tend to focus on the what-ifs and if-onlys, but remember that you did the best you could with the knowledge and resources you had at that time. It would be beneficial for you to express your feelings openly, whether that's in a journal, speaking to someone you trust, or seeking professional help, like a bereavement counselor. 

It's also equally important that you give yourself permission to grieve. We all grieve in our own way and in our own time. Don't let anyone tell you how or when to grieve. Bereavement support groups, online or offline, can also provide solace and a sense of understanding that friends or family may not always be able to offer.

Lastly, remember to take care of yourself during this very challenging time. It's easy to forget about our own wellbeing when we're immersed in grief. Eating healthily and incorporating small amounts of physical activity into your daily routine can help. 

There's no 'right' way to cope with loss. The most important thing is to not isolate yourself and reach out when you need to. We're here for you.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. It sounds like a truly heart-wrenching experience and you have my deepest sympathies. It's understandable that you feel regret and guilt, but it's important to remember that both are feelings that people typically process after their loved one's death. It's important to not let these feelings consume you. 

The loss of a sibling is a heartbreaking one and being in a less developed country with fewer resources can make the situation even more challenging. At a tender age of 8 years, your brother had a hard battle to fight. The trauma of his illness, the hardships surrounding it and finally, culminating in his loss, is a major burden for anyone to bear. 

Please remember that you were both young. There is no "right" way to have been a sibling, and it's clear you cared for him due to your regrets. Even in regret, you reveal your love and care for him. It is never easy to see a loved one suffer, and sometimes, we avoid it unconsciously because it's too painful to bear. That doesn't make you any less caring or loving.

This is going to be a tough time for you, so please consider seeking support, whether it's from friends, family, or professional help. There could be resources available online or in-person for grief counselling that might help you during this difficult time. It's okay to mourn, to feel regret, and to feel all the feelings that are overwhelming you right now. Please do what you need to heal, step by step, day by day.

Again, I'm really sorry for your loss. This community is here for you, and do not hesitate to reach out. We're here to listen, and you're not alone in this.

post:
Tl:dr my gf was sent to a mental hospital over nothing and i feel broken.

I (y14,t.f) have a gf (y16,f),2 weeks ago she tryied to commit suicide due to one of her "firends" who made up some things,its a long rabbithole but basicly her neighbour sexually assulted her multiple times and she just found out that her neighbours are her bestie's aunt and uncle,her friend try to take revenge by putting her dad in prison. warning!this is where the story starts to be a bit redecilous but bare with me here,we are in romania,its a corupt and broken country.
To save her dad she tryied to commit suicide by sliceing her wrists,she failed and she wound up in the hospital,she luckly wasent sent to the ward,in romania mental hospitals are pretty below avrage,its more of an open prison so they can feel safe knowing a punk that they dont care about wont die. My gf had to go to counceling and had to take anti-depresents,i told her to not take them and she didnt want to either,her mother is a addict for those pills and she doesnt want to end up like her,i dont want her to change since there is nothing wrong with her. At counceling,yesterday to be exact,she felt uncomftrable with some of the questions and didnt answer them,i am the only person she has full trust in,i help her a lot with her mental health as much as i can,becose she refused to answer she was put in a psych ward,i am devistated,she needs certain things that most people dont, for example shes a really picky eater and she needs to take pills becose she is vegan,i support her on being vegan but its hard to take care of,its a long distance relationship and im really scared,she has no phone,we useually feel eachothers feelings,i feel when shes sad and when she cryies,she does too for me,it feels weird,its almost like youre sad for something that you dont know what it is. Shes alone,scared and misses me,i hope she will get out on good behaviour and a bribe,tommorow il get to talk to her,on of our friends is going to visit her tommorow,he promiced he will call me and hand the phone to ada so i can talk to her. I feel lost,our friendgrup is kinda dead now since everyone is with theyr own plans,my bestfriend randomly stopped texting us for no reason,we did nothing out of the ordinary,i really need someone to take care of me and tell me good night,my best friend used to do that but he stopped texting in the worst moment.
reply:
Hey buddy, this sounds extraordinarily tough for you, and it's clear how much you care for your girlfriend. It's a really challenging situation but here are a few thoughts:

- It might help to get a trusted adult involved, someone who can advocate for her in this corrupt system. It's a lot for you to shoulder alone. 
- Mental health issues are complex and it's important to involve professionals who can guide you. Medication and counseling could be beneficial, although finding the right therapist and medication might take time. 
- You're her boyfriend, not her healthcare provider. There's only so much you can do and remember it's okay to ask for support too. You also need to take care of your own mental health in this situation. Reach out to a counselor or a trusted figure in your life for support.

Take it one day at a time. You're both young, and there's so much ahead. Much love, friend. You're not alone in this. üíú

reply:
Hi there, I'm really sorry to hear about everything you're currently going through. This is a heavy situation to handle and you must be going through a lot emotionally. First, you need to understand that your emotions are justified and it's important to give yourself space to feel and process them.

You mentioned your girlfriend has been put in a psych ward which feels overwhelming to you right now. Please remember, she's there to get professional help and support. You're doing well supporting her as best as you can from a distance, but also know you're not alone in caring for her. The professionals at the psych ward are trained to help in these situations. 

It's really important to take care of your own mental health during this time too, this might feel almost impossible due to your feelings of responsibility. Can you find anyone around you who can provide emotional support? Sometimes, turning to trusted adults like a teacher, counselor, community leader, or even family member, can help if friends aren't available. 

You mentioned your girlfriend doesn't want to go on anti-depressants. That's a personal choice, but remember, sometimes they can be a crucial part of healing and recovery. Encourage honest conversations with her doctors and mental health professionals - they can also outline several other treatment options.

Look into local or online mental health resources, like helplines or support groups. They can offer counselling and advice on the best strategies to help her. 

Make sure your love and support for her is communicated clearly. Write her letters if possible, and send them with the friend that‚Äôs visiting. She might find comfort in having something tangible from you.

Everything seems intense now, but life has a way of evolving. Be patient with the process, and don't forget to take care of yourself too. Sending strength and positive vibes your way. You're stronger than you think.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about the situation that you and your girlfriend are currently facing. It seems like you're under a tremendous amount of distress and I commend your strength for continually being there for her. It's important that you remember to take care of your own mental health as well during these times. Don't be afraid to confide in someone trustworthy about your feelings, and try to find ways to relax and unwind to help manage the stress.

This is indeed a tough situation, but it also sounds like she's receiving professional help, which is critical at this juncture. It worries me a bit that you say there's nothing wrong with her, given that she did attempt self-harm. Depression can be an insidious and deeply affecting disorder, which necessitates professional attention.

While it's perfectly normal for her to feel uncomfortable with therapy at first, encourage her to maintain open communication with her counselors because they are there for her well-being. Keeping things inside can hinder the healing process. It's common to feel apprehensive about starting on anti-depressants, but in some cases they can be life-changing for people with depression. It's ultimately a decision to be discussed with her doctors.

If the current mental health support system in your country is not adequate, you might want to research online resources, helplines, or forums where she can get further help.

Remember, you can't carry this burden alone. She needs a strong supportive network, professional help, and kindness from everyone around her. Please take good care of yourself as well, it's equally important.

In terms of advice, I suggest continuing to be there for your girlfriend as much as you can. During your call, remind her of how much she matters to you and that you are committed to helping her through this difficult time. If she's worried about medication, it might be helpful to suggest she discusses her concerns with her healthcare provider. They can explain the pros and cons, as well as discuss alternatives.

Your girlfriend's wellbeing is crucial, but so is yours. Try to take good care of your own mental health, perhaps by finding someone trustworthy to talk to about your feelings. This could be a friend, family member, or a professional. There are also many online resources and hotlines available, which might be useful.

Self-care is important too. Even basic practices like keeping a regular sleep schedule, eating healthy meals, and doing things you enjoy can make a big difference in managing stress and emotional pain. 

Remember, this is a tough situation for both of you, but it won't last forever. You're showing great strength and resilience in the face of adversity, and those qualities will serve you well as you move forward. Be gentle to yourself and take it one day at a time.

Tl:dr my gf was sent to a mental hospital over nothing and i feel broken.

I (y14,t.f) have a gf (y16,f),2 weeks ago she tryied to commit suicide due to one of her "firends" who made up some things,its a long rabbithole but basicly her neighbour sexually assulted her multiple times and she just found out that her neighbours are her bestie's aunt and uncle,her friend try to take revenge by putting her dad in prison. warning!this is where the story starts to be a bit redecilous but bare with me here,we are in romania,its a corupt and broken country.
To save her dad she tryied to commit suicide by sliceing her wrists,she failed and she wound up in the hospital,she luckly wasent sent to the ward,in romania mental hospitals are pretty below avrage,its more of an open prison so they can feel safe knowing a punk that they dont care about wont die. My gf had to go to counceling and had to take anti-depresents,i told her to not take them and she didnt want to either,her mother is a addict for those pills and she doesnt want to end up like her,i dont want her to change since there is nothing wrong with her. At counceling,yesterday to be exact,she felt uncomftrable with some of the questions and didnt answer them,i am the only person she has full trust in,i help her a lot with her mental health as much as i can,becose she refused to answer she was put in a psych ward,i am devistated,she needs certain things that most people dont, for example shes a really picky eater and she needs to take pills becose she is vegan,i support her on being vegan but its hard to take care of,its a long distance relationship and im really scared,she has no phone,we useually feel eachothers feelings,i feel when shes sad and when she cryies,she does too for me,it feels weird,its almost like youre sad for something that you dont know what it is. Shes alone,scared and misses me,i hope she will get out on good behaviour and a bribe,tommorow il get to talk to her,on of our friends is going to visit her tommorow,he promiced he will call me and hand the phone to ada so i can talk to her. I feel lost,our friendgrup is kinda dead now since everyone is with theyr own plans,my bestfriend randomly stopped texting us for no reason,we did nothing out of the ordinary,i really need someone to take care of me and tell me good night,my best friend used to do that but he stopped texting in the worst moment.
reply:
I'm so sorry to hear about the difficulties you're going through at such a young age (14, t.f). It's indeed a complex situation for your girlfriend (16, f), especially dealing with such traumatic experiences and mental health while still a minor herself. It definitely doesn't help that you're dealing with this amidst the perceived corruption within your country.

Primarily, when you said you help her with her mental health as much as you can, that's incredibly brave and commendable, yet it's important to remember that you are not a professional, and there's a limit to the level of support you can provide. It's entirely okay to not have all the answers.

Simultaneously, it's essential to respect her process and her needs, even though they might not make sense to us. The path of healing and recovery differs for every individual. If she's receiving counseling and prescribed medication, it's generally advised not to contradict professionals' advice, as they have the necessary training to handle such situations. Nevertheless, it's understandable considering the situation in Romania as you mentioned.

Likewise, your feelings of pain and despair are completely valid. In this turmoil, it‚Äôs crucial to remember self-care: reach out and connect with others around you, seek professional help if possible, exercise regularly, and maintain a healthy diet. Even small things like reading, listening to music, or practicing mindfulness can help too.

Remember, it's okay to feel sad, lost, and scared. Amidst everything, take things one day at a time. Please seek help for yourself too if it gets too overwhelming. It's as crucial to look after your mental health as it is to support your girlfriend's. You're not alone in this. Wishing you strength and resilience for the journey ahead.

Why does quietness or social awkwardness make people so uncomfortable? 

I feel like a leper or pariah. 

Everyone eventually ends up disliking me or thinking I‚Äôm weird. 

Even if they are super nice and friendly to begin with. They always pick up on my anxiety and alien behavior. Il

I‚Äôve managed to alienate all my coworkers in a matter of weeks. I don‚Äôt know how one person can be so unlikeable. 

People (especially other girls) get so uncomfortable around me and they think I‚Äôm naive or mentally delayed. People are afraid to swear around me and think I‚Äôm devoutly religious for some reason. 

I also have a British accent and grew up attending sheltered religious private schools. So this likely impacted my social development and made me overly formal, deferential, and reserved.
reply: Hey there! It's tough when you feel like your quiet nature causes discomfort to others, but remember, it's okay to be who you are. People may initially be taken aback by quietness or social awkwardness due to unpredictable reactions or misunderstanding. Change could be positive, though. Try exploring workshops or books on improving social skills, they could help tackle anxiety and undesired habits. Remember, different isn't unlikable and having a British accent or being reserved reflects your upbringing, not your capacity for being liked. Hang in there! üí™üôåüèº #UniqueIsBeautiful

Even if they are super nice and friendly to begin with. They always pick up on my anxiety and alien behavior. Il

I‚Äôve managed to alienate all my coworkers in a matter of weeks. I don‚Äôt know how one person can be so unlikeable. 

People (especially other girls) get so uncomfortable around me and they think I‚Äôm naive or mentally delayed. People are afraid to swear around me and think I‚Äôm devoutly religious for some reason. 

I also have a British accent and grew up attending sheltered religious private schools. So this likely impacted my social development and made me overly formal, deferential, and reserved.
reply:
Hey there, and thank you for being brave enough to share your concerns with us. Social awkwardness or quietness can sometimes make others feel uncomfortable because as human beings, we're hardwired for connection and communication. When we come across someone who acts differently or seems distant, it can throw us off, leading to misunderstandings and unfortunate stereotypes.

However, feel free to remember that people's reactions are often based on their own fears and insecurities, and not always a reflection on your person or disposition. Also, everyone, including you, has a unique character and style of interaction.

Society all too often favors extroversion, even though quieter personalities have their own irreplaceable contributions. The workplace can be demanding for introverts, but keep in mind the strengths you bring by being different. You're likely observant, detail-oriented, and an excellent listener - these traits are invaluable.

Regarding the perception that you are naive or religiously devout, it could be they are attributing their perceptions to your more formal, deferential nature along with the presumed delicacy of private religious schooling. 

Cultural differences might also play a part, as British humor and communication style can sometimes be misunderstood in places where it isn't standard.

People might also be over-correcting in their interactions due to their own perceptions or misunderstandings. It could be worth considering speaking openly with those around you about your feelings and experiences to help them better understand. 

Moreover, it might be beneficial to seek assistance from a professional therapist or counselor. They can provide the tools and strategies to help you understand these challenges and to successfully navigate your interactions with others. Don't be too hard on yourself; you're unique, and that's a strength, not a drawback. You're not alone in this, and your journey towards better understanding and interacting will make you stronger.

reply:
I really empathize with you feeling like an outsider due to your quietness and social awkwardness. We can wrestle with these feelings if our personalities don't fit the common mold. Often, people feel uncomfortable because they're not sure how to interact with someone who is quieter or more reserved, potentially creating misunderstandings or false assumptions. 

Remember, it's completely okay to be introverted, reserved, or socially awkward. These traits should not equate with being disliked. In fact, there are many individuals who appreciate these qualities because they bring a different, valuable perspective. 

However, if your feelings of isolation impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to learn some social skills or strategies to communicate more effectively. For instance, you might find practicing small talk or finding common interests with others helpful. You could also consider seeking support from a mental health professional, who could provide techniques on how to handle social situations.

Lastly, remember there's no such thing as being "unlikeable" as a person. We all have unique quirks and qualities that make us who we are. You're just as deserving of respect and companionship as everyone else, so don't be too hard on yourself.

It doesn't make you any less worthy or likeable as a person.

Hang in there, and remember, it's okay to be different. It is what sets us apart and makes us unique. Everyone has something valuable to bring to the table, including you.

Believe me when I say that you're not alone and many people grapple with such feelings and situations. That said, it's important to recognize that everyone is unique and we all have our strengths and weaknesses.

Social interaction involves certain expectations and norms, and any deviation from them can lead people to feel uncomfortable. Perhaps what you perceive as alien behavior is just your unique way of interacting, which is probably different than what others are accustomed to. People often fear what they don't understand; the unfamiliar can be intimidating.

Lastly, dealing with social anxiety is tough, and it‚Äôs okay to seek professional help to manage these feelings. Discussing it with a therapist or counselor could help you gain perspective and find ways to become more comfortable with yourself and with others.

Just remember, it's okay to be you, in your full, complicated, beautiful uniqueness. The right people will appreciate you for who you are.

Take care.

Today I was coming back to hotel I took an elevator I was alone but then some girl came to elevator too I was scared I didnt looked at her but she started a conversation about do I enjoy my stay at hotel and is it my first time in Austria. I said Yes and thats its very nice here she then asked me where i was from i said I was from poland and stuff she asked about weather. When elevator finally stopped at my floor I thanked her and got off as fast as I can and go to my room.
I felt happy I could actually talk without stutters or weird mumbling im kinda happy even tho this conversation was kinda one sided cause most of things I said was "yes" "no" but im still happy and the elevator ride felt like it was going up forever
reply: That's great! A step forward is still progress no matter how small. Practice makes perfect so any chance you get to engage in conversation, take it. You're doing brilliant and remember, it's okay to be nervous. It's human. Even the smoothest talkers get tongue-tied sometimes. So whenever you get opportunities like this, seize them. You're improving and that's all that matters! Keep it upüëèüî•üëå

post:
As a 16 year old in high school, I do relatively well grades-wise. However, when it comes to socializing, I'm a failure. I don't really talk unless I'm talked to, which is close to never. I get that it's kind of on me that I don't have many friends, but that's aside from the point. Besides, I'm sure my RBF is probably to blame as well.

Due to me being quiet, it seems that everybody around me makes up terrible and untrue things about me. Some that I hear a lot are "school shooter", "kidnapper", and (my personal favorite) "The Riddler from The Batman". I have never really understood why. Isn't being called a school shooter what can cause one? It's not like I would even want to hurt anybody around me.

This has completely demotivated me from making friends at all. I fear that I'll be seen as a creep even if I try to socialize. It's not even that I look bad or something, I just have a bad rep for no reason. If I'm called to talk in class, I always hear the reaction of "he can talk??????". It's as if I'm not even seen as another person by them.

When it comes to the rare few I have talked to, they don't even know my name. They refer to me as "Tyrone", "Lebron", or some other random name. Sometimes I'm just reduced to "white boy". I get that it's all light hearted, but it's pretty damn demeaning. I'd like to speak up about it, but I fear I'll just be shut down instantly with how kids my age are.

There are a few kind people who have taken the time to actually understand who I am. The majority of them are women. However, any time I am speaking with them, somebody always has to say something like "W Rizz" (even though I'm talking to them completely platonically) and it just makes things awkward. It seems like I'm seen as a joke everywhere around school. I wish people around me would understand that I'm a human being with feelings.

At some point last year, we were to do group projects in an English class. The teacher assigned groups based off who was friends with each other, and, seeing as I had no friends in the class, I got paired up with people who had special needs. This wouldn't have been a problem if it weren't for the fact that not only was the entire workload up to me for the quarter, but I was beginning to be seen as special needs myself. I haven't even been diagnosed for any neurodivergence. This only made people make fun of me even more.

As much as I want to get through high school, the people around me make it a living hell. What should I do? I would love to ignore them, but it's pretty hard when it's everywhere I go. I just want to be seen as an actual human being.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about your struggle, it sounds incredibly tough. Remember, it's okay to be reserved and quiet, but if you feel like it's affecting your well-being and happiness, you might find professional help beneficial, such as a counselor or therapist who can provide you with tools to handle these situations. 

Here are a few things to ponder:

1. You may want to consider joining clubs or groups based on your interest, as it could help you meet people with common ground. 

2. Understand not every high school experience is great ‚Äì many mature, thoughtful and understanding people are found outside school life, remember there is a whole world outside of high school. 

3. In regards to bullies, you can try opening up to a trusted teacher or school counselor about your experience. They are there to protect you and can help dismantle bullying. 

But most importantly, believe in the wonderful person you are. You're more than the labels they assign to you.

reply:
Hi there,

I'm really sorry to hear about your difficulties. High school can be a challenging environment and it sounds like you're experiencing the brunt of that. Remember, it's extremely important to continue to reach out in moments like this. Everyone has a natural desire to connect with others, and it's totally normal to want social acceptance. 

First, understand that your worth is not defined by the behavior or opinions of others. Try to develop your self-esteem through positive self-talk and involve yourself in activities that make you feel good about yourself. 

Second, ignoring such people may not always be feasible but learning to disregard their hurtful comments can help lower the negative impact on your mental health. They are simply projecting their insecurities.

Next, consider talking to a trusted adult. This could be a parent, a school counselor, or a teacher. Discussing the situation can provide a helpful outside perspective and they might be able to intervene. It's the job of your school to provide a safe learning environment.

You mentioned that there are a few kind people who take the time to understand you, can you turn them into allies and friends? Healthy socialization is key.

Lastly, consider seeking the help of a mental health professional such as a clinical psychologist or psychotherapist. They can provide strategies to help you cope with your feelings and work on your communication skills in a setting that feels safe. 

You're not alone. You have strength and resilience in you, even if it doesn't feel like it right now. Please remember to take care of yourself. There is life after high school, and it doesn't last forever. You can thrive, and you can overcome these challenges.

Hello, 

It sounds like you're going through a really tough time in high school right now and I'm really sorry to hear this. It's important to remember that many people, especially at your age, often struggle with forming and maintaining social connections. It is admirable that you are so self-aware and reaching out for support.

It's very hurtful and unfair that your peers are making assumptions about you and labeling you in ways that are untrue and all because you tend to be a quieter person. Everyone is unique and the world would be a boring place if we all acted and interacted in the same way. We're all equal no matter how extroverted or introverted we are. Your silence does not define you any more than one attribute defines anyone else.

It's important to recognize the quality of your connections instead of the quantity ‚Äì and it's encouraging to hear that there are some who take the time to understand who you really are. Starting small and focusing your energy on deepening these relationships might be a good starting point.

Is there a school counselor or a trusted adult you can speak with at school about how you're feeling?  They should be able to provide you with some coping techniques and even potentially help foster a more accepting environment.

While it's definitely easier said than done, try to not let others' opinions of you dictate your own self-perception. Continue being you and explore hobbies or interests you enjoy. Joining clubs or activities within your interest range can also provide an opportunity to meet like-minded individuals who will appreciate you for who you are.

This is an incredibly challenging time, but please know that it's temporary. You have an entire future ahead of you beyond high school, and not everyone's high school experience defines their life. It gets better, and most importantly, remember you are not alone. 

Stay focused on your future goals, keep doing your best academically and reach out for support whenever you need it‚Äîwhether it's your family, school staff, or even in an anonymous online space like this one.

post:
As a 16 year old in high school, I do relatively well grades-wise. However, when it comes to socializing, I'm a failure. I don't really talk unless I'm talked to, which is close to never. I get that it's kind of on me that I don't have many friends, but that's aside from the point. Besides, I'm sure my RBF is probably to blame as well.

Due to me being quiet, it seems that everybody around me makes up terrible and untrue things about me. Some that I hear a lot are "school shooter", "kidnapper", and (my personal favorite) "The Riddler from The Batman". I have never really understood why. Isn't being called a school shooter what can cause one? It's not like I would even want to hurt anybody around me.

This has completely demotivated me from making friends at all. I fear that I'll be seen as a creep even if I try to socialize. It's not even that I look bad or something, I just have a bad rep for no reason. If I'm called to talk in class, I always hear the reaction of "he can talk??????". It's as if I'm not even seen as another person by them.

When it comes to the rare few I have talked to, they don't even know my name. They refer to me as "Tyrone", "Lebron", or some other random name. Sometimes I'm just reduced to "white boy". I get that it's all light hearted, but it's pretty damn demeaning. I'd like to speak up about it, but I fear I'll just be shut down instantly with how kids my age are.

There are a few kind people who have taken the time to actually understand who I am. The majority of them are women. However, any time I am speaking with them, somebody always has to say something like "W Rizz" (even though I'm talking to them completely platonically) and it just makes things awkward. It seems like I'm seen as a joke everywhere around school. I wish people around me would understand that I'm a human being with feelings.

At some point last year, we were to do group projects in an English class. The teacher assigned groups based off who was friends with each other, and, seeing as I had no friends in the class, I got paired up with people who had special needs. This wouldn't have been a problem if it weren't for the fact that not only was the entire workload up to me for the quarter, but I was beginning to be seen as special needs myself. I haven't even been diagnosed for any neurodivergence. This only made people make fun of me even more.

As much as I want to get through high school, the people around me make it a living hell. What should I do? I would love to ignore them, but it's pretty hard when it's everywhere I go. I just want to be seen as an actual human being.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. It's hard to feel like you're constantly being judged and misunderstood. It definitely has a significant impact on how you see yourself and how you interact with others. Rest assured that you're far from alone in dealing with feelings of isolation and misunderstanding.

You've mentioned that there's a few kind people who've taken the time to understand you, so that's a good starting point. They can potentially help to bridge the social gap between you and your schoolmates, and even help change your image to others.

As for being called harsh names, people often do this out of ignorance and immaturity. It's not reflective of who you truly are. Remember, the perception others have of you doesn't define you. One strategy might be to talk to a trusted adult like a school counselor or teacher who you feel connected to. They may be able to help you with coping strategies, and possibly address the issue with the wider school community.

At the same time, engaging in extracurricular activities or joining clubs that highlight your interests can introduce you to people who share similar hobbies. This could provide you a "safer" environment to practice socializing and making friends. 

Also, remember that people evolve with time. Who you are in high school isn't the end-all and be-all. Things will change, and you'll have many opportunities to grow and refine your social skills as time goes on. Hang in there, and consider seeking professional help if things start to feel overwhelming. You're not alone, and there are resources to help you navigate this. Trust that things will get better. They usually do with time, patience, and support.

reply:
I'm so sorry to hear that you're going through all of this. It sounds incredibly challenging and I think anyone in your situation would be struggling. High school can be a particularly difficult time, especially when it comes to socializing and fitting in. Firstly, I want to tell you that your feelings are valid and it's okay not to be okay.

You're right, it's not fair or correct that you‚Äôre being labeled or placed in certain stereotypes because you're quieter than your peers. It's important to remember that the labels that others put on us don't get to define who we are.

I think one of the most valuable things you can learn is to divide between what is reflection of them and what's really about you. The behavior of your peers is a reflection on them, not on you, although it certainly affects you. Sometimes people are uncomfortable with difference, or use cruel humor as a coping mechanism.

One thing you can consider is reaching out to a trusted adult in your life, like a parent, teacher, or school counselor about how you're feeling. Sometimes it can be helpful to have an older, more experienced person in our corner who can offer advice or intervene if the situation becomes too extreme.

I'm very glad to hear that you have found a few kindhearted people who have taken the time to get to know you! Sometimes, just a handful of supportive relationships can be even more valuable than being part of a larger social group.

Lastly, remember that although high school can seem all-consuming, it's just a small part of your life. Try to focus on hobbies or interests you have outside of school: this can boost your self-esteem and provide you with more positive social interactions. 

You deserve to be treated with respect and kindness, just like anybody else.

post:
(M30). Have had OCD, anxiety, health anxiety since I was little.

A year ago I was lying in bed to sleep, it was the middle of the night. Suddenly out of nowhere I find it hard to breathe, I get palpitations and a burning sensation in my chest. I get out of bed thinking I'm having a heart attack. I go to the emergency room and after EKG (ECG), tests, blood test and blood pressure measurement, they send me home.

I contact the local health center as after that episode I started to have irregular heartbeats. The doctors take my blood test, urine test, they do an EKG on me, and all values look good. My doctor concludes that it is anxiety and panic, so I see a psychologist. I have trauma from childhood and the year before (2021) my grandmother passed away suddenly, my grandmother who raised me (basically).

I continued to contact the local practitioner as I could wake up in the middle of the night completely out of breath and a racing heart. I am constantly worried about having heart disease, such as a stroke or heart attack, but the doctors say my heart is normal.

I continued to have heart palpitations several days a week, had constant chest pressure and chest pain and finally got a referral to a heart specialist clinic. There they connected me to machines, did an echocardiogram, ultrasound and I had to perform a test where I cycled while connected to machines. According to the results, my heart is normal.

I keep waking up at night with my breath in my throat, the feeling of someone strangling me, pain in my stomach and pressure on my chest and a constant worry and fear of death. I go back to university in 2 weeks, looking forward to that, but really don‚Äôt want this shit to affect my studies and social interactions too much. 

I don‚Äôt know what to do. Really. I‚Äôm on the edge my family members have had it, they don‚Äôt want to hear it and they think I‚Äôm crazy. I‚Äôve always been an anxious kid, I‚Äôm afraid of dying constantly and I think about that a lot, but since I had that one ‚Äúmajor‚Äù panic attack, my life has changed completely and I haven‚Äôt felt well for over a year now. 

I see a therapist, but not that often, once a month maybe (your typical underfunded Scandinavian free health care office). But I‚Äôll have more appointments in the autumn. But i think about trying CBT.

Also, one thing that gets me to relax is meditation, East Asian calming music and Tibetan bowls. I‚Äôm thinking about learning Transcendental Meditation.
reply:
Hey there, sending hugs your way firstüòä It seems like you've had a long hard journey & it's commendable that you're still persevering.

Consider exploring daily meditation apps or mindfulness exercises which could be beneficial for your anxiety- something like Calm, Headspace, or Habitica can help immensely. These logical steps could aid you when you're feeling overwhelmed.

Additionally, researching into cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a great proactive step; it's proven quite beneficial in managing anxiety disorders. An online therapy platform, like BetterHelp or Talkspace, could be an option if face-to-face therapy isn't possible frequently.

Moreover, connections with people who experience similar concerns could help provide solace - try and join OCD or anxiety-focused subreddits or online communities.

Perhaps, you could also incorporate exercise into your routine- physical fitness can help regulate the 'happy chemicals' in our brains, providing a morale boost!

Also, remember, it's okay to not have it all figured out- you're going through enough & it's paramount to remind yourself occasional rest is okay. Remember you're not alone. It's okay to feel this way. We're all here, rooting for you. You‚Äôre not crazy; you're coping in the best way you can, & that's more than okay.üíô

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you've been going through this. It sounds incredibly tough. I'm glad to hear that you've had a comprehensive range of tests and your docs have confirmed your heart is healthy - that's really reassuring. It may be that the symptoms you're experiencing are physical manifestations of anxiety and panic as they initially suggested. 

You mentioned that you're seeing a therapist, which is a great step. You might want to consider seeking therapy more regularly if possible. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) can be really effective for addressing anxiety disorders and it might be something to discuss with your therapist. It might also help to join a support group for people experiencing similar symptoms; sometimes it can be really reassuring to know you're not alone.

The meditation and music you've found helpful are great self-care practices and can be really beneficial. Transcendental Meditation could be another good path - many people find it very calming and a good tool to manage anxiety. 

Try not to let other people's reactions affect your own process. It's unfortunate that your family is not more supportive, but your health and well-being matter. You're definitely not crazy. Keep doing what you're doing and try to focus on one day at a time, one step at a time.

Also, remember that there's no need to face this alone. Reach out to others when you need support - there are plenty of communities like this one that are here for you. You're doing great so far; keep going!

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're dealing with such a difficult situation. It's incredibly challenging when you're experiencing intense anxiety and fear and it starts impacting your health and daily life.

Firstly, it's really positive that you've been proactive and had your physical health checked out. It seems like you've been doing a lot to manage your anxiety, seeing a psychologist and considering options like CBT and Transcendental Meditation - these are all steps in the right direction. 

In terms of therapy, while it's important you continue the appointments you have coming up, you may wish to consider additional support if it feels like it's not enough. Online therapy platforms can be great resources when physical appointments are limited and may provide additional comfort during the moments when you feel trapped in your fears. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a promising idea and the premise of challenging and changing thought patterns can be especially effective with obsessive and health-related anxieties.

Have you considered exposure therapy as part of your CBT? Exposure therapy is a type of CBT technique where you gradually expose yourself to the subject of your fear in controlled and safe ways, to systematically eliminate the anxiety response. This might be something to consider.

Meditation and calming music certainly help create a peaceful surrounding that can reduce anxiety significantly. Transcendental Meditation might be an effective technique for you. Regular practice of such techniques can present a world of difference in managing anxiety effectively.

The bottom line is, don't lose hope. Remind yourself that anxiety cannot harm you no matter how much it makes you believe otherwise. It might not seem like it now, but with the right tools and support you can navigate through this and come out stronger. You are not alone in this journey. While it might seem hard to discuss this with your family, find the right support groups and lean on friends who'll listen.

Please remember: this is NOT medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider.

reply:
Dear Friend, 

I'm so sorry to hear about your ongoing struggles with anxiety and health concerns. But kudos on reaching out for help. You're showing strength and resilience, even in the face of adversity.

Understand that these intense feelings of anxiety and the physical phenomena associated with them can truly be debilitating. Remember, though, as much as it feels like it, these sensations will not cause you harm. Anxiety can manifest itself in a myriad of physical symptoms which can indeed mimic serious health issues. Yet, as demonstrated by your extensive medical tests, there is no underlying physical condition.

This is a significant indication that what you're experiencing are the physical symptoms of anxiety and panic. This may provide some reassurance, despite how real and terrifying these sensations can be. 

Engaging in therapy with greater frequency might be helpful. Approach your healthcare provider about increasing participation. They may be able to refer you to alternative services or give advice on other types of support if they can't increase your own sessions. 

CBT, as you've mentioned, is an excellent technique for managing anxiety, panic, and health anxiety. It would be worth exploring, along with incorporating techniques such as mindfulness, yoga, and Transcendental Meditation into your daily routine. These activities, much like your love for East Asian music and Tibetan bowls, work to elicit the relaxation response, which helps to counteract overwhelming anxiety.

Please take care of yourself, pace yourself at university, and give yourself grace. Anxiety is not something that can be conquered overnight, much as we wish it were so. You are incredibly brave, and don't forget to reach out to professional mental health networks, support groups, or online communities where you can find solidarity and understanding.

Take care and be well,

[Your Name]

post:
24M

Hi all, first of all i‚Äôm NOT asking for a diagnosis. Been to the GP several times. Just searching for some insights and opinions..

So there‚Äôs some things I‚Äôve been struggling with for years. Father died in 2013 of cancer, had very difficult years after in which I didn‚Äôt grieve his death. Also had a very manipulative girlfriend from 2013 tot 2018. Been also having OCD since I were a kid.

When that relationship ended I started to develop a cough and bowel issues. I saw that my stools were thin and weird. Saw my GP for both issues, but she assured me it would be nothing. Health anxiety started to get worse and I started getting panic attacks. Years passed and the symptoms didn‚Äôt go away. Went to my GP so many times to get reassurance about my health..

Last year in april I moved to a new place with my new girlfriend who is my fianc√©e today! Around that time I felt a very hard immovable lump in my neck that freaked me out. Started worrying about cancer and convinced myself I had it. Went to my GP who referred me for an echo, but nothing weird. Could be an extra rib they said in the hospital. Anyhow, that lump freaked me out to the MAX and I developed an one sided headache at that time. It‚Äôs more of like a head pressure around my right temple that sometimes radiates to the neck. It‚Äôs literally always there from waking up to going to sleep. Doesn‚Äôt wake me up tho. Developed (in my imagination) one sided weakness on the left side, which suddenly went away. The cough I had for years disappeared out of nothing but now I‚Äôm left with this one sided head pressure that‚Äôs constantly there for 14 months now. Also since a couple of months occasionally a weird smell. For some hours my smell gets distorted and then out of nothing (usually after sleeping) it resets. Bloods are perfect and did some neuro tests (reflexes, pupils etc) and everything is OK. GP doesn‚Äôt see a need for an MRI because if it were a brain tumor she‚Äôd likely see something in the tests and the symptoms would‚Äôve gotten waayy worse over the course of a year. Also still left with bowel issues. Never a solid stool, always gassy and stools smell bad. Thought I had blood in my stool but my GP said it was undigested foods. Also a constant pressure in my lower left abdomen. Don‚Äôt know what to do now, doc says it‚Äôs all because of high amounts of stress I put my body to.

Is it really possible that I have this one sided constant pressure because of something psychomatic for so long? It didn‚Äôt get worse over time. Also the bowel movements, could this really be stress for so many years? Doc also said bowel cancer usually gives anemia, which i don‚Äôt have. Also have strong depersonalization issues for some years which worsened A LOT the last couple of weeks.. no one notices anything. 

I sometimes think I developed bowel cancer some years ago and last year it metastized to my brain and have it there also since. Is this something realistic or am I not being sober in this? Is my heavy derealization from a tumor or more likely the anxiety and trauma‚Äôs. Last weeks everything feels very fake.

I would think.. if it were something so serious, something would‚Äôve happened by now right? The phantosmia, the head pressure (that sometimes gets really mild almost not noticable), (perceived) weakness and pulsating tingling in left side of the body would‚Äôve developed significantly if it were really something right? This derealization is not cool.. want to feel normal again..

Sorry for my english btw, I‚Äôm dutch.
reply: Hey, it certainly sounds like you've been going through a lot! Your symptoms seem to be greatly distressing you, but remember - we can't replace professional advice. It's promising that your doctor's investigations turned up nothing serious, and stress or anxiety can absolutely cause physical symptoms. It might be helpful to look into seeing a therapist or counselor to help work through these anxieties. In terms of your gastrointestinal issues, have you considered changing up your diet to see if it makes a difference? Things like probiotics or fiber supplements might be useful, but it's always best to get advice from a dietician or your doctor. Don't let your worries consume you, engage in activities that relax and help you manage stress. Wishing you the best, take care!

24M

Hi all, first of all i‚Äôm NOT asking for a diagnosis. Been to the GP several times. Just searching for some insights and opinions..

So there‚Äôs some things I‚Äôve been struggling with for years. Father died in 2013 of cancer, had very difficult years after in which I didn‚Äôt grieve his death. Also had a very manipulative girlfriend from 2013 tot 2018. Been also having OCD since I were a kid.

When that relationship ended I started to develop a cough and bowel issues. I saw that my stools were thin and weird. Saw my GP for both issues, but she assured me it would be nothing. Health anxiety started to get worse and I started getting panic attacks. Years passed and the symptoms didn‚Äôt go away. Went to my GP so many times to get reassurance about my health..

Last year in april I moved to a new place with my new girlfriend who is my fianc√©e today! Around that time I felt a very hard immovable lump in my neck that freaked me out. Started worrying about cancer and convinced myself I had it. Went to my GP who referred me for an echo, but nothing weird. Could be an extra rib they said in the hospital. Anyhow, that lump freaked me out to the MAX and I developed an one sided headache at that time. It‚Äôs more of like a head pressure around my right temple that sometimes radiates to the neck. It‚Äôs literally always there from waking up to going to sleep. Doesn‚Äôt wake me up tho. Developed (in my imagination) one sided weakness on the left side, which suddenly went away. The cough I had for years disappeared out of nothing but now I‚Äôm left with this one sided head pressure that‚Äôs constantly there for 14 months now. Also since a couple of months occasionally a weird smell. For some hours my smell gets distorted and then out of nothing (usually after sleeping) it resets. Bloods are perfect and did some neuro tests (reflexes, pupils etc) and everything is OK. GP doesn‚Äôt see a need for an MRI because if it were a brain tumor she‚Äôd likely see something in the tests and the symptoms would‚Äôve gotten waayy worse over the course of a year. Also still left with bowel issues. Never a solid stool, always gassy and stools smell bad. Thought I had blood in my stool but my GP said it was undigested foods. Also a constant pressure in my lower left abdomen. Don‚Äôt know what to do now, doc says it‚Äôs all because of high amounts of stress I put my body to.

Is it really possible that I have this one sided constant pressure because of something psychomatic for so long? It didn‚Äôt get worse over time. Also the bowel movements, could this really be stress for so many years? Doc also said bowel cancer usually gives anemia, which i don‚Äôt have. Also have strong depersonalization issues for some years which worsened A LOT the last couple of weeks.. no one notices anything. 

I sometimes think I developed bowel cancer some years ago and last year it metastized to my brain and have it there also since. Is this something realistic or am I not being sober in this? Is my heavy derealization from a tumor or more likely the anxiety and trauma‚Äôs. Last weeks everything feels very fake.

I would think.. if it were something so serious, something would‚Äôve happened by now right? The phantosmia, the head pressure (that sometimes gets really mild almost not noticable), (perceived) weakness and pulsating tingling in left side of the body would‚Äôve developed significantly if it were really something right? This derealization is not cool.. want to feel normal again..

Sorry for my english btw, I‚Äôm dutch.
reply:
Hello friend,

It‚Äôs clear you're going through a tough time right now, and it takes immense strength to open up about what you're experiencing. Your concerns are valid and it‚Äôs okay to be worried about your health. 

From what you've described, everything suggests that these are manifestations of stress and anxiety, which are incredibly powerful and can induce physical symptoms. A lot of your symptoms seem to be compatible with anxiety and a high level of stress, such as the headaches, bowel issues, and even distorted smell. Panic attacks or anxiety can often result in what is referred to as somatization, or physical symptoms caused by mental factors. 

Depersonalization can be related to past trauma, in an attempt for your brain to protect you from experiencing intense emotional pain. This feeling of unreality and disconnection can be a hall mark of anxiety and is not necessarily indicative of a physical health problem. Mindfulness and grounding techniques can sometimes help with depersonalization and derealization, and therapy may provide some relief.

It‚Äôs important to trust the experts who have been examining you ‚Äì your GP and the hospital staff. They look out for specific signs or symptoms that would indicate if further investigations are needed. And remember, Google doesn‚Äôt have a medical degree! 

These constant worries and fears about your health might indicate that you are suffering from health anxiety. CBT therapy could potentially be a big help, as it's designed to change thought patterns and behaviours, and has been shown to be successful in managing health anxiety.

Remember, it's okay to reassure yourself that you have been thoroughly checked by medical professionals and to remind yourself that your symptoms may be a result of worry and anxiety, rather than a physical illness. 

Make sure to pay continual attention to self-care and relaxation techniques to manage your anxiety. This might include mindfulness, regular exercise, healthy eating and a prioritising a good sleeping routine.

You're not alone in your struggles. This community understands and supports you. It could be beneficial to seek professional psychological help for your anxiety and stress. There is no shame in seeking help. 

Stay strong, and take care of yourself.

reply:
Hi there, 

I am very sorry to hear about the physical and emotional pain you have been feeling as that can be incredibly hard to bear. It really sounds like you're dealing with quite a lot at the moment, both physically and mentally. 

Though I am not a mental health clinician in real life, your post reminded me of the importance of integrated care, which is a coordinated approach that brings together physical and mental wellbeing. I would encourage talking about your concerns and experiences in detail with your doctor once more, or another healthcare institution if that seems more comfortable for you. Perhaps they can consider referring you to a specialist or therapist who understands both your physical and psychological health. 

There are mental health professionals who specialize in health anxiety and other related concerns such as OCD, stress, grief, and trauma. They can provide cognitive-behavioral therapy, which helps you understand how your thoughts influence your bodily sensations, among other things. This kind of therapy aims to help you incorporate coping strategies to reduce anxiety and stress, which may also help alleviate your physical symptoms.

I would also recommend reaching out to a local support group, who may offer you comfort, understanding, and advice during these difficult times, and maybe even some useful tips to address your symptoms.

Wishing you all the best. You are not alone in this, and you're doing well by reaching out and seeking help.

reply:
Hi there, 

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such difficult times. While I can't provide the medical reassurances you may be looking for, I hope I can offer some advice from the perspective of mental health, where mind and body are frequently interlinked.

Firstly, bear in mind that anxiety can manifest in many ways, including physical symptoms, at times exactly what we fear the most, such as serious diseases. Second, it's also important to note that mental health issues like depersonalization and derealization can also be intensified by stress, anxiety and past traumas. 

You mentioned the death of your father and a manipulative relationship which you've not fully grieved or processed - this could be contributing a great deal to your current mental and physical health. It may be beneficial to seek therapy or counselling to help process these events. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy or Mindfulness-based Cognitive Therapy could be particularly beneficial for you - they teach techniques to manage anxiety and panic attacks and also to deal with OCD symptoms.

Regarding your physical health, if you're still feeling unwell and are not satisfied with your GP's help, it might be worth seeking a second opinion from another healthcare professional. With that being said, it's crucial to remember that Internet opinions cannot replace the professional advice of healthcare providers.

Many people here are coping with similar stress and health anxiety, so please know that you're not alone. Remember, it's okay to ask for help - consider reaching out to professional therapists, psychologists and social workers. There are hotlines available too, if things ever get too overwhelming for you. 

Lastly, maintaining your physical health, like eating balanced meals, engaging in regular exercise, and ensuring you get good quality sleep, can have a significant positive impact on your mental health as well. 

Please seek the help you need, you don't have to go through this alone.

Losing a parent is an extremely testing experience and your past relationship seems to have taken a toll on you as well. The symptoms you've mentioned certainly sound challenging and it's understandable that they produce anxiety.

First, it's important to remember that while symptoms can be discomforting, they aren't always indicative of severe sickness. Also, the mind and body are inextricably linked. Mental stress can manifest as physical symptoms. This seems to be the case here according to your GP - who has conducted thorough health checks to ensure you're physically well.

Regarding your worries about cancer, once again, it's crucial to trust your doctor's expertise. A far more likely scenario than bowel-brain metastasis is that your experiences have been heavily influenced by your past traumas and unprocessed grief. Manifestations of psychological distress can easily disguise themselves as physical disease.

With your derealization situation, remember that it's often a reaction to intense stress or trauma, and is a common symptom of various anxiety disorders. This, along with all other symptoms you've described, should eventually alleviate with appropriate mental healthcare. 

Consider seeking a mental health professional or a counselor who could help you navigate through this challenging time. Therapy could assist you to not just cope with the symptoms, but also to process unresolved grief and past traumatic experiences. Remember: There's always help available, and seeking it is an important step towards healing. 

Lastly, it's excellent that you've found a fianc√©e who could be a support system for you. Stay hopeful, reach out to supportive networks, and focus on self-care.

Take care, and remember, you're not alone in this.

reply:
Hi there, 

You're doing commendable work and I admire your dedication towards making valuable treatment accessible to those who truly need it.
  
You might find it helpful to start by identifying and making a list of key veteran associations and hyperbaric centers within the US. Searching online should provide you with a preliminary list. Once identified, you could reach out to them via their official website; many organizations have a ‚ÄòContact Us‚Äô section where you can share your proposal comprehensively. 

You might also consider reaching out to them through professional social networking platforms like LinkedIn where many of these organizations have active profiles or, if available, directly emailing the appropriate point of contact. 

Attending conferences, webinars, or seminars related to PTSD treatment could additionally offer networking opportunities likely to be beneficial for your cause.

Remember, your approach should convey the benefits and proven effectiveness of your program, sharing any testimonials or success stories you have would potentially increase their interest.

Hope this helps and best of luck with your noble endeavor!

post: Hi, I am a physician leading a highly effective hyperbaric oxygen therapy program for PTSD, currently supported by the Israeli MOD for treatment-resistant veterans. I seek to make this treatment available to US veterans who may need it. How can I contact veteran associations and hyperbaric centers to explore knowledge sharing?
reply:
Hello,

It's great that you are looking to expand your support to include US veterans. Here are some steps you could take:

1. Identify Relevant Organizations - Look for established veteran organizations in the U.S., such as the American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars, Disabled American Veterans, etc. 

2. Outreach Approach - Once you've identified these organizations, you can usually find a 'Contact Us' section on their websites. You may send them an email or letter introducing your program and offering to share your knowledge and techniques. Be clear about how it will benefit the veterans they serve.

3. Connect with medical institutions: Similarly, reach out to various hyperbaric centers across the U.S. Explain what your program offers and how collaboration could enhance PTSD treatment outcomes.

4. Networking: Attend conferences or events catering to PTSD treatment. This could help you network and make direct connections with relevant associations and healthcare professionals.

5. Publications/Seminars- Another approach would be to publish your work or conduct seminars to draw their attention towards your endeavor. 

I hope this helps. Your efforts are truly commendable! All the best with your outreach!

post: Hi, I am a physician leading a highly effective hyperbaric oxygen therapy program for PTSD, currently supported by the Israeli MOD for treatment-resistant veterans. I seek to make this treatment available to US veterans who may need it. How can I contact veteran associations and hyperbaric centers to explore knowledge sharing?
reply:
Hello there,

That's a noble mission you're undertaking. You should know that reaching out to these organizations directly is often a good starting point. Begin by drafting a formal letter of intent outlining what you want to achieve. 

For veteran associations, consider getting in touch with groups like The American Legion, Disabled American Veterans (DAV), or Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW). They usually have contact information available on their websites. For hyperbaric centers, you might want to reach out to the Undersea and Hyperbaric Medical Society or directly to individual centers across the US.

Social media platforms, like LinkedIn and Twitter, could also be a significant avenue to establish initial contact. Sometimes, direct messages can lead to more formal communication.

Furthermore, consider visiting conferences, seminars or workshops where you can network with key stakeholders personally.

Finally, it might be helpful to engage with a consultant with experience in medical partnerships or someone familiar with the US healthcare system.

Good luck on your endeavor! You're doing an incredible job.

post:
Hello.

Normally i don't write depressing shit about myself but i just can't take it anymore seriously.                     
 I have always been a happy person and had lot of well (Friends) i thought but it all went downhill...

First of all im 18 years old with a child, How you ask? my girl lied about using contraceptives and decided to keep the child and afterwards cheated on me. I love the child to death but thinking he grows up with parents seperated so early and seeing him not much breaks my heart in pieces. I keep trying to hold all that weight and keep going forward to do the best for my child but then i realised my friends hated me and used me for my car and money. So all the childhood friends with good memories just didn't give a f about me. I tried to tell my parents but they didn't take me seriously and just said i need to be a man and be there for my child, All easy said when you've been dealing with depression almost all your life and when you finally build yourself up in position that you're happy... you get shot with multiple arrows at once and fall all the way back down, when this time you have no one to help you. I also lost my job recently due a miscommunication and im in a big financial problem now. I feel like no girls like me or even find me attractive when im literally behaving as myself and still take care of myself.

All my life it's been a journey of dragging myself up and get shot down every... single... time...              
 Say what you want about me that it's partly my fault, because yes it is. But making mistakes is a part of life but honestly i just can't bear the weight anymore.

The message is long but i just need to express myself somewhere.

Sorry if the message is written poorly it's because im Dutch

Thank you for the people that care to read this lol.

​

​
reply:
Hey there,

Your message really hits home. First, don't apologize for your feelings. Instead, embrace what you're going through‚Äîit makes you human. 

Secondly, regarding your child: you already are an amazing father. Remember, being present doesn't always mean being physically there. With time, your child will understand the love you have for him. 

Coming to friends, it's sad to realize late that some of them were only there in good times. But this is an opportunity to find genuine ones. 

Your parents may not fully understand the situation, but being a 'man' doesn't mean neglecting mental health. It's ok to ask for help. 

As for girls and jobs, these can change quicker than we think. You‚Äôve got a whole life ahead of you, mate. 

Keep expressing yourself, wherever you find peace doing so. We are here, listening.

Take care, hold your head high, and keep moving forward. One step at a time.

Sending good vibes your way.‚úåÔ∏èüôÇ

reply:
Hello there, 

Firstly, I just want to say it's incredibly brave of you to open up and share what you're going through. It's clear that you're dealing with a lot of tough situations right now and you deserve lots of support. 

Firstly, it's perfectly okay to grieve over your relationship and the loss of your close group of friends. It's also perfectly okay to worry about your child's future. As a parent, you want to give your child the best life possible, and it is understandably heartbreaking to have early challenges. However, please remember that the love and dedication you have for your child matters above all else. Children thrive in an environment where they feel loved, and it is evident that you love your child dearly.

Secondly, it is okay to feel deceived by your friends. Real friends are meant to back you up, not use you. The fact that you feel used shows that you know your self-worth. You deserve friends who respect and cherish you just as much as you respect and cherish them.

Thirdly, feeling misunderstood and judged by your parents can be immensely tough. It's important to remember that their perspectives might be influenced by a different generation, so their understanding of your situation might be different from yours. 

You are not alone in this journey. There are places you can reach out for support and counselling, like local community organizations and mental health clinics. Speaking with therapists and psychiatrists can provide you with some helpful strategies to manage your feelings. 

Please remember that it's perfectly okay to feel overwhelmed and fall down; we all do. The key is to keep getting up. Life presents us with countless opportunities for a fresh start. I believe in your strength to rise above these problems, because admitting the struggle is the first and biggest step towards healing.

I hope this message encourages you, even just a bit. We're all here for you, and we're cheering you on.

Take care of yourself.

Hello.

Normally i don't write depressing shit about myself but i just can't take it anymore seriously.                     
 I have always been a happy person and had lot of well (Friends) i thought but it all went downhill...

First of all im 18 years old with a child, How you ask? my girl lied about using contraceptives and decided to keep the child and afterwards cheated on me. I love the child to death but thinking he grows up with parents seperated so early and seeing him not much breaks my heart in pieces. I keep trying to hold all that weight and keep going forward to do the best for my child but then i realised my friends hated me and used me for my car and money. So all the childhood friends with good memories just didn't give a f about me. I tried to tell my parents but they didn't take me seriously and just said i need to be a man and be there for my child, All easy said when you've been dealing with depression almost all your life and when you finally build yourself up in position that you're happy... you get shot with multiple arrows at once and fall all the way back down, when this time you have no one to help you. I also lost my job recently due a miscommunication and im in a big financial problem now. I feel like no girls like me or even find me attractive when im literally behaving as myself and still take care of myself.

All my life it's been a journey of dragging myself up and get shot down every... single... time...              
 Say what you want about me that it's partly my fault, because yes it is. But making mistakes is a part of life but honestly i just can't bear the weight anymore.

The message is long but i just need to express myself somewhere.

Sorry if the message is written poorly it's because im Dutch

Thank you for the people that care to read this lol.

​

​
reply:
Firstly, I want to commend your strength for sharing your struggle on here; it's a brave act that many people are too scared to embrace. I hear your pain about feeling disenfranchised in multiple areas of your life and the weight you're bearing coming to a head. It is clear you are grappling with a great deal, but it is important to remember you are not alone.

It appears that you are confronting financial, personal and emotional stressors--each a difficult task on their own and particularly overwhelming when overlapped. Finding the most pressing issue and tackling that first may make it a bit more manageable. 

With regards to your son, remember that kids thrive on love, care and stability. Showing him love whenever you are able to be with him will remain in his thoughts. It‚Äôs not always about quantity, but the quality of time spent. 

Loss of friendships, especially deep-rooted ones, is painful but sometimes necessary. It is crucial to surround yourself with positive, supportive people. Joining groups or activities that interest you may be a great place to start building a new network.

As far as your financial concerns go, many communities offer resources for employment and financial assistance. A quick search online could point you in the right direction with resources or agencies within your community that can provide guidance or possibly assistance.

Lastly but very importantly: your mental health. I would encourage you to seek out a professional who can assist you in a formal setting. Check if there are local resources available for mental health services; they could help you navigate through your feelings of depression.

Know that it's okay to ask for help, we all need it from time to time. You're making the effort to understand and work on your struggles, which is a huge step. It might take time, but it's never too late to change the direction of your life. You're very young and have a lot of life ahead of you. Don't lose hope.

Your message is loud and clear and I want you to know it's okay. It seems like you're in a really tough place and a lot has occurred which is out of your control. It's really difficult to take on responsibilities at such a young age like parenthood, especially when the circumstances aren't supportive. It's completely okay to feel overwhelmed and frustrated.

Losing your job and realizing your friends weren't actually there for you can feel very isolating. These feelings might make you feel like everything's against you. This moment of your life is incredibly challenging, but please remember, it's just a moment. It doesn't define you, nor does it set parameters for your future. 

It's important to seek some professional help right now. Seeing a mental health professional could give you a secure and safe space to express your emotions, and to learn coping strategies for your current circumstances. They can also point you towards resources, both for help with your depression and your financial problems.

In the meantime, remember it's okay to be vulnerable and engage with your feelings. Your feelings are valid because they are yours and you're entitled to feel them. They aren't a sign of weakness. You're stronger than you know, and things will get better.

Take care.
