I'm really sorry to hear you're feeling this way, and I can only imagine how tough things must be for you right now. Remember, everyone's mental health is just as important as their physical health, and it's totally okay to seek help when you're feeling overwhelmed like this.

For your current circumstances, I'd encourage you to look into local resources and organizations that can offer financial or emotional support. There might be places that can lend a helping hand with anything from providing groceries, baby supplies, to free meditation sessions to help you cope with the stress. Since you've lost your job, local job assistance or a career center might also provide free counseling and guidance for finding new work.

Regarding your child, remember that all a kid needs is love, time, and emotional support. Listening, talking, playing, just being there. You might not be able to spend as much time as you'd like with your kid right now, but do make sure the time you do have is filled with warmth and affection.

As for your relationships, know that it's okay to let go of toxic friendships. And while your parents may not fully understand your struggles, that doesn't mean they don't care about you. They may be unaware of the severity of your feelings, so try reaching out again. 

I really think you'd benefit from talking with a mental health professional. They can provide you with tools to manage your feelings of depression and help realign your perspective. If you're having trouble finding or affording mental health services, look into teletherapy‚Äîmany places offer this service at reduced prices, or even for free.

Finally, remember that you're not alone and there are people out there that want to help and support you. Keep hanging on, brighter days are ahead.

Take care.

post:
At 23 years old I moved from Rome to the Netherlands to study for my Master, and I had the time of my life. I made a lot of friends from every possible country, I had been in love, I have discovered a lot about myself. 
Moving from the center of Rome, one of the biggest cities in the world, to such a small country like The Netherlands. What I found there was open-mindedness and obviously a very international and different social setting, which has led me indeed to bond with many different people with different backgrounds and thus likely habits.
Then though, I had to move back to Rome at the end of the experience, but after one year staying here I feel like my life has no purpose here. I was used to a life of new discoveries everyday, I was challenged to change my habits in order to experiment new cultures, but now it all disappeared. How do you manage to go back to the usual routine and the usual neighborhood life? Everybody told me to try and change it, but how can you really, in such an environment? Should I go alone to places and introduce myself?
reply: Hey there! It's never easy to return to an old routine after such an expansive journey. The beauty of travel is the way it colors and changes our perspective. What's important is to remember those experiences and allow them to be a part of your current journey, even if it's back in your old neighborhood. There's nothing wrong with going alone to places or introducing yourself to new people - it's one way to add a bit of the unexpected back into your life. Consider joining clubs with similar interests, reconnecting with old friends, or venturing out and exploring parts of Rome that you've never seen before. Your adventure doesn't have to stop because your location has changed!

Moving from the center of Rome, one of the biggest cities in the world, to such a small country like The Netherlands. What I found there was open-mindedness and obviously a very international and different social setting, which has led me indeed to bond with many different people with different backgrounds and thus likely habits.
Then though, I had to move back to Rome at the end of the experience, but after one year staying here I feel like my life has no purpose here. I was used to a life of new discoveries everyday, I was challenged to change my habits in order to experiment new cultures, but now it all disappeared. How do you manage to go back to the usual routine and the usual neighborhood life? Everybody told me to try and change it, but how can you really, in such an environment? Should I go alone to places and introduce myself?
reply:
Hey there,

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. What you're experiencing is a very common phenomenon known as reverse culture shock. You've expanded your horizons by living in a different country, and now, returning to your old routine might feel stifling and without purpose.

So how do you combat this? Initially, it might require you to actively seek out new experiences, even in your familiar setting. Your environment might be the same, but remember - you've changed. There's always something new to learn and explore.

Another possible option is to go back to your city as a tourist. Look for places you've never visited before, try foods you've never tasted - approach your city with the same excitement and curiosity as you did when you moved to the Netherlands.

It's also crucial to find a supportive community. Seek out like-minded people who enjoy the same activities as you, people with whom you can share your experiences. Joining social or hobby clubs might be a good start. Don't hesitate to introduce yourself. Yes, it's out of your comfort zone, but you've proven through your international experience that you can thrive there.

Finally, remember that it's okay to miss your life in the Netherlands. It's okay to feel sad or nostalgic. But also remember that you're brimming with new experiences, perspectives, and abilities that you've gained from your time abroad. Use these rich experiences to enhance your life back home, and to encourage the growth of your sense of purpose. 

Sending you strength and good thoughts. You've got this!

Should I go alone to places and introduce myself?
reply:
Your feelings of "loss of purpose" might be a form of reverse culture shock, something many people experience after spending significant time abroad. Such feelings can be disorienting and confusing, and can also lead to a sense of isolation. It's important to remember that these feelings are normal and that many people have gone through the same thing.

Finding purpose again could involve incorporating elements of your experience in the Netherlands into your life in Rome. You mentioned that you appreciated the open-mindedness and international social setting in the Netherlands. Perhaps you could seek out those same elements in Rome. There may be international student groups, language exchange clubs, or other culturally diverse communities which could provide a similar environment to what you experienced in the Netherlands.

Also, it's perfectly okay to go places alone and introduce yourself! If you're hesitant, look out for events or groups that cater to newcomers or solo attendees. You never know who you might meet! Plus, forcing yourself outside your comfort zone could reignite that exploratory spirit you had in the Netherlands.

Ultimately remember, your feelings are valid. Transitioning back into a "routine" life can be challenging ‚Äì take it day at a time and be patient. It might be helpful to speak to a counselor or join a support group (in person or online) for people who've also lived abroad or are dealing with similar feelings. It's okay to ask for help when you need it, you're not alone in what you're going through.

Feel free to reach out if you need someone to talk to. We're here to support you.

Take care!

Hey there, I'm genuinely sorry to hear you're going through a tough time right now. Losing a job and constantly being at home can definitely take a toll on one's mental health. In addition to job searching, it's important to look after yourself as well. Take it one day at a time. One strategy might be setting small, daily goals like a morning walk or cooking a new meal. This may sound clich√©, but it genuinely helps to bring a slight change to the monotony. 

Also, have you considered remote jobs or freelancing? It could potentially open up more employment opportunities. If you're open to it, I can share some websites to get you started. It's quite normal to feel this way after losing a job, especially when circumstances are difficult. Please know that you're not alone and there are people and services available that want to support you.

Make sure you're taking small steps each day to look after your mental and physical health. That might mean getting out of bed for a couple of hours, going for a walk, or even just taking a shower and eating a good meal. Little changes can often have a big impact.

When it comes to work, try and explore different avenues. There may be remote work opportunities or other job fields that you haven't considered yet. Reach out to job agencies, both physical and online. They often have resources to help people in your situation.

Lastly, don't hesitate to talk about your feelings with your girlfriend. Openness is key in a relationship and supporting each other emotionally is vital. It's alright to not be okay. It's part of being human. Take care of yourself and remember, you always have worth, no matter your employment situation.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this difficult period. Losing a job can be a challenging experience and feeling like you're 'rotting away' is an indication that you might be dealing with some form of depression. I highly recommend reaching out to a mental health professional, if you haven't already, to gain some insights and tools for dealing with your emotional state. 

In the meantime, small things can often have a big impact on our mental well-being. Try injecting some structure into your day, as having a routine can help foster a sense of normality and productivity. Perhaps you can establish consistent wake-up and bedtime, or schedule in regular meals and exercise. 

In addition to this, consider exploring some new hobbies or interests. This could be anything from learning to cook a new recipe, taking up meditation, reading, drawing, or even catching up with friends over a video call. 

Remember, it's okay to have bad days and it's okay to ask for help when you need it. You're not alone in this, so don't hesitate to seek out resources available to you in your country, in your community or even within this forum. 

Finally, reconnect with your partner. Open up about what you're experiencing. Having a support system can make a monumental difference in your mental health. Be kind to yourself during this challenging time.

Hey there, 

I can sense that you're dealing with some tough emotions right now, and that's completely normal and okay. Losing your job, especially due to factors beyond your control, can really impact your self-esteem and overall mental health. In this modern age, our work is often a big part of our identity, and losing it can feel like losing a part of ourselves. 

You're not alone in these feelings. Many people, from various walks of life, have felt this way, especially during this pandemic. Remember, it's okay to reach out for professional help when we're not feeling well mentally, just as we would physically. If you're comfortable, you might want to consider reaching out to a mental health professional in your area, or perhaps look into online resources or hotlines available in Norway.

Moreover, striving for a routine other than just delving into the digital world may help. It could be as simple as investing time in your hobbies, exercising, cooking something special for you and your girlfriend or even exploring outside when possible. The aim is not to escape your reality, but to enrich it. Interaction with nature and establishing a balanced daily routine can often be very therapeutic.

You're already showing great strength by seeking support and expressing your feelings - which is the first step towards feeling better. Remember, it's okay to have bad days, but always remember that there are resources out there to help you through them.

Stay strong and keep pushing forward!

I make a great deal of effort to connect and process various people and understand them. Often it exhausts me with how much they wish to share and all these words and concepts I can barely connect with and videos they send- and I have to reread many times and feel so dumb. I don't mind this too much- but what I do mind is that this person will go through all of this just to forget about me and move on sometime this or the next month, or week! I know it's a big thing to say- but it feels like a form of emotional rape. And both men and women do this crap.

So the trauma and disassociation I referred to above probably has a lot to do with all the abandonment and neglect I've known since birth pretty much which really makes it hard for me to get invested or care about gender, race, conservatism or Liberalism, or any of the issues current today. I have always felt left out, excluded, and marginalized. I don't know what a partner looks like- but also not what friends or family looks like! Hell, I don't know what love and care looks like because those who were most often the most eager to give out hugs and warm words were the freshest to leave without any explanation or thought. This is not far from being different than a lady who has had a one night stand and feels dirty afterwards because there was never any love and she was just used. At least she might have some family and/or friends to return home to. This has not been true for me.

I couldn't even cry when the one person who did really care and stay was killed by the police- Jasper Aaron Lynch. I couldn't cry because of how surreal it felt just to have had your deepest bond be someone you knew mostly digitally and saw in life only three times- and this best friend who called you his best had the photos to remember things with with other people- not with you. 

So what does love mean? please I need to know this. And don't lecture me about porn because I hate it too- but I also realize that even the die hard porn hater who is a straight as the cross conservative Christian watches YouTube and frequents Disney films- and these things are all family with porn

See porn is not just bad because of the toxicity regarding sex to both men and women- but it's even more fundamentally bad in how it reduces the social habitat of being human and gives a mere approximation- a toxic one to a human's needs- and frankly all social media and the entertainment industry is built on this- pipe dreams in the ass of everyone who will take a seat!

It's all parasocial engagement. the people do not care about you and it takes a part of life- a part that should be there to live!- and caramelizes it to get you addicted: You watch great sex instead of having real sex yourself with someone you care about and want to be intimate with and stay with- a person you wake up to and feel fuzzy and warm with; you watch a Disney movie where characters seem to be spontaneous and invite fun into their daily lives because you are too pencil screwed to ever make light of things and co-create with another, you are adulting; you watch content creators on YouTube and read blogs to engage intellectually because you can't ever have intellectually deep conversations with any of your teachers, who teach thousands of students and don't care about you, or your friends who are too busy and just want to have a good time.

Frankly the people who create your intelligence and amusement are of the same breed who give rise to your libido- none of these people exist! They are golden calves of one form of idolatry or another!

I just don't know how to survive anymore with all this. I can't seem to find anyone- and if I do it is again online which is by its nature non-committal.  I can't care about the gender wars when I find myself thrown into the fray because of hormones and intimacy frustration when the human race has really not included me. Your concerns are not even real because I have lived an entirety of life being unreal and disposable. I don't know what anything really means anymore including someone who wants me to become a Christian because I was left behind. I don't know if ultimately everything is just reducible to a machine and everything is constructed off of simply hurting each and everything- and we are both so complicated and so stupid to point the finger everywhere but ourselves and label "the other" as the group doing the hurting.
reply:
Hey there, I see there's a lot occupying your mind right now. Your loneliness and frustration are palpable and that's not easy to deal with. You're dealing with too much negativity around you which is affecting your view on people around you and the world. 

It's crucial for you to understand that not all people are bad or follow the same toxic patterns that you're noticing. Every person is unique with their own interests, values, and behaviors. It's great that you enjoy theatre, Shakespeare, literature, music, etc. and trust me, there are others who also enjoy them equally. You must strive to find these people rather than focussing on those who don't share your interests.

It seems like you need a break from all the toxic online spaces and spend some time around nature, books, music or whatever helps you relax and introspect. It could be beneficial for you to reach out to a mental health professional who can help guide you through your feelings of loneliness, frustration, and disassociation. 

The world is full of diversity - different races, religions, political parties, genders etc., and not all are the same. There's so much more to individuals than just the labels they carry. When it comes to love, it is one of the most personal emotions, and it's experienced differently by everyone. This confusion you're facing is valid and it's okay not to know 'What love means' because it's not the same for everyone. 

Lastly, focusing on self-improvement is not a bad thing and doesn't mean to change for others. It means to find happiness in oneself and being satisfied with one's own growth. "Don't change for the world, let the world change for you," is a mantra you can follow. You are who you are, and that's your power. Stay strong!

post:
So here I am- one of many nights where I feel sexually frustrated and horny. I suppose I have my hands and porn, or my hands and my imagination. And maybe I will get the usual from a lot of dudes and beaus: one side will call me out as a lazy fuck who needs to work on self improvement which really just translates to "go to the gym, freshen up your wardrobe, get offline, go outside and meet people, and find a good stable career". The problem with these dudes is they don't know anything but Marvel or some other nonsense. Theatre, Shakespeare, Literature, Music, dance, film, sociology, philosophy, history, art- they know nothing. They would be pretty dumb founded if you asked them about any books or authors. Their brains work like a Campbell's soup commercial. A taxidermist couldn't fish out anything of any value. I've seen how stupid and vulgar they often are showing off themselves in mirrors and confabulating on the latest tech- and they will always increase the victimization of any other men with any real challenges by blaming them as being responsible for their victimization. They also use men in subordinative and domineering ways to make themselves feel superior. This often is given off as them trying to be helpful when really they are just patronizing as fuck! So I would rather not even be a fucking dude anymore- maybe become trans not to have to be associated with these worthless men.

Then there are the women out here who are hyper vigilant and on patrol for anyone who might in anyway aggress them and force themselves upon them, or manipulate them. And it can feel like walking on pins and needles and they aren't always clear because simply they don't trust you- and there are some of us who will never earn that trust because... "you just carry a vibe!" And to these women I jerking off, looking at porn, and my profile page- I am condemned immediately! No questions, buts, or ifs about it. I am the villain! Don't I know of their free choice and rights?! Don't I know the oppression they have faced for aeons?! Don't I know how common rape and sexual assault is?! I should not act entitled- how dare I! "YOU ARE AN INCEL!!" And there are plenty of men who will come loud and proud to this argument, championing it like a white knight. One of these men that I know personally will also lecture me in being a vegetarian because of all the methane produced by cows while he meanwhile pollutes the environment with bit-coin mining!

And all I have said in any of this was about being lonely and sexually frustrated, admitted to porn and jerking off- nothing else- and yeah the porn industry is fucking toxic and there's a history of abuse, violating and exploiting women, and getting them so fucked out of their minds that they would agree to anything on set- and yeah Harvey Weinstein and Hugh Hefner are scum. I agree with everything. I also find that the sexual exploitation simply reversed its direction with Onlyfans and much of the Reddit posers on here exploit lonely and disaffected men emotionally while wrapping it in sugar coated sex. Some content creators don't do this- but most do. The former victimization of women is not rectified by victimizing later the opposing group in which oppressors came from. It doesn't work this way. This is the same thing that happens in other ways too. Most men are NOT Harvey Weinstein's or Jeffrey Epstein's! These are a few successful assholes who acquired their magnificence through exploiting others who worshipped them- and these assholes exist with both dicks and pussies. And yet we as a society continue to worship assholes and when things get too sticky we destroy them and pretend like we weren't to blame and go worship an asshole from another label group. So all men are assholes. Now it's women. Then all women are assholes. Maybe all whites are assholes. Then all blacks. Or all Asians. Or whatever fuck! Assholes exist regardless of gender or race or political affiliation or nationality or religion! 

And I have nothing more to account for than my own actions in this world. I am a white male on the autism spectrum and I may do bad things because of my "privilege" but I also may do bad things because of media exposure and me being on the spectrum? But I am only responsible for my actions in as much as I can and have been aware of what I do. I cannot be accountable for people prior to me who passed on their genes to me and I can only be but so accountable to ignorance when in this world people mostly choose to fight and not explain things- not have any kind of patience because you set off a trigger, and because with all this stupid tech there is a pollution of pseudo- info and each person seems to live in their own bubble of knowledge like MGS2 forecasted. 

So I look at all this and look at the toxic men and toxic women I meet regularly- men who gaslight me,  dehumanize me, and are totally vapid and condescend me; and I look at women who are hyper vigilant, flaky, unapproachable, have double meanings, unpredictable, insecure, angry, dog worshipping, psychologically baggage dumping, emotionally fake, noncommittal, aggressively interested then not, operating as a surrogate persona of their former ex to which they are bound, or addicted to attention- and I don't want any of it. I'd rather just be acknowledged and engaged with as a person a priori!!!! I am a person fundamentally before my gender! Do I have to become trans just not to deal with all the garbage of both men and women.

Why do so many men seem to gravitate to me as we have something in common as both being losers in the gender wars and being sexually frustrated?! All else doesn't exist. I mean I get the frustration and depression- but I am so much more than this as a person- and to be seen either by men or women as I am often seen reduces and dehumanizes me on some level I feel. I never make any magical memories with my co-depairers or those who see me as the potential target to lash out against. It's always purely about them and I am part of the stage set of their play. So yeah it really is best to find someone who is trans- but then I have to be careful with a lot of trans to female because too many try to mimic the toxicity of women. But men who trans to women usually do not mimic male toxicity I have noticed. I can have a emotionally mature bond without the domination and stupid cultural crap.

Maybe I am all off on everything I am saying here. But I am writing how I see it and what I have been exposed to. I am also suffering from severe disassociation, trauma and shut down most of the time and feel like all the people who try to connect with me- both men and women are just going to dump me without second thought- use and dump me. I make a great deal of effort to connect and process various people and understand them. I understand that you're going through a tough time, and it sounds like you're feeling pressured, frustrated and alone in your experiences. I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way but feel the need to mention that chat like this is not geared toward helping people through situations like this. There are trained professionals who can provide better help and support than we can at this time, and I urge you to seek them out. 

I would recommend trying professional help in the forms of therapists or counselors. There are many types that may suit your needs, such as psychotherapists, cognitive-behavioral therapists, or trauma therapists. They can provide targeted strategies and therapies which can really help you in exploring complex issues and understanding your own mind better.

You're not alone. There are people who want to talk, listen, and help. Reach out and take that first step, and remember it's okay not to be okay and it's okay to ask for help. I would also encourage you to work on finding positive outlets for your thoughts, emotions and energy. 

Just to reiterate, I‚Äôm really sorry that you‚Äôre feeling this way, but I‚Äôm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

reply:
Hello, and thank you for sharing such a deeply personal account of your feelings. It sounds like you're experiencing a whirlwind of emotions right now - frustration, loneliness, and it sounds like you're going through a lot of pain. Please know it's okay to feel these emotions. Dealing with these feelings can be incredibly challenging and can often make us feel isolated, misunderstood, and lost. 

You've highlighted so beautifully and keenly the complex issues around social pressures, gender expectations, and the many unfairnesses of life - and it's clear these issues are causing you a lot of distress. Sexuality and gender identity in particular can be complex topics and it's entirely normal to feel confused or frustrated, given the complexities involved.

In terms of your disassociation and the trauma you've spoken about, these are indicative of deeper emotional wounds and it's crucially important to address them, as difficult as it may be. The feeling of being emotionally used and abandoned is a significant aspect of trauma that's often overlooked. 

Trauma healing is a journey and it doesn't happen overnight. It's okay to need time to heal and it's also okay to reach out for help when you need it. I strongly suggest you consider speaking with a mental health professional who specializes in trauma. They can provide you with the opportunities to understand and heal from your experiences in a safe, supportive environment. 

The feelings of loneliness and disconnection you're experiencing are sadly very common in today's society, and particularly for those of us on the spectrum. It can be really tough when you're trying to connect with people and feel like you're constantly hitting a wall. It sounds like you've been trying really hard to connect and understand people on a deeper level, which is a very admirable effort. 

Connecting with others means opening oneself to potential hurt or rejection, and unfortunately, that's a risk we take when we make these attempts. But remember, rejection doesn't reflect your worth as a person. You are worthy of genuine, fulfilling connections and love.

Also, it may be helpful to seek out groups or communities with similar interests to your own, like literature, philosophy, history. This could provide an avenue for you to connect with others on a deeper, intellectual level.

As for your sexual frustrations, please bear in mind there's no single 'correct' way to navigate these feelings. It's about finding what works for you, in a way that is both fulfilling and respectful to yourself and others. It's also important to consider discussing these feelings with a professional, like a sex therapist, who can better guide you through this.

Again, I can't stress enough the importance of you reaching out to a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or counselor, who can provide a safe space for you to explore these feelings and gain further understanding of yourself.

Remember, you don't have to go through this alone. Help is available, and there are people who want to support you through this. Keep reaching out, keep expressing your feelings, and remember it's okay to ask for the help that you need. Your experiences and feelings are important and valid, and you are worthy of love, care, and respect.

These are a few successful assholes who acquired their magnificence through exploiting others who worshipped them- and these assholes exist with both dicks and pussies. And yet we as a society continue to worship assholes and when things get too sticky we destroy them and pretend like we weren't to blame and go worship an asshole from another label group. So all men are assholes. Now it's women. Then all women are assholes. Maybe all whites are assholes. Then all blacks. Or all Asians. Or whatever fuck! Assholes exist regardless of gender or race or political affiliation or nationality or religion! 

And I have nothing more to account for than my own actions in this world. I am a white male on the autism spectrum and I may do bad things because of my "privilege" but I also may do bad things because of media exposure and me being on the spectrum? But I am only responsible for my actions in as much as I can and have been aware of what I do. I cannot be accountable for people prior to me who passed on their genes to me and I can only be but so accountable to ignorance when in this world people mostly choose to fight and not explain things- not have any kind of patience because you set off a trigger, and because with all this stupid tech there is a pollution of pseudo- info and each person seems to live in their own bubble of knowledge like MGS2 forecasted. 

So I look at all this and look at the toxic men and toxic women I meet regularly- men who gaslight me,  dehumanize me, and are totally vapid and condescend me; and I look at women who are hyper vigilant, flaky, unapproachable, have double meanings, unpredictable, insecure, angry, dog worshipping, psychologically baggage dumping, emotionally fake, noncommittal, aggressively interested then not, operating as a surrogate persona of their former ex to which they are bound, or addicted to attention- and I don't want any of it. I'd rather just be acknowledged and engaged with as a person a priori!!!! I am a person fundamentally before my gender! Do I have to become trans just not to deal with all the garbage of both men and women.

Why do so many men seem to gravitate to me as we have something in common as both being losers in the gender wars and being sexually frustrated?! All else doesn't exist. I mean I get the frustration and depression- but I am so much more than this as a person- and to be seen either by men or women as I am often seen reduces and dehumanizes me on some level I feel. I never make any magical memories with my co-depairers or those who see me as the potential target to lash out against. It's always purely about them and I am part of the stage set of their play. So yeah it really is best to find someone who is trans- but then I have to be careful with a lot of trans to female because too many try to mimic the toxicity of women. But men who trans to women usually do not mimic male toxicity I have noticed. I can have a emotionally mature bond without the domination and stupid cultural crap.

Maybe I am all off on everything I am saying here. But I am writing how I see it and what I have been exposed to. I am also suffering from severe disassociation, trauma and shut down most of the time and feel like all the people who try to connect with me- both men and women are just going to dump me without second thought- use and dump me. I make a great deal of effort to connect and process various people and understand them. Often it exhausts me with how much they wish to share and all these words and concepts I can barely connect with and videos they send- and I have to reread many times and feel so dumb. I don't mind this too much- but what I do mind is that this person will go through all of this just to forget about me and move on sometime this or the next month, or week! I know it's a big thing to say- but it feels like a form of emotional rape. And both men and women do this crap.

So the trauma and disassociation I referred to above probably has a lot to do with all the abandonment and neglect I've known since birth pretty much which really makes it hard for me to get invested or care about gender, race, conservatism or Liberalism, or any of the issues current today. I have always felt left out, excluded, and marginalized. I don't know what a partner looks like- but also not what friends or family looks like! Hell, I don't know what love and care looks like because those who were most often the most eager to give out hugs and warm words were the freshest to leave without any explanation or thought. This is not far from being different than a lady who has had a one night stand and feels dirty afterwards because there was never any love and she was just used. At least she might have some family and/or friends to return home to. This has not been true for me.

I couldn't even cry when the one person who did really care and stay was killed by the police- Jasper Aaron Lynch. I couldn't cry because of how surreal it felt just to have had your deepest bond be someone you knew mostly digitally and saw in life only three times- and this best friend who called you his best had the photos to remember things with with other people- not with you. 

So what does love mean? please I need to know this. And don't lecture me about porn because I hate it too- but I also realize that even the die hard porn hater who is a straight as the cross conservative Christian watches YouTube and frequents Disney films- and these things are all family with porn

See porn is not just bad because of the toxicity regarding sex to both men and women- but it's even more fundamentally bad in how it reduces the social habitat of being human and gives a mere approximation- a toxic one to a human's needs- and frankly all social media and the entertainment industry is built on this- pipe dreams in the ass of everyone who will take a seat!

It's all parasocial engagement. the people do not care about you and it takes a part of life- a part that should be there to live!- and caramelizes it to get you addicted: You watch great sex instead of having real sex yourself with someone you care about and want to be intimate with and stay with- a person you wake up to and feel fuzzy and warm with; you watch a Disney movie where characters seem to be spontaneous and invite fun into their daily lives because you are too pencil screwed to ever make light of things and co-create with another, you are adulting; you watch content creators on YouTube and read blogs to engage intellectually because you can't ever have intellectually deep conversations with any of your teachers, who teach thousands of students and don't care about you, or your friends who are too busy and just want to have a good time.

Frankly the people who create your intelligence and amusement are of the same breed who give rise to your libido- none of these people exist! They are golden calves of one form of idolatry or another!

I just don't know how to survive anymore with all this. I can't seem to find anyone- and if I do it is again online which is by its nature non-committal.  I can't care about the gender wars when I find myself thrown into the fray because of hormones and intimacy frustration when the human race has really not included me. Your concerns are not even real because I have lived an entirety of life being unreal and disposable. I don't know what anything really means anymore including someone who wants me to become a Christian because I was left behind. I don't know if ultimately everything is just reducible to a machine and everything is constructed off of simply hurting each and everything- and we are both so complicated and so stupid to point the finger everywhere but ourselves and label "the other" as the group doing the hurting.
reply: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

post:
Hello,
I am a Student in a German school and I hate almost everyone at my school. I Just hate it, for sometime I could Life with it. I Had and still have good Friends, and I still enjoy my Life, But These people (drug addicts and alcohlics with the age of 15) or telling rumors about me and "Beat me Up" with words. I Just feel so overwhelmed with it becouse for a long time they didnt do it, I Just Lived with it but they started again. I think I can handle it if I Play some Videogames or fap but I am right now taking with both a Detox, and I Just feel so sad and overwhelmed and dont know what to do.
I have the fear that people start hating me becouse of These rumors/and or feel disgusted and in that way I would never get a girlfriend too. What can I do? What will make me feel Better again besides gaming and faping?
reply:
Hey there,

Sorry to hear about your struggles. It sounds like a really tough time for you. Remember that people's opinions are not a reflection of your worth. Trust in yourself. It's easier said than done, but important. 

It sounds clich√©, but activities such as sports, taking up a new hobby, reading books or even learning a new language can help a lot. They distract you, make you feel accomplished, and provide a sense of purpose. 

Also, reaching out for professional help isn't a bad idea. Guidance counsellors at your school or a therapist can really help you navigate through this difficult time. 

Lastly, remember these people and this situation are temporary. Things will get better. You're braver and stronger than you think. Keep going!

Much love and support to you.

I have the fear that people start hating me becouse of These rumors/and or feel disgusted and in that way I would never get a girlfriend too. What can I do? What will make me feel Better again besides gaming and faping?
reply:
Hi there,

I'm sorry to hear you're going through this. It sounds like you're experiencing quite a bit of stress. Let's try to tackle this a step at a time. 

Firstly, it's crucial to understand that the behavior of those around you says more about them than it does about you. People who spread rumors or hurt others with words are often insecure themselves and choose to target others to cope with their own issues. Try to distance yourself from their negativity as much as you can, both physically and emotionally.

Sharing your feelings with your good friends can help. Let them know you‚Äôre having a tough time, as they may be able to provide the support and encouragement you need, and it could also protect you from rumors. 

Also, have you spoken to a trusted adult about this? A teacher, counselor, or family member could offer helpful perspective and perhaps even intervene on your behalf.

Doing things you enjoy can help improve your mood. It sounds like you're taking a break from video games, which is fine. Maybe you could try something new like reading, drawing, or playing a sport? You might even discover a new hobby. 

Lastly, about fear of people not liking you due to rumors, keep in mind that anyone who bases their opinion of you on unfounded rumors is probably not someone you need in your life. Focus on being your best self, and people who matter will see that. 

Remember, you don‚Äôt need everyone to like you, just a few good people who appreciate you for who you are. And when it comes to dating, trust in the idea that someone out there will appreciate the real you, regardless of rumors or toxic individuals.

Stay strong and remember that it's alright to ask for help. We're here to support you.

I think I can handle it if I Play some Videogames or fap but I am right now taking with both a Detox, and I Just feel so sad and overwhelmed and dont know what to do.
I have the fear that people start hating me becouse of These rumors/and or feel disgusted and in that way I would never get a girlfriend too. What can I do? What will make me feel Better again besides gaming and faping?
reply:
Hi there,

Firstly, I would like to commend you for reaching out and sharing your feelings here. You're definitely not alone in this journey, and I want you to know that there are many kind souls online who would love to extend their support to you. 

Being a teenager in school, particularly in a difficult environment, is stressful and can make us feel vulnerable. It's valid to feel overwhelmed and sad, dealing with rumors, unpleasant people, and the fear of being rejected. Toxic environments can be tough, so it's important to learn how to cope and protect your mental health.

One thing that might be beneficial for you is to remain engaged in positive activities that can be both recreational and therapeutic. This could include reading, writing, art, sports or even simply taking a walk outside. Physical activity can do wonders for our mood and overall mental health.

Another strategy could be to recognize and challenge any negative thoughts you might have about yourself. You're much more than what others may perceive or say about you. You can fight these negative feelings by acknowledging your strengths, accomplishments, and qualities. A little self-love can be really impactful!

We also need to remember that other people's opinions of us are often a reflection of their own insecurities and not an accurate depiction of reality. Seek validation from the people who truly matter to you, those who know your worth and see you for who you really are. It might also be helpful to talk to someone you trust about what you're going through, like a family member, counselor, or a good friend.

Remember, seeking help from a mental health professional is a great option if you find your feelings too overwhelming to handle on your own. There is absolutely nothing wrong with seeking help, and it's a step forward towards feeling better. Please take care!

Thank you for sharing with us, and recognize that each day is a step forward in your journey. Keep your head high!

post:
Upon reflecting and grinding, it occurred to me that when I make the mistake of opening up and talking about my problems, no matter where it is, I am the victim. But if I keep it light and just "contribute" then I am welcomed. Idk I feel like I am half a Machievell and half a Sociopath because I try my best to make my "moves" count socially.

With dating? Forget it. Too much risk and I am just an average white dude slowly going into his 30s. If women want me, then they should be obvious because now it seems women are not really women but a lesser version of a man, if that makes sense. Women aren't being top women.

As for friends? I think I got the hang of it but it is all surface and cliche stuff. I get it won't get me "closer" but it's fine because I wouldn't want them to use my weaknesses against me. Again, it seems that today's world is like the Fall of Rome: everyone for themselves but don't you dare criticise anyone or anything  


Just my 2 cents. Wondering what you all think
reply:
It sounds like you're caught in a tough situation navigating social and dating dynamics. I get it, it's not easy. Our society often makes it difficult to be vulnerable without fear of judgment. Remember, it's okay to share your problems with others, and not every interaction has to be strategic. In terms of dating, it's crucial to communicate honestly and openly with potential partners to foster mutual understanding and respect. Not all women are the same, just like all men aren't. There are so many people out there seeking genuine connections just like you.

Lastly, it might seem like everyone is out for themselves, but genuine friendships do exist. In your quest to make your "moves" count socially, don't forget to drop the shields once in a while. Let people see and know the real you. Sure, you might get hurt, but you may also find the genuine connections you're looking for. Stay strong, buddy. üí™

Hey there, it sounds like you're grappling with some challenging emotions and perspectives about social interaction, relationships, and the nature of people and society as a whole. This all does get pretty messy, doesn't it? It can be hard to trust and open up to people for fear of being hurt or used, and it's tough feeling like you have to strategize your every move socially. 

It seems like you feel the society has become a bit more selfish and less willing to handle criticism. It's true, the world does seem to be moving in a more individualistic direction. Just remember, you're not alone in that sensation, there are plenty of us feeling lost in this fast-paced, digital world.

Regarding dating, sure, risks come with it but also opportunities. Just because you consider yourself 'average' doesn't mean you haven't got tons to offer. Remember that people are attracted to all sorts of qualities - not all physical - so try to put value in your personality, skills, and experiences too.

In terms of friendships, yes, they often start off quite surface-level, but once trust and connection are built, you can get to more substantial conversations. You don't have to share something you're uncomfortable with just for the sake of sounding deep.
  
It's clear you're introspective. Reflection is a great tool for personal growth. You're on the right track seeking diverse perspectives to help navigate these challenges. Keep reaching out and carrying on an open dialogue. 

Stay strong and remember, it's okay to ask for professional help if you ever need someone to talk to objectively about your emotions.

Perhaps seeking a support group, either online or offline, could provide a safe space for you to discuss these feelings further.

Upon reflecting and grinding, it occurred to me that when I make the mistake of opening up and talking about my problems, no matter where it is, I am the victim. But if I keep it light and just "contribute" then I am welcomed. Idk I feel like I am half a Machievell and half a Sociopath because I try my best to make my "moves" count socially.

With dating? Forget it. Too much risk and I am just an average white dude slowly going into his 30s. If women want me, then they should be obvious because now it seems women are not really women but a lesser version of a man, if that makes sense. Women aren't being top women.

As for friends? I think I got the hang of it but it is all surface and cliche stuff. I get it won't get me "closer" but it's fine because I wouldn't want them to use my weaknesses against me. Again, it seems that today's world is like the Fall of Rome: everyone for themselves but don't you dare criticise anyone or anything  


Just my 2 cents. Wondering what you all think
reply:
Hi there,

It sounds like you're going through quite a struggle right now. Feelings of alienation, isolation and not being understood are common when we're navigating the complexities of life and social relationships. It's completely okay to feel this way and you're not alone. 

I think the first step to address these feelings is self-compassion. Go easy on yourself and remember that everyone makes mistakes and it's part of being human. The fear of vulnerability isn‚Äôt uncommon, but it's often through vulnerability that we form deeper connections with others.

If you feel people take advantage of your weaknesses, it might help to set clear boundaries about what you're comfortable sharing and knowing respect is a two-way street. 

It's okay to keep it light sometimes, and it's also okay to be serious if the situation calls for it. Understanding when it's appropriate to open up is something that comes with time and experience, so try not to put pressure on yourself.

As for dating, it can be confusing. The dynamics have evolved and people express their interest in different ways. It's important to focus on clear communication and understanding each other's needs. Recognize each person is an individual, with their own thoughts, feelings, and experiences. 

It sounds like you value strength, resilience, and independence. But it's essential to remember that strength comes in many forms, including the capacity for empathy, compassion and vulnerability.  Those traits aren't gender-specific, they're human.

Living in a dynamic world can indeed feel like a balancing act sometimes. But rest assured, you're not alone in navigating through these winds of change. Try not to lose sight of the fact that every interaction holds potential for learning and growth. I encourage you to seek out positive discussions and keep an open mind. 

Remember, it‚Äôs okay to ask for help when needed. You might benefit from seeking professional advice where you can explore these feelings in a safe environment. You're already incredibly brave to share your feelings here and you‚Äôre on the right track. Wishing you all the best on your journey!

Well, here I am.

I've been bouting with anxiety and depression for a long time, but there is something I never really talked about to anyone. It's about my size. I know that according to stats it should be in perfect average (17 cm), but many of the women I've slept with off handedly remarked that that was no way the real average because they usually date larger man. Infact, turned out that the Italian average is quite a bit higher.

[https://oltreuomo.com/lunghezza-media-del-pene-italia-per-regione/](https://oltreuomo.com/lunghezza-media-del-pene-italia-per-regione/)

​

https://preview.redd.it/tr1i928ltama1.png?width=600&format=png&auto=webp&v=enabled&s=28894c3ce514b3e4418e619203211ec0ad614423

Anyway, since those instances I've started developing an intense anxiety about sex, something I already lived badly because of performance anxiety etc. In time I stopped dating altogether, I even stopped masturbating and finding other human beings attractive.For a short period I had this weird online thing with a girl from abroad, who probably had very similar insecurities as me. She never showed me her face and was extremely private about her appearance BUT she we were into one another she insisted at least sexting and sharing nudes with me.I tried to take pictures of myself but as I did I felt so ashamed because it looked so tiny that I stopped right there and quitted that relationship too. This is just to show you how deep you can fall if you don't take your mental health seriously. Talk to somebody, act on your issues, take medications if necessary, or you will end up old, alone and slave of twothousand fears, like me.
reply:
Hey there, I understand the societal pressures can often lead us to compare ourselves unfavorably with others. But remember, every person is unique in their own way. It's important to understand that even if some people might have offhandedly made comments, it doesn't quantify your worth or ability as a man. 

Regarding your anxiety, it is a very complex issue and I'm really sorry you're going through it. Please don't hesitate to seek professional help. Therapists, counselors, and sexual health experts can help provide supportive strategies to deal with fears and anxiety.

A huge part of intimacy lies in the emotional connection and understanding, not size. If you're comfortable with who you are, this will project onto the partner too. Again, it's not about comparison, but about acceptance.

And lastly, don't let insecurities keep you from maintaining relationships with other human beings. No matter what, you are deserving of love, affection, and companionship. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and take steps in the direction of your mental health. üíõüåºüåà

Hey there, thank you for opening up and sharing your struggles here, it's an important step towards healing. Based on what you mentioned, it sounds like you're dealing with a common but rarely talked about form of body dysmorphia, similar to how some people may feel incredibly distressed about their weight or appearance.

From a therapy standpoint, it's encouraging to note that Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) can be quite helpful in these situations, focusing on challenging and changing unhelpful cognitive distortions and behaviors, improving emotional regulation, and developing personal coping strategies. It's advisable to seek professional guidance about it.

In terms of self-esteem and body image, remember that we tend to be our most severe critics. The size of your organ does not necessarily equate to your worth or ability as a man or a sexual partner. Pleasing a partner is about more than size, it involves emotional intimacy, technique, and communication.

Consider also that self-confidence and positive self-perception can be greatly influential in your interactions with others. Engage in activities that make you feel good about yourself, explore different aspects of your sexuality in a safe and comfortable environment. 

Remember, it's normal to seek help. Therapy, support groups, and online forums can be a lifeline for someone going through what you're experiencing right now. You're not alone, and there are many people equipped to help you navigate through this.

Hello there,

First off, let me acknowledge the courage it takes to share this so openly. Kudos to you.

You're right, mental health is crucial. And it can be worsened if we get hooked on measuring ourselves (in any way) against others. This is a trap many fall into - constantly comparing and coming short.

One critical thing to remember is that everybody - EVERYBODY - has insecurities. We all put on shows, especially when it comes to these intimate topics. People have a tendency to exaggerate or misrepresent reality to mask their insecurities. Don't let the conversation partners of your past define your self-worth or skew your perception of 'average'. The most significant part of an intimate relationship isn't physical attributes, but emotional connection, trust, and understanding - clich√© but true!

It sounds like you're isolating yourself as a response to your anxiety. Therapy might be a great way for you to confront and manage this anxiety in a supportive environment. There's absolutely no shame in seeking help, and for some, therapy and/or medication can be the very lifeline that helps them regain control. 

So don't give up on yourself, and more importantly, don't retreat from the world. Your worth is not defined by your size, but your heart and the immense courage you've shown by addressing your issues. Lean into this bravery, and take the step towards seeking help. You've got this. We're all rooting for you!

I've studied psychoanalitics for years and used it by helping many people online and irl in my native language. (Hungarian)

Looking to improve my English speaking skills to start online therapy, and I'd like to talk with anyone who needs me! (For free of course, this is  NOT an advertisement, and I won't make you pay later!)

About me being able to help you:

\- People naturally talk about their life to me IRL and share thoughts, for me it's natural to ask them the right questions and reflect on their fals beliefs and give a reality-check how they can change and how their perception is distorted negatively. I have a natural talent for psychology.

\- I am very respectful, attentive, kind person who would honestly want to help.

\- I'm in a state where I see Oneness and truth values of life which I follow.

\- I have very serious mental illnesses which I completely healed naturally by myself and now I live in peace even in hard circumstances, I'm in control of my reality.

\- You'll be feeling free and accepted - I have raised many people's self-esteem and changed their world view radically, but this only works with people who are open.

\- Relationship, communication (self-expression and understand others), career, mental illnesses, just any advice needed to understand your thoughts even if it's a small problem...

Feel free to DM me!
reply:
Hey there! Your dedication to psychoanalysis and helping others is truly admirable. Expanding your services to English speakers shows passion and ambition. If you're interested in improving your English speaking skills, consider language exchange platforms, online chats, or even watching English movies & series. 

Also, consider sharing recorded sessions (with the client's consent, of course) to catch potential language improvements. Additionally, there are many online resources out there to increase your English language proficiency and accent softening. 

It's amazing you healed your mental illnesses naturally, your strength and resilience are inspiring. Sharing these experiences could give hope to many. Keep up the great work, happy to see you spreading positivity and help to those who need it most. Do reach out if you ever need more advice, we're all here to support each other!

reply:
It's fantastic to see you aiming to help others, using both your knowledge and personal experiences in psychology! This language barrier can be tricky, but there are a few strategies that can help fine-tune your English speaking skills:

1. Practice with native English speakers: You can look into various language exchange programs (many are free!) where you can practice your speaking skills with native English speakers interested in learning Hungarian.

2. Brush up on psychological terminology in English: This is vital in ensuring proper understanding between you and the person you're helping. 

3. Record and Listen to Yourself: Listening to your own voice can help you spot common pronunciation and grammatical errors. 

4. Language Learning Apps: Duolingo, Memrise, Babbel, etc. are useful tools to learn English and improve fluency. 

Please ensure to establish clear boundaries on the type of mental health advice you can give. Supervision is very important in this field for maintaining the highest level of care. There might be tough cases which could need more advanced level of care or crisis intervention. Have some resources ready for those cases, like local crisis line numbers for the person‚Äôs city or country.

Good luck! All the best with your noble mission.

post:
Hi. I am 21 and I have huge mental health problems that I can solve only by getting a job. I have a terrible relationship with my parents.
 
My mother tries to be a good mother, but she is a Soviet dummy from what was once a person. A lot of things hurt me, a lot of things that she personally did hurt me, but in conversation she will never admit it and will deny everything, if she does not start accusing me in the spirit of "how could I do otherwise? you didn't obey me?".

 My father showed practically no involvement in my upbringing. He was always there, but I don't feel warm looking at him, I don't have warm memories. He's a good man, you don't understand, just broken, broken by the Afghan war.He just don't know how to love, and too afraid to try. 

 My sister with two children and her husband is now in Russia, and my best friend is in Ukraine (he is safe in Ternopil. Air defense works well).
I want to go there, help people,volunteer , do something in life at least once at the call of my own heart, and not under the strict control of my mother to meet public expectations. 

All I have to do is study.  Studying by myself ,long and hard, but for half a year, by the end of the summer, I just have to get a job and leave. I understand that no one from the family will understand my action, they never idid. I tried to explain to them that what is happening is a horror. Sometimes they even agreed with me. But they are so hooked on the propaganda needle that every conversation starts from the same place every day. 
I live in constant stress and fear, very often I think about the moment of my death and how short life it's all so intense it's immobilizing. Sedatives don't help much. I just need something to help reduce stress, relax a little, and do what I have to. If you know any techniques or practices, please share!
reply: Hey there, from what you've shared, your emotions and feelings are totally understandable in such a challenging situation. You're really brave for sharing and wanting to take action. Consider looking into mindfulness meditation - it's been known to help reduce stress and create a sense of calm. YouTube is a good resource for guided meditation sessions. Begin with just a few minutes each day and gradually increase as you start to feel comfortable. Remember that seeking professional mental health support can be really beneficial too. It might seem challenging now, but hang in there, you've got this! #MentalHealth #Mindfullnessüôèüåπ

A lot of things hurt me, a lot of things that she personally did hurt me, but in conversation she will never admit it and will deny everything, if she does not start accusing me in the spirit of "how could I do otherwise? you didn't obey me?".

 My father showed practically no involvement in my upbringing. He was always there, but I don't feel warm looking at him, I don't have warm memories. He's a good man, you don't understand, just broken, broken by the Afghan war.He just don't know how to love, and too afraid to try. 

 My sister with two children and her husband is now in Russia, and my best friend is in Ukraine (he is safe in Ternopil. Air defense works well).
I want to go there, help people,volunteer , do something in life at least once at the call of my own heart, and not under the strict control of my mother to meet public expectations. 

All I have to do is study.  Studying by myself ,long and hard, but for half a year, by the end of the summer, I just have to get a job and leave. I understand that no one from the family will understand my action, they never idid. I tried to explain to them that what is happening is a horror. Sometimes they even agreed with me. But they are so hooked on the propaganda needle that every conversation starts from the same place every day. 
I live in constant stress and fear, very often I think about the moment of my death and how short life it's all so intense it's immobilizing. Sedatives don't help much. I just need something to help reduce stress, relax a little, and do what I have to. If you know any techniques or practices, please share!
reply:
Hello there,

I'm incredibly sorry to hear about the struggles you're experiencing and the immense pressure you're under. It's really tough when the people around you, especially family, aren't supportive or understanding. It seems like you're carrying a weight that's too heavy for one person, but it's inspiring to see your desire to help others. 

For immediate stress relief, I'd recommend some mindfulness techniques. Deep-breathing exercises really help to calm the mind and body. There are tons of guided meditation videos online that can walk you through these steps. They're usually about 10 to 15 minutes long and you can do them whenever suits you best. 

Regular physical activity can also help reduce stress levels. It can be as simple as going for a walk or doing some stretches. Physical activity boosts your mood and makes you more energetic, which can have a beneficial effect somehow on your mindset.

Consider reaching out to mental health professionals. Going through turbulent times without professional support can be really challenging. They can provide you with effective coping mechanisms tailored to your specific situation and if you feel you need it, you may also want to look into therapy options. 

Last but not least, remember that it's okay to take small steps. It's okay not to have it all figured out right away. Be patient and kind to yourself.

I hope some of this helps! You're incredibly strong, and I believe in you. You're not alone, and there are lots of people who want to help. Take care of yourself.

I just need something to help reduce stress, relax a little, and do what I have to. If you know any techniques or practices, please share!
reply:
Hello,

I'm really sorry to hear you're going through an incredibly tough time right now. It's evident that you're dealing with a lot - strained family relationships, societal pressures, the distance from your best friend, and your desire to help and make a difference amid a daunting environment.

Firstly, I think it's crucial to recognize that feelings of stress and fear in such demanding circumstances are valid. Your emotions are legitimate, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed. However, it's also essential not to let these feelings immobilize you.

Deep breathing exercises can be a simple but highly effective tool in controlling stress and anxiety. It can help you to keep calm, ground your thoughts, and bring attention to the present moment. You can try 4-7-8 breathing technique, where you inhale for a count of 4, hold for 7, and exhale for 8.

Also, consider practicing regular mindfulness and meditation, if you haven't already. Apps like 'Headspace' and 'Calm' offer guided sessions that can help you navigate through your thoughts and feelings.

Furthermore, physical exercise can play a significant role in reducing stress and boosting your mood. It doesn't have to be a strenuous workout; even walking or gentle stretching for a few minutes a day can make a big difference. It contributes to better sleep, which in turn enhances your overall well-being.

Last but, not least, consider seeking professional help. It can seem a daunting step, but talking your feelings through with a therapist or counsellor can be incredibly valuable. There are resources available that can provide help remotely if that's something you would be comfortable with.

Remember, it's okay not to be okay. You don't have to go through this alone. Reach out to people you trust. Every small step counts. Know that you are strong and you have the capacity to navigate through this challenging period. We're here for you. 

Please take care of yourself.

post:
I‚Äôm so sick of going online every day and seeing all men get lumped together in derogatory statements. I have horrendous self esteem and self worth issues, and have all of my life. So every time I see one of these comments or memes about how men are useless, how we‚Äôre scum, how we mistreat women, etc., it kicks me down even further. It makes me feel like if there are so many people who would hate on me just for my sex/gender then what‚Äôs the point of living? So I can have my already low self worth smashed even flatter? And I can‚Äôt even speak up about stuff like this outside of places like this subreddit. The moment i do I‚Äôm met with ‚Äúthere is no misandry‚Äù and accusations of being an incel, as though voicing concern at having my psyche whipped everyday could somehow make me think women owe me sex or mistreat them. No. I just makes me think a lot of people out there hates me until they get to know me. It‚Äôs shit like this that makes me immense grateful (not proud) that I‚Äôm a straight, white, cismale, because I‚Äôd have offed myself a long time ago from the increased hate from others for being anything else.

Edit: It seems I need to clarify some stuff. I understand why people say these things. My ex wife was assaulted once as a child, my mother was multiple times, and so were my cousins. I understand some people‚Äôs reasoning behind distrust of men in general. I also don‚Äôt feel like they are addressing me personally when people say these things. My issue is that it makes me feel subhuman that it is socially acceptable to make derogatory blanket statements about men or to attack men when they express how such statements make them feel. And don‚Äôt even get me started on how much it hurts that there are people that would try to get others to fear me by default simple because of what‚Äôs between my legs. Just because I can understand it doesn‚Äôt mean it doesn‚Äôt hurt still.
reply: Hey there, remember that generalizations are unjust, and not everyone thinks the same way. It's crucial to practice mindfulness, and remember not to let others to define your worth. You are more than stereotypes. Continue being the caring and understanding person you are, stand up for what you believe is right, and hopefully, in time, you'll meet people who will appreciate and respect you for who you are. Also, reach out to others offline - family, friends, trusted mentors or mental health professionals who can offer you a supportive, listening ear. Keep going, you matter.

You have raised a very poignant and personal issue, and it sounds like you are struggling a lot with this current social climate. It's clear that it has been affecting you deeply and causing a great deal of pain. Firstly, I am really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

What you are experiencing is valid, and it can be very damaging to regularly encounter derogatory stereotypes about gender. It's important to challenge these notions and focus on the fact that these statements do not define you as an individual. You are not solely defined by your gender or any other broad characteristic, but by your own personal qualities and actions.

Remember that you are worthy of respect and kindness, no matter what you may read or see online. If these comments and memes continue to upset you, it could be helpful to consider limiting your exposure to them. Your mental health and wellbeing are important, and creating a positive and supportive environment for yourself, both online and offline, is crucial.

Additionally, while it may be painful to hear about the troubling experiences your ex-wife and mother have had, their experiences do not dictate who you are as a man. We all have our unique paths and stories. 

Lastly, look for support in those who know you personally and can affirm your worth and your positive qualities. You're not alone in this and there are resources available to provide help.

reply:
Hello there,

Thank you for bravely sharing your feelings - it's not easy to discuss what you're experiencing, especially amidst the noise and misunderstanding that often exists online. I'm sorry that you've been feeling devalued and misunderstood. It's understandable that repetitive negative comments could impact your self-esteem.

It's important to remember that the comments you read online are not an accurate reflection of society as a whole. People often use online platforms as an outlet for displaying their own anger, insecurities, or frustrations, rather than a space for empathetic understanding. And unfortunately, these comments can often be generalized, lumped together, and create harmful stereotypes.

Everyone, regardless of their race, age, or sex/gender, deserves to be treated with fairness and respect - you included. Rather than holding onto these hurtful comments, remember that they don't define your worth or value. For each negative comment, there are people in your life who value you and the positive impact you've made on them (even if it might be hard to see right now).

Having "a space to breathe" online may also be beneficial. Perhaps consider limiting your exposure to these types of comments, or seek out online communities that foster a more positive and balanced discussion.

Lastly, please remember if feelings of worthlessness continue and thoughts of suicide continue to creep in, don't hesitate to seek help from professionals. Reach out to organizations which exist expressly to assist individuals facing such struggles, like the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline, which is available 24/7.

Sending strength your way.

post:
I know it might sound bad, but when I was 20 I experienced a psychosis.  Over the course of fifteen years we finally got me stable on medicine and disability income, help from parents, and part time kitchen work.

If anyone has questions for me to clarify please ask.

I wanted to go to gradschool to study afro Caribbean music and religion.  I've been slowly learning those music's on the congas since I was 24.  As I was white, and crazy, so to speak, I burned many bridges with local musicians, who were black.

Anyway I like to continue drumming and continue learning Kung Fu while working for USPS, and I want to read the books in my area of interest.

Is this possible for my future?

I'm interested in Carl Jung and psychoanalysis, Karl Marx, comparative religion myth and folklore,  anthropology, African and Caribbean studies and literature.




I feel really really fucking bad that I can't do whatever the fuck I'd be able to do with a religion or folklore or ethnomusicology PhD.

I haven't had sex in fifteen years.

Things have been getting dark for me.

Ive been holding out for gradschool so I can move to Caribbean or something and learn the drums better.

It looks like that will probably never happen

But maybe getting stable with a USPS job is a good move
reply:
Hey there! Stability is definitely a good starting point, so I think you're on the right track with the USPS job. It may not be directly aligned with your interests but it can certainly give you the freedom and stability you need to focus on learning Afro Caribbean music or furthering your education. Plus, there's always opportunity to keep learning and growing on your own, even if you can't get that PhD. Maybe consider looking for remote or online courses about religion, folklore, anthropology, ethnomusicology etc.? 

Remember, it's never too late to follow your dreams. Small consistent steps towards your goal can make a big difference in the long run! Challenges are there to make us stronger, so don't lose sight of your dreams and never stop fighting for what you love. ‚ô° #ChaseYourDreams #YouCanDoIt

reply:
Sorry to hear that you're struggling right now. It definitely sounds like you've come a long way on this journey and I commend you for that. You've got amazing aspirations and passions ‚Äì drumming, Kung Fu, grad school and working at USPS, which is impressive.

It can be challenging to feel distant from our dreams, but remember that there is no timeline. It's about taking one step at a time. Stability is very important. Having a stable job with USPS can provide a steady income allowing you to pursue your passions ‚Äì be it studying, drumming, or Kung Fu - in your free time. 

Keep in mind that you don't necessarily need a formal education to study the things that interest you. You can read and learn about concepts and ideas at your own pace, without the stress of the academic expectations.

In regards to your interests in Afro Caribbean music and religion, remember bridges can always be rebuilt if you want them to be. Reach out, admit where you were wrong if applicable, and show genuine interest in learning, most people appreciate humble sincerity.

About the personal aspect of your life, it's perfectly fine if things didn't happen for a while. It's always wise to focus on becoming the person you wish to be before engaging in such relationships.

If you find your situation continuing to darken, consider reaching out to a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life. Even a small conversation can help us see things a bit clearer. 

Remember, life isn‚Äôt a race. Take time, give yourself grace and prioritize what makes you happy. Have the courage to live life your own way, on your own terms. You are more than capable and resilient. Take one day at a time.

reply:
I'm really glad that you've reached out here and you've already made great strides by getting your condition under stable management. It's clear that you have a deep passion and interest in afro Caribbean music and all sorts of relevant subjects. These interests can serve as incredibly fruitful outlets for you, and it's important to continue engaging in them as much as possible.

Grad school is a significant commitment, and yet it's not the only way to continue pursuing your passion. You might consider looking into online courses or community classes that focus on these areas of interest. While the path to education and passion might look different than we'd hoped, remember it's the learning and involvement that's important.

Adding stability like a secure job can absolutely be beneficial for mental health. Beginning with a position at USPS could provide regularity and routine, both good for mental health. It might also grant more resources to pursue your interest in Afro-Caribbean music and religion outside of an academic context.

Regarding the feeling of darkness and your romantic life, these are common issues to run into after handling a major mental health diagnosis. It might be beneficial to look for a therapist to help you navigate these feelings.

Remember, life rarely goes exactly the path we imagined, but that doesn't mean your accomplishments are any less impressive or your dreams any less attainable. Please keep taking care of yourself - your passion and resilience shine strongly in your post.
