I feel really really fucking bad that I can't do whatever the fuck I'd be able to do with a religion or folklore or ethnomusicology PhD.

I haven't had sex in fifteen years.

Things have been getting dark for me.

Ive been holding out for gradschool so I can move to Caribbean or something and learn the drums better.

It looks like that will probably never happen

But maybe getting stable with a USPS job is a good move
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

Firstly, it‚Äôs great that your passion for music and religion has given you the will to strive for grad school. Passion can be a truly powerful thing. It's also impressive that you're setting ambitious goals for yourself despite the challenges you've faced. Remember, it‚Äôs never too late to pursue your dreams, and it‚Äôs never a bad choice to study something you love. 

Secondly, it is indeed possible for your future! Plenty of people pursue graduate studies while working and sustaining their hobbies. It does require a lot of time management and persistence, but it is certainly doable. You might consider seeking advice from academic advisors at your prospective schools or contacting people in your desired field to get a sense of what they did to balance work and studies.

On the subject of your mental health, it seems like you‚Äôre going through a lot right now. Prioritizing your mental well-being is important, so make sure to seek help from mental health professionals as soon as you can. There are also various resources available online that can provide support and advice for managing your feelings.

Lastly, remember that your worth isn't defined by academic achievements, jobs, or sexual activity. There are many paths to fulfillment, and it‚Äôs okay if yours doesn‚Äôt look like what you once envisioned. Keep going slow, steady, and focus on stability, because sometimes, stability is the first step to better times.

post:
I know it might sound bad, but when I was 20 I experienced a psychosis.  Over the course of fifteen years we finally got me stable on medicine and disability income, help from parents, and part time kitchen work.

If anyone has questions for me to clarify please ask.

I wanted to go to gradschool to study afro Caribbean music and religion.  I've been slowly learning those music's on the congas since I was 24.  As I was white, and crazy, so to speak, I burned many bridges with local musicians, who were black.

Anyway I like to continue drumming and continue learning Kung Fu while working for USPS, and I want to read the books in my area of interest.

Is this possible for my future?

I'm interested in Carl Jung and psychoanalysis, Karl Marx, comparative religion myth and folklore,  anthropology, African and Caribbean studies and literature.




I feel really really fucking bad that I can't do whatever the fuck I'd be able to do with a religion or folklore or ethnomusicology PhD.

I haven't had sex in fifteen years.

Things have been getting dark for me.

Ive been holding out for gradschool so I can move to Caribbean or something and learn the drums better.

It looks like that will probably never happen

But maybe getting stable with a USPS job is a good move
reply:
Hey there! 

First off, it's incredible to see the resilience you've exhibited over these years. You've faced some major challenges and yet you're still here, pursuing your interests and planning for the future. Don't discount how significant that is.

In fact, your potential future sounds quite interesting: drumming, Kung Fu, working at USPS, and engaging with thought-provoking literature. If this is what makes you happy, chase that. Your dream to study Afro-Caribbean music and religion can definitely remain alive, even if it takes a different shape than in a traditional grad school setting.

Given your circumstances, it might be beneficial to explore online courses or workshops which focus on your areas of interest. You can then learn at your own pace without the pressure that comes with a more formal education setting. 

In the music world, you're truly never too old to form new connections. It might be a tad difficult, given past experiences, but it's definitely not impossible. Try and reach out to local musicians again and explain your situation. People are often more understanding than we initially think.

The loneliness and sense of darkness you're experiencing is something a lot of us can relate to, including me. It's okay to feel this way, you're not alone. Hold onto your interests and ambitions, they are your light in these dark times. You're right, stability with a USPS job is a good move, but don't forget to balance work with your passions. 

It's a journey, friend, and remember ‚Äì it's okay to give yourself time and space to figure things out. Keep on trucking and challenging yourself. We're rooting for you!

post:
Hello Friends, let me tell you about a self-help technique called journaling. Journaling is the practice of writing every single day. You can practically write about anything you want. You can write about your emotions, you can plan out your day, you can philosophize about life. Journaling is an ancient technique, a perfect example of this is Marcus Aurelius's journal, his Meditations. The stoics used to have different practices and methods to make the most out of their journaling sessions, and they included different excersizes like writng about the finitude of life, writing about their values, and reflecting on their days and what they can do to be better the next day.

I have been experimenting with journaling for years and I wanted to share with you the outline I use to start and end my days and my weeks which keeps me sane, organized, focused, confident, and in harmony with my goals and motivations. Here it is:

\- Start by mentioning 5 things I like, appreciate, love, and admire about myself.

\- Then appreciate 3 things I am thankful for.

\- Write down my short term goals (1 month to 6 months).

\- Write down my medium term goals (6 months to 5 years).

\- Write down my long term goals (5years forward). The idea is that my there should be little fluctuation specially in my medium and long term goals.

\- Plan out my day in google calendar.

\- Space to write about personal things troubling me.

\- If Monday, plan my workload for the week. Once I make a plan, I cannot change it for the week.

\- If Sunday, analyze this weeks workload and think about changes and improvements for the following week.

\- Night

\- Write down 3 things I did right today.

\- Write down 3 things I could do better.

\- Write down 3 things I am thankful for.

\- Thank God.

I recommend you try my outline for a week or two and then tell me what you think about it! I would love to hear your experiences.

Good luck to you all,

Ivan Berezin
reply:
Hey Ivan, very insightful post! Your journaling method seems to have all the essentials for self-improvement: gratitude, planning, reflection, and spirituality. It indeed seems quite efficient. I have a couple suggestions: You could consider *expanding* on the things troubling you as a way to explore solutions. It's very Stoic. Also, perhaps *adding* a visual representation of your progress/achievements towards your goals could be motivating. Cheers, looking forward to hear more about your experiences with journalling! 

Best,
[Your Name]

Hello Ivan,

Thank you so much for sharing your journaling method with us. It's clear you have put careful thought into crafting this process, and it's fantastic to see how well it is serving you in establishing harmony and focus in your life. 

For those following Ivan's suggested method, remember that it's meant to be an evolving practice. So, as you're integrating this method into your routine, ensure it serves your needs and resonates with you. Tailor it to your preferences if you need to.

Also, bear in mind the importance of practicing patience with yourself, especially if you're new to journaling. Change takes time. It's a gradual journey, so don't be disheartened if you aren't noticing immediate results. Trust the process and persist; the benefits will follow. 

Remember, it's okay and even normal to have some days where you're not feeling up to it. Don't beat yourself up over missing a day (or days) of journaling. Simply pick up where you left off, and remember that self-growth is not a linear process. It's a lifelong journey filled with ebbs and flows. 

At all times, prioritize self-compassion above all else. This can be one of the crucial points within your journaling practice. 

Thanks again for sharing, Ivan!
Wishing you all further strength, clarity, and growth through your journaling journeys. 

Best Wishes,
[Your name]

reply:
Hello Ivan, 

Thank you for sharing this practical and self-reflective approach to journaling! It strikes me as a grounded and reflective way to engage in self-discovery and goal setting. The outlining of personal qualities and the opportunity to plan and improve is particularly empowering.

Consistency in journaling is crucial to reap its therapeutic benefits. If you ever struggle with maintaining the routine or find yourself being overly critical while reflecting on your day, perhaps consider a more forgiving perspective. Remember, some days are more challenging than others, and it's perfectly okay not to be "perfect" all the time. 

Furthermore, the space to write about personal things troubling you is an effective way to manage stress. Engaging in this process can often lead to solutions of existing problems or helps put things into perspective. In times of hardship, adding motivational or inspirational quotes might also be beneficial.

And as you reflect on the past week every Sunday, remember to be kind to yourself. Instead of dwelling on what didn't work out, appreciate the effort you've put into your work and take note of the lessons learned.

Finally, it's commendable that you express gratitude daily. This practice not only fuels positivity but also fosters resilience, which is essential in our lives. 

Remember, the journey to mental wellness is a continuous one. Everyone's experience is unique, and some days might be tougher than others. But every step you take contributes to your growth and wellness. Your efforts towards self-improvement are exceptional, and it's inspiring to see.

Wishing you the best on your journey!

Forum member.

post:
I‚Äôm from a town of 12,000 inhabitants in southern Europe. During the ‚Äò90s, I suffered bullying from the age of 7 to 17.
Today, I ran into the person who bullied me the most during my adolescence while I was at a caf√© with my parents (my father is 75, and my mother is 67). He was with friends, his partner, and a newborn baby, and I didn‚Äôt want to do anything, but seeing so much normalcy and happiness for someone who caused so much pain wasn‚Äôt fair. It lasted for over 10 years.

After changing schools, the nightmare continued, but he was the one who started it all and relentlessly focused on me. He also became obsessed with my brother and my parents, and we felt powerless to do anything about it. The reason for his obsession was my overweight.

My parents feel that they didn‚Äôt do enough to protect me from that person. The bullying I endured because of them (him in particular) is impossible to put into words: all sorts of humiliations, threats, insults, and persecutions. I always felt defenseless against them, and they always seemed to win. My parents went to the school and the police, but no one paid attention; they dismissed it as kids‚Äô stuff. My father had been saying for a while that he didn‚Äôt want to die without confronting them. They even insulted my parents in public, calling us mentally unstable. For over 20 years, that person and their group of friends have been keeping tabs on me.

Today at the caf√©, I did something ridiculous. I wrote a note, and my father gave it to this bully. In the note, I expressed that I hope he takes good care of their child because he has already caused too much harm and left too many victims, and no matter how he tries to be a good person now, they have caused pain. 

He confronted my father, and I stood up to him, telling him what I felt inside: that he will always be the terrible person who tried to harm us for over a decade, that he‚Äôs now a teacher, and I will do everything possible to get him fired because people like him shouldn‚Äôt be educating teenagers. He said hurtful things about my family, and his partner even sent me to therapy, which I, of course, did, and he was a significant cause of many problems I faced.

I didn‚Äôt want to bring up the past, but I know my parents felt hurt because he caused us harm, even threatening them when they were heads of the family, and they couldn‚Äôt do anything. It saddened me as a child that a classmate would do that to my parents just because they hated me for being overweight. Another thing that hurt me deeply is knowing that, all these years, I have been a topic of conversation among his friends, and they‚Äôve been keeping tabs on me. One of his friends who works at a supermarket laughed at me, and I got fed up and called her a derogatory term. I know it‚Äôs not the right way to handle it, but I‚Äôm exhausted. 

After all this, I also feel quite sad for still living in the same town where there are people who take an interest in my life despite hating me so much, and I haven‚Äôt done anything to them.

All of this connects with my deepest wounds and the little girl who couldn‚Äôt defend herself, but now I can, and that‚Äôs why I spoke up today. In fact, to prevent further harm, I‚Äôm considering leaving a record with the police and explaining what happened. I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs a good idea; what do you think? I would leave things as they are, but I‚Äôm afraid for my parents. What goes against me is that we acted foolishly with the note, but he escalated the situation, even though he was the one with a history of bullying.
reply: Your experience sounds very difficult, and it's understandable that you'd feel deeply affected by it. No one deserves to be bullied or harassed. It's good that you're thinking of taking action and standing up for yourself. Documentation is always recommended when dealing with these types of situations. Keeping a record with the police could help provide some evidence should the situation escalate further. Try engaging with a local community or support group, online or offline, to gain some strength. Don't let their past actions define your present or future - you're stronger now!

I‚Äôm from a town of 12,000 inhabitants in southern Europe. During the ‚Äò90s, I suffered bullying from the age of 7 to 17.
Today, I ran into the person who bullied me the most during my adolescence while I was at a caf√© with my parents (my father is 75, and my mother is 67). He was with friends, his partner, and a newborn baby, and I didn‚Äôt want to do anything, but seeing so much normalcy and happiness for someone who caused so much pain wasn‚Äôt fair. It lasted for over 10 years.

After changing schools, the nightmare continued, but he was the one who started it all and relentlessly focused on me. He also became obsessed with my brother and my parents, and we felt powerless to do anything about it. The reason for his obsession was my overweight.

My parents feel that they didn‚Äôt do enough to protect me from that person. The bullying I endured because of them (him in particular) is impossible to put into words: all sorts of humiliations, threats, insults, and persecutions. I always felt defenseless against them, and they always seemed to win. My parents went to the school and the police, but no one paid attention; they dismissed it as kids‚Äô stuff. My father had been saying for a while that he didn‚Äôt want to die without confronting them. They even insulted my parents in public, calling us mentally unstable. For over 20 years, that person and their group of friends have been keeping tabs on me.

Today at the caf√©, I did something ridiculous. I wrote a note, and my father gave it to this bully. In the note, I expressed that I hope he takes good care of their child because he has already caused too much harm and left too many victims, and no matter how he tries to be a good person now, they have caused pain. 

He confronted my father, and I stood up to him, telling him what I felt inside: that he will always be the terrible person who tried to harm us for over a decade, that he‚Äôs now a teacher, and I will do everything possible to get him fired because people like him shouldn‚Äôt be educating teenagers. He said hurtful things about my family, and his partner even sent me to therapy, which I, of course, did, and he was a significant cause of many problems I faced.

I didn‚Äôt want to bring up the past, but I know my parents felt hurt because he caused us harm, even threatening them when they were heads of the family, and they couldn‚Äôt do anything. It saddened me as a child that a classmate would do that to my parents just because they hated me for being overweight. Another thing that hurt me deeply is knowing that, all these years, I have been a topic of conversation among his friends, and they‚Äôve been keeping tabs on me. One of his friends who works at a supermarket laughed at me, and I got fed up and called her a derogatory term. I know it‚Äôs not the right way to handle it, but I‚Äôm exhausted. 

After all this, I also feel quite sad for still living in the same town where there are people who take an interest in my life despite hating me so much, and I haven‚Äôt done anything to them.

All of this connects with my deepest wounds and the little girl who couldn‚Äôt defend herself, but now I can, and that‚Äôs why I spoke up today. In fact, to prevent further harm, I‚Äôm considering leaving a record with the police and explaining what happened. I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs a good idea; what do you think? I would leave things as they are, but I‚Äôm afraid for my parents. What goes against me is that we acted foolishly with the note, but he escalated the situation, even though he was the one with a history of bullying.
reply:
I'm sorry to hear about the pain you've gone through and the difficult situation you're currently facing. It's clear that these past traumas still cause a great deal of hurt. It's important to remember that standing up for yourself is not a foolish act, and reaching out for support is a huge step towards healing.

Engaging with the police might be a good idea if you and your family feel threatened. Regardless of past, everyone has a right to feel safe and secure. Document any future encounters as well to provide evidence if it ever becomes necessary.

Something else to consider would be therapy for your ongoing feelings of fear and bitterness. A professional will be able to provide you with coping strategies and clarity on seeing the situation differently. You also mentioned that knowing this person is still talking about you is distressing. In that regard, working on regaining your personal power and independence might help.

Lastly, have you considered moving to a new town? This isn't an option for everyone, but a fresh start in an environment free of these memories might be beneficial. 

Remember, you didn't deserve to be treated like this. You're stronger than you realize, and you have every right to live a life free of fear and full of happiness.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through all of this. It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pain, frustration, and fear from all the years you had to experience bullying. Your courage to stand up to your bully today is commendable; however, the confrontation might have reignited your past experiences and emotions - something that can understandably be overwhelming.

You're right about considering your responses and actions. Right now, it might be helpful to consider how, ideally, you would like the situation to look. What kind of outcome will bring you feelings of closure or peace? If reporting this to the police or considering legal actions aligns with your ideal outcome, then it could be a reasonable decision to make.

Remember, it's crucial to place your wellbeing and mental health as a priority. Given the extent of the trauma you and your family have experienced, you might want to consider consulting with a local mental health professional for everyone involved, if possible. Professional support not only helps address the past concerns and make sense of current feelings but can also better equip you to deal with any future encounters.

Remember, it's okay to seek support. You're not alone, and your feelings are valid. Take care of yourself thoroughly and surround yourself with positive influences wherever possible.

post:
I‚Äôm from a town of 12,000 inhabitants in southern Europe. During the ‚Äò90s, I suffered bullying from the age of 7 to 17.
Today, I ran into the person who bullied me the most during my adolescence while I was at a caf√© with my parents (my father is 75, and my mother is 67). He was with friends, his partner, and a newborn baby, and I didn‚Äôt want to do anything, but seeing so much normalcy and happiness for someone who caused so much pain wasn‚Äôt fair. It lasted for over 10 years.

After changing schools, the nightmare continued, but he was the one who started it all and relentlessly focused on me. He also became obsessed with my brother and my parents, and we felt powerless to do anything about it. The reason for his obsession was my overweight.

My parents feel that they didn‚Äôt do enough to protect me from that person. The bullying I endured because of them (him in particular) is impossible to put into words: all sorts of humiliations, threats, insults, and persecutions. I always felt defenseless against them, and they always seemed to win. My parents went to the school and the police, but no one paid attention; they dismissed it as kids‚Äô stuff. My father had been saying for a while that he didn‚Äôt want to die without confronting them. They even insulted my parents in public, calling us mentally unstable. For over 20 years, that person and their group of friends have been keeping tabs on me.

Today at the caf√©, I did something ridiculous. I wrote a note, and my father gave it to this bully. In the note, I expressed that I hope he takes good care of their child because he has already caused too much harm and left too many victims, and no matter how he tries to be a good person now, they have caused pain. 

He confronted my father, and I stood up to him, telling him what I felt inside: that he will always be the terrible person who tried to harm us for over a decade, that he‚Äôs now a teacher, and I will do everything possible to get him fired because people like him shouldn‚Äôt be educating teenagers. He said hurtful things about my family, and his partner even sent me to therapy, which I, of course, did, and he was a significant cause of many problems I faced.

I didn‚Äôt want to bring up the past, but I know my parents felt hurt because he caused us harm, even threatening them when they were heads of the family, and they couldn‚Äôt do anything. It saddened me as a child that a classmate would do that to my parents just because they hated me for being overweight. Another thing that hurt me deeply is knowing that, all these years, I have been a topic of conversation among his friends, and they‚Äôve been keeping tabs on me. One of his friends who works at a supermarket laughed at me, and I got fed up and called her a derogatory term. I know it‚Äôs not the right way to handle it, but I‚Äôm exhausted. 

After all this, I also feel quite sad for still living in the same town where there are people who take an interest in my life despite hating me so much, and I haven‚Äôt done anything to them.

All of this connects with my deepest wounds and the little girl who couldn‚Äôt defend herself, but now I can, and that‚Äôs why I spoke up today. In fact, to prevent further harm, I‚Äôm considering leaving a record with the police and explaining what happened. I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs a good idea; what do you think? I would leave things as they are, but I‚Äôm afraid for my parents. What goes against me is that we acted foolishly with the note, but he escalated the situation, even though he was the one with a history of bullying.
reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about your struggle and the pains from the past that continue to haunt you. It's perfectly natural to feel incensed and triggered by the sight of someone who has caused you anguish for a significant portion of your life. Please remember, it's okay to feel, and expressing your emotions is a normal part of healing. 

It's important to understand that dwelling too much on past hurt can be counterproductive. It seems that you've already taken actions by going to therapy, which is commendable. Therapies are designed to help you redirect your emotional focus and rethink the patterns of the past in a way that's beneficial to your healing. 

You might want to continue with therapy for managing these particular triggers. It could also be beneficial for your parents who are harboring feelings of guilt. Family therapy could bring about a greater understanding and enhance your collective coping mechanisms.

As for reporting to the police, it might bring you some peace of mind to have the situation on record, particularly due to the continued negativity you are experiencing. However, you'll also want to ensure this doesn't further complicate things emotionally for you or your family. Talk to a legal advisor first to understand the potential implications. 

You're not alone in your journey. Healing from bullying is a process that takes time and there are resources available to help support you along the way. Consider finding a support group (online or local) where you can share your experience and learn from others who have had similar experiences. This might bring comfort, understanding, and offer you strategies to cope.

Regardless of what you decide, ensure your actions are contributing to your healing process and not fuelling your pain.  It's important to remember that that's a time from your past and it doesn't define who you are today. Wishing you strength and healing as you navigate these difficult times.

reply:
I'm really sorry to hear about the painful experiences you've been carrying with you all these years. It's clear that the traumas inflicted by this bully have had a significant and long-lasting impact on you and your family's emotional wellbeing.      

Firstly, it's not ridiculous to express your feelings, even if they're difficult ones like these. You have every right to voice your pain and it takes an admirable amount of courage to stand up to your bully after all these years.   

Do what feels right to you regarding whether or not to go to the police. However, please remember to consider what outcome you're seeking. Is it to get this person to pay or lose his job? Or is it just the acknowledgement of what he did, that it was wrong and that it has had lasting effects on you and your family? 

As for your parents feeling responsible, remind them they did what they thought was best at the time and they shouldn't carry guilt for the wrongdoings of others.

Throughout all the bitterness and frustration, it's heartwarming to see that you have maintained your empathy; wishing good for the child of your bully indicates immense strength of character. 

Remember, healing is a journey, not a destination. Seek professional help if you haven't. It's never too late to address your past and to heal from it. And remember, you hold within you the strength and resilience to overcome these experiences. You're not alone in this journey. Be kind to yourself.
